content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												3 years and 1700+ hrs later am still not bored of this game, so it's about time i did a review. Campaign/Single Player - The campaign is a lot of fun and has a great story, plus you will come to see the destrutive power of a single Space Marine and the weapons they own, by fighting wave after wave of Orks plus Chaos Forces. (don't want to give too much away)- The only bad thing for me was the difficulty, hard feels way to easy i've gone through the campaign on hard and only died once (sneeky Bloodletters) other then that it's brilliant. Exterminatus/Co-op - A bit like the Campaign as you fight wave after wave of Orks, but now you can do it with friends plus you have full freedom of which class and weapons you want to use (when you unlock them that is)- You are best playing this mode with friends as some public players like to show off and get as many kills as they can, this tactic is fine until the waves become harder and they end up dying a lot, then when all lives are gone they leave the game (lives are limited and you need them to respawn) Multiplayer/VS - First thing, if you are a gamer that cares about how many kills/deaths you get multiplayer is not for you, due to the amount of lag and sometimes hackers you will end up dying a lot, but if you game for fun then this is perfect for you even if your not W40K fan.- You can pick from 3 class types, Tactical Marine, Devastator Marine or an Assault Marine, each class has different weapons and perks so you can spend a lot of time experimenting to find out what suits you.- There is also an awesome customization feature, you can pick from many Chapters/Warbands or even create your own, you can also unlock different armour pieces for your Space Marine and Chaos Space Marine (so you could run into battle as a pink Chaos Marine with spikes) Overall: This game offers you something new from other shooter games, you can fly around the map as an Assault Marine or overwhelm your enemy with Heavy firepower the choice is yours.Single Player: 10/10Multiplayer: 8/10 Host migration is a pain, it can make some matches unplayable. Thank the Emperor without him humanity would of fallen a long time ago EDIT: 03/05/2015Bin asked a lot lately if mulitplayer is dead, you should be able to find matches for Seize Ground and Annihilation but Capture the Flag, Capture and Control plus Dreadnought Assault are dead for now, but there is a group called  Red Thirst  that gets players together to play these modes so if your interested in joining, the group is on my profile.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												I rather enjoyed this and I must admit, having played a number of Warhammer 40k games throughout the years this is the only one I've gone through that captured a fraction of the atmosphere and "flavour" of the 40k universe. It's not something I can easily describe, but clearly the developers Relic have an understanding of the universe and the factions within. For the most part the characters, the way they are written and the way they reacted to the games plot and situations was very .. "warhmmer"  and it was stronger for that in my mind.One thing this game absolutely nailed was the scale. The size of the Space Marines versus normal humans, the power armour was correctly proportioned and detailed in all the rght ways, the weapons are the correct sizes, the vehicles, buildings, aliens... everything was bang on as far as I am concerned when it came to scale.In truth I can't really fault the game too much. It had to step away from the lore a bit to fit in game mechanics, for example a Space Marine Captain (leader of a 100 strong Space Marine Company, veteran of centuries of warfare) wouldn't turn up to battle with just 2 fellow Space Marines in tow..  armed with a standard Bolter and Combat knife, but that had to be done for progression of course... by the end of the game I had a personal force field (Iron halo), a selection of around 7 different firearms, and a choice between a chain sword, power axe and a blummin' two handed thunder hammer. Not really correct in the world...  but makes sense in a game.The game itself was good fun, melee combat was well done, although an ability to parry would have been nice, and the gun play felt very heavy and dangerous. They got the feel and sound of a Bolter just as I imagine it, bang on the money, and at times I really felt like I was playing a real Space Marine from the stories and board games.The main critism has to be the checkpoint system. Some poorly placed checkpoints sapped a little joy from the experience, mainly the one's that were frequently placed before an unskippable in engine cutscene... which generally pre-empted a major engagement  you could easily lose.... only to then repeat the whole scene again when the you're plonked back at the checkpoint. That wasn't good.However that last point aside, an enjoyable game and glad I finally played it!

content:
Posted: April 17, 2014
TL;DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:We have all seen big men, wearing big armor, wielding big guns and doing manly stuff from previous games (like Gears of War or Star Craft), but have you ever wondered who started it all?Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a Third Person Hack, Slash and Shooter game developed by Relic Entertainment who has constantly delivered quality work when dealing with the Warhammer 40k universe.STORY (No Spoilers):You play as Captain Titus of the Ultramarines, along side his friend Sidonus and the newly initiated Leandros, all of whom are sent to the forge world of Gaira with the objective of protecting a Warlord Class Titan from being looted by a full Ork Invasion. Unknown to Captain Titus, however...other forces are at work there.PROS:+ Visuals (as a whole): -This game boast beautiful cut scenes, epic scenery, massive buildings and intense combat. Model and Animation quality are very well made which is complemented by its superior sound quality. The violence in this game is extreme and oddly very satisfying.+ Audio: -From the soundtrack to the footsteps and  bolter or lasgun fire, Relic has performed admirably on the sound assets which greatly improves the immersion experience. The voice acting delivered by Mark Strong as Captain Titus is great and complemented by the performance of the supporting cast.+ Story: -The game offers a linear story progression which contains enough lore to satisfy the old school and long time fans of the Warhammer 40k Universe, but at the same time, is easy enough to comprehend and understand for the new comers. Story is around 8 to 9 hours long, and 6-7 if you have already played it once. The difficulty level of the game does merit a replay.+ Multiplayer: -I normally don't consider multiplayer because I'm a singleplayer oriented gamer but I was able to substantially play the multiplayer mode of Space Marine and was impressed. Multiple game modes and heavy customization really is a big bonus here.CONS:- Texture Quality: -Although I said that visuals AS A WHOLE is good, the texture quality of this game is quite inferior. It may have looked good on the console versions but on the PC on 1080p, one can see that the textures used was only low res. The poor lip syncing was also a minor annoyance for me. The Artstyle is great but it does not excuse low resolution textures specially on the PC.- Terrible PC Settings: -This game should have had a more extensive PC settings instead of the generic preset of “low-medium-high”. I feel that devs who does not put effort on the settings are not fully utilizing the capabilities of the PC as a gaming platform. On the up side, at least gamers with not so powerful systems can still enjoy the game and have fun.- Disappointing Boss Fight (NO SPOILERS): -A certain boss fight for me was very disappointing since it was more or less a quick time event and mini-game than an actual fight. The fight in itself was still badass and manly as hell with regards to the story though.CONCLUSION:GREAT GAME, extremely fun and satisfying to play with a very enjoyable singleplayer and multiplayer experience.WORTH IT?:The game is well worth its full price for not just the fans of the Warhammer 40,000 universe but fans of 3rd person action games and new comers to the franchise alike.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:Miyumi's Review Corner (MIRECO)

												The epitome of Warhammer 40k in a third-person format, done completely right.+ Solid storyline befitting the WH40K universe.+ Solid mechanics that seamlessly flows from shooting to melee.+ Excellent thematic carry-overs from the written word of WH40k depicted in videogame format. Boltors feel *exactly* like how they're supposed to. Visceral combat feels exactly like how its depicted in the lore, etc.+ Pacing that leads from one segment of the Adeptus Astartes to another easily.- You dont get to play anything more than Space Marines.- Multiplayer is basically Horde mode vs Orcs, or Space Marines vs Chaos Space Marines. Great, but nothing more.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third person hack-and-slash set in the beloved Warhammer 40k sci-fi universe. It's a worthy addition to the RTS video games that the franchise is known for. The gameplay is simple and intuitive with easy to control shooting and sword fighting mechanics. The game is linear but not to it's own detriment. It uses the linearity to create a unique action game that puts you right into the boots of a Warhammer Space Marine fighting against the legions of Orks.The campaign is fairly short, and it has it's quirks some of which can become quite grating as the game progresses. A part from that the game truly delivers in all other fashions that an action game and more importantly a Warhammer game should. Brutal action, satisfying kill animations, and a fairly well developed multi-player experience really makes the game the complete package. It's game that's worth playing, and it's unfortunate that it got overlooked by many people.The multiplayer with its coop wave based game mode titled "Exterminatus" is one hell of fun experience that will give you many hours of fun.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												A highly under-rated entertaining action game.Pros  -The 40k universe is well pictured and as expected revolves around the unsubtle epicness of the franchise.  -The RPG elements nicely supports the action part of the game, rather in-depth visual personalisation and decent class/ability/perk unlockable system  -Great multiplayer in all its variants, co-op arenas, tdm, ffa etc.  -The gameplay action and feel of power is just brilliant and makes all the fun, especially in multiplayer.Cons  -Although a decent one, it is still a console port with all it entails. Console menus, low res texture & poly count, below standard LOD and few graphic options.  -The one most let-down for everyone and a deal breaker for a lot of people, there is no support whatsoever for DEDICATED SERVERS. Be warned for some (if not most) multiplayer sessions are plagued with latency issues, desyncs and host migrations.Get it cheap now, hop in and enjoy yourself. It still has an active community.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
My Warhammer 40k: Space Marines ImpressionsStory:Set in the vast and deep Warhammer Universe, you take role of Ultramarines Captain Titus - extremely well voiced by Mark Strong - and are immediately sprung into a war on global scale when Orcs attack a planet. Which planet? No need to know since it matters not. As an Ultramarine you are not supposed to "ask question", let alone "question orders". Not that it would change much to be honest as I couldn't tell you the name of the planet if I wanted. Anyway, soon you learn that scientists have managed to encapsulate the mythical warp energy and all kinds of monsters are now throwing their bodies like blood-filled waterbaloons to secure this for their respective faction.A deep, long-standing lore as Warhammer's would surely put many devs in a peril to cram at least the important parts into a game one would think. Unless you don't even try. Which is the case here. You won't hear where you come from, why you fight, who the factions are or the characters. Nothing. But then again, as an Ultramarine you ought to fight for the Machine Gods (whoever them might be). Don't ask questions, there is only WAR. Gameplay:It is a third-person-shooter with a very hefty dose of melee combat thrown in for good measure. It is in no way an afterthought though. In fact many times you will realize that brawling your way out of combat is the better choice. Very good that the variety in melee weapons is formidably well as to classic weaponry. Speaking of, you start with only a pistol and add a rifle shortly to your arsenal. During the ~7 hours you'll play the campaign there will be frequent and steady additions to it. At the half-way point even glorious energy-type guns. These especially feel fittingly powerful against the huge hordes of orcs rushing at you during the constant barrage of firefights. Make no mistake, this game is about shooting things and it does not stop until the credits keep rolling. It is refreshing to feel extremely overpowered at times. Movement shows this too as you feel like a walking tank with humongous armor. A tad slow but it conveys the feel of heaviness nicely to the player.One very clever mechanic about combat is melee as mentioned before. Apart from just being a very powerful type of attack, it also serves as the only way to heal yourself - which might sound weird at first. It works like this. After putting your an enemy into a staggered state you can kill it with a gratuitous finishing move and regain a good portion of your health-points back. It is a refreshing mechanic which leads to an extremely offensive playstyle. Don't come into this when you like planning and cover. It's full frontal combat. Set-pieces and sweet jet-pack sections give you nice amount of variety as well.Verdict:Space Marines is a good game with very satisfying combat mechanics. To my disappointment did the devs not put any priority whatsoever into showcasing the deep Warhammer lore. A big shame as this lack of knowledge makes you care significantly less about characters and events unfolding. Why would I care about the machine gods, the imperium, the codex when I never get to learn more about them? There is huge potential with the lore but it was wasted here sadly. The story as well looses importance with this. A very rudimentary construct keeping me go from level 1 to level 2 at best. In the end I only wanted to get to the next area to bash some orcs head. While being the weakest link of the game it only emphasizes how well the actual gameplay is to make me enjoy playing until the end. Ultimately I am glad I played this game.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2015
												Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a 3rd person shooter based in the (suprise!) 40k universe.I've played several Warhammer 40,000 video games. Some were good, others mediocre, and others were so great that I still play them, even several years after their release.This is one of them.This is one of the best 40k games, period. It nails everything- from what makes a good 3rd person shooter, to what makes a true-to-lore 40k game. To start off, This isn't your standard 3rd person-totally-not-gears-of-war game. Whilst most 3PSs focus on a cover system, Space Marine removes that entirely. You ARE the cover. You can wade into a mob of enemies, without dying every 3 seconds. It perfectly encapsulates what makes a space marine a space marine, and lets you experience that firsthand.The combat is divided into two parts- ranged and melee. You are given a wide variety of weapons to slaughter your enemies in different and uniquely brutal ways. Each weapon feels (and sounds!) exactly how it should. The shot of a bolter, the hiss of a meltagun, and the roar of a plasma cannon. And although the ranged weapons are cool, the melee weapons are even better. Chainswords (chainsaw-swords) evicerate and rend flesh whenever they strike, turning a large horde of orks into a bloody mess very quickly. Thunder hammers, although slow, deal tremendous damage and completly pulverise your enemies. The combat (especially in single player or the horde-mode) is immensly satisfying and one of the best parts of the game.The game has both a single-player and a multiplayer. The single player has a decently lengthy campaign (10-12 hours) with a pretty good story. It does have its faults (unfinished story arcs that will probably never get finished b/c r.i.p THQ), and the last boss fight is pretty lame. The multiplayer, although good and reasonably well balanced, gets repedative with the 4 maps (excluding expansions). You also can't choose which side you are on pre-match, meaning you might not even get to see your shiny new color scheme for a couple matches. The multiplayer also follows the standard 'level up to improve' philosophy, with special perks unlocked by completing challenges (some of which are brutally difficult without help). Overall, this is a fantastic 40k game that really makes you feel like you are playing a space marine. It has a few issues (mostly with multiplayer), but you can easily get many hours of enjoyment out of this game.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												Warhammer 40,000 lore has had a long history and has served as the progenitor for many of our modern interpretations of "Space Marines". Surprisingly Relic Entertainment's Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is our first time actually playing as a Space Marine outside of the strategy genre recently, but this entry certainly makes up for any previous lacking of action games. The gameplay of this third-person shooter perfectly captures the spirit of being a 7-foot armored titan, wading into your foes with sword and axe just as effectively as you bring them down with a hail of gun fire.Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine tells the story of Captain Titus of the Ultramarines and it's up to him and his battle brothers to secure key assets on the Ork-invaded forge world before the rest of the fleet arrives to retake the world. Titus is joined by a pair of AI controlled marines, Sidonus the veteran sergeant, complete with scars, and Leandros, only recently elevated from novice, who still fervently clings to the Codex Astartes rulebook. Eventually the forces of Chaos, comprised of traitorous Space Marines, Imperial Guardsmen and Daemons, also jump into the fray to further complicate matters. If all of these terms leave you scratching your head, Space Marine isn't here to drop decades' worth of tabletop backstory on you. For fans of the series it will be enjoyable immersion with lots of little details and call outs, but even if you don't know what the Codex Astartes is, Space Marine does a good job of laying in enough context for you to get the gist.Overall, the story is enjoyable and will continue to compel you to want to play more, and Mark Strong lends a calm and commanding voice to Captain Titus. There are some great epic moments like jump-packing onto an Ork ship, a massive aerial battle as you race to reach a key location first and fighting down a bridge shoulder to shoulder with squads of space marines. The overall story arc does ring annoyingly similar to previous Warhammer 40,000 videogame narrative structures, i.e. Orks invade, Space Marines are sent in and then Chaos gets involved. The fighting is spectacular though as Relic Entertainment nails the feel of being massive armored death dealers that are equally skilled with ranged combat as they are in melee, and the third-person camera transitions seamlessly between the over the shoulder weapon firing and pulling away for melee. The game actually rewards and requires you to mix it up with chainsword and other deadly close combat weapons rather than keeping your distance. While you have a regenerating shield, your health can only be refilled by executing foes. This promotes a style of play that really hasn't been seen in the third person shooter genre, forgoing cover to take the fight to the enemy, but it is an excellent fit for the Space Marines.All of the elements of animation, visual cues and sound design come together incredibly well considering this is Relic's first venture in the genre. The game does an excellent job in spacing out gameplay mix-ups as well, just when you think you might have had enough of fighting waves of enemies there might be a section where you fire a turret from a train at a drop ship or the game lets you take the fight vertical with a jump pack. The sections with this rocket jet pack are especially satisfying as you crash into the ranks from above in massive shockwaves just to rocket back into the air to do it all again. There is no fuel to worry about and you'll have the jump pack until you finish with that section, so use it to your hearts content. When Titus inevitably removed the jump pack as the game moved towards the next level, I was always a little sad and wanted it to continue because those sections are way too much fun.Once you've gotten a feel for the game in the single player campaign, you can jump into Space Marine's multiplayer mode. With Space Marines being able to take quite a bit of punishment, the overall feel is much weightier than the modern military shooter trend, with sustained accuracy tipping the balance more in importance than pure reflex. As you level up and complete challenges you'll unlock new weapons, armor and perks. Regrettably, the balance does start to feel a little off with some of the unlocked weapons and perks, especially in relation to what you start with, but you always have the option to copy the load out of the person who killed you.The coolest aspect, especially for fans of Warhammer 40k fans, has to be the armor customizer. It's certainly the most robust system to date short of breaking out the paint set and miniatures. You can easily get lost in mixing and matching the unlocked individual armor sections, changing symbols and adjusting the paint scheme on each piece. There are also a number of pre-generated Chapters and Warbands, so it's easy to jump in if all you want is it to represent your favorite force. If you are a fan of Warhammer 40,000 you should pick up Space Marine. Even if you're unfamiliar with the lore, Space Marine can still be a fun romp.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												"Succes is measured in blood, yours or your enemies" - Captain Titus, Space MarineAn epic game set in the Warhammer universe where for the first time you play in a third person persepective and face an on slaught of Orcs and other minions.  This game is a must have for any fan of the series and for action fantasy fans a great addition to the Steam Library.  If you have played any of the Warhammer 40K series RTS you owe it to yourself to play this game at get a new angle at the world or W40K.Warhammer Space Marine features some top noth graphics (for 2011) and rag doll physics that are just awesome to see.  The screen can get overun at times with all the orcs and baddies that the Space Marine must attack - and this he does well - the carnage is gruesome and enjoyable.  I really loved all the unique weapon upgrades you could obtain and Fury Mode kicks some major A$$ for when you need it most.  Warhammer sports a moody soundtrack and audio that seems to come from the depths of hell at times... needless to say that it always seems to fit the mood at the right time.  "Humans to kill" The Orc banter and dialogue I thought was rather good and comical at times.The game boasts a sporty/meaty on line package where you can do co-op, on line play & off line single player challenge mode.  The on line that I played was a blast working my way to level 6 and blowing away orcs was adventurous and rewarding.  There are endless customization items and loadouts available for your on line character once you start leveling a bit.  If you plan on doing off line challenge mode it is basically similar to Horde Mode - which everyone knows about now a days.I just really enjoyed this game & it makes me miss THQ - they released good games - Warhammer, Red Faction, Stalker Saints Row... plenty of others.  This is a game where from what I seen you can pick up a few missions here and there or a little on line play for your fix of Warhammer.   There are collectables scattered around the game world where you can collect these items for further insight to the game and achievements as well.I truly hope to see a Space Marine 2 as Captain Titus at least deserves another round of Orc Onslaught after this under rated game has captured a place in my top gaming experiences on the PC.  Recommended peeps - pick it up.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2016
												What I always liked about this game was the simplicity of the experience. You're a Space Marine. There are orks. You kill orks. For the Emperor. If you don't already know Warhammer 40k, here's the deal: 40,000 years into the future, the human Imperium worships their God-Emperor (he didn't exactly want the job of being called God), and spans a million worlds. There's several alien species which would be happy to exterminate humanity (and each other), as well as a sort of parallel-dimension-spirit-world that can corrupt things on this side. In this, you play as a Space Marine: A genetically and surgically augmented supersoldier who can live for centuries (but will probably be killed in battle before then), and has some thoughtful extras like three lungs and two hearts and their skeletal growth includes their ribcage fusing into a essential a solid sheet for better organ protection. Then they're put into armor that makes them even stronger and faster. Right, you play as one of them. And you're given a gun that shoots small rocket-propelled grenades designed to penetrate then explode inside the target, and given a chainsword (that is, a chainsaw with a hilt).Gameplay switches between God-of-War-esque Beat-em-Up action and over-the-shoulder-shooter very smoothly, and it needs to; you'll run into mixed groups of ranged and melee enemies pretty quickly. Difficulty is a surprisingly natural curve, too. You'll see enemies who need specialized moves or combos to defeat--you might encounter one by itself the first time, and then after that you'll run into a group of three or four. As the game goes on, things escalate and early-game enemies aren't ever quite obsolete. Another nice touch is your health regen is accomplished by doing execution-type kills on stunned enemies. There aren't health pickups; if you're on low health you have to charge something and prove hard enough.This is one of those definite "grab it on sale" games. Gameplay is simple, but it's fun and challenging.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2014
												Space Marine is a spectacular game. The graphics beautiful and they clearly show the the people who moddled this game took a lot of time and effort on this game. In the campaign I liked to spend 5 minutes sometimes just to admire the scene.  THere aren't many games out their that have been given as much time and effort to make the background so inspiring and so real life. Not only it shows the Imperium of man in the 41st millennium have such skilled builders like described in the books, but also shows how much potential moddlers can achieve when creating the game people are going to play.The combat system is amazing. When first I heard about a 3rd person shooter for warhammer 40k I first thought it was a mistake and it should of been a first person. But I'm gladly they didn't make it a first person shooter, because if so the game would of been completley different. Not only it allows you to see background the full scale of the war, but also the executions you just can't stop loving. Every close combat weapon have there own executions for different scenarios of combat and for both Orc and Chaos as well as the Chaos deamons.The campaign is a thrilling adventure which you can't stop playing until you have to force yourself to take a break. Like some books that have such cliff hangers on every chapter you can't stop reading, for example: Percy Jackson. There are scenes which hold your breath because you don't know where the squids will come from (little Orc kamikaze peach dogs that go up to their enemies and explode in front of their face) as your in a tight spaced sewer that the Orcs use to get into places. You don't know if they'l go up behind you or not and if they do then they can make you jump resulting in you getting killed sometimes, (which happened to me a lot in one of the chapters). There are also very happy ending like you finnaly beating the Orc warcheif and stop having to fight with the orcs.There are two bosses in the game: The Orc Warcheif and The Chaos Prince, who both have their own combat moves which you have to get fiqure out and make a plan how to counter them. There is only one sidequest in the game: to collect all servo sulls. It's not necessarily quest because no-one gives it to you, but there are to achivements if you collect servo skulls. And each servo skull is reward. Hint: It's something to do with Imperial Guard the and the people when the Orc Invasion struck. After you finnish the campaign, you really want to go and start playing online. There are 2 gamemodes: Versus and Exterminatus.Versus contains different gamemodes where there 2 teams against each oother: seize ground, annihilation, capture the flag, and a dlc gamemode: Drednought.Seize ground is where there are 3-4 control points and both team have to hold and defend control points from the enemy team whilest treing to capture the enemies. Each control point you hold gives you points unless the enemy have captured more control points than your team.Annihilation is where both teams try to be the first to get 41 kills.Capture the flag is where both teams have to defend their own flag and capture the enemies flag 3 times.Drednought is where both teams battle out to be in control of a drednought. At the start of the game or whenever a drednought is destroyed there will only be on capture point. The team who capture it, one of their players will become a drednought. That team has to captaure as many points as possible until reaching 20 points, whilest the other team try to destroy the drednought and dfending the control points.Versus also contains weapon and armor challenges. Whenever you complete enough weapon points for a specific weapon, you get a weapon perk for that weapon. If you complete enough armour challenges, you get different armour parts available to you for you to use.Exterminatus is really fun. There are a max of 4 players in a single game, where they need to work as a team treing to survive waves of Orcs or Imperial guard or Space Marines. There are 2 exterminatus gamemodes and 3 maps. Each map contains 4 arenas and each arena contains 5 waves. The 4th arena however has a bonus round.Classic gamemode is where your team are the Space marines and you fight waves of Orcs. On the Bonus round you fight a wave of Chaos marines and Chaos deamons. There are 2 maps for this gamemode.The Chaos Unleashed is a dlc gamemode where your team are the Chaos marines fighting waves of Orcs, Imperial guard and Space Marines. The Bonus round is where you fight massive swarm of Orcs who have the help of Killa Kans.You can customise your own character who can achieve you the maximum level of 41. Each level grants you a reward. The character is either Chaos or Space marine depending on the gamemode. You only have one online character who can equip different loadouts you can customise. There are 3 classes for online: Tacticle, Devestator (Heavy), or Assult. Each loadout contains a class you can pick. The options are yours. Use which ever weapons you like best for different classes and their perks.    You can customise how you Space Marine and Chaos Marine lookes as well. You can choose chapter set, or make your own set. Most armour parts will be locked until you unlock them in Versus mode by completing the armour challenges. But if you want something more Vertren then you can buy some skins, which are very cheap.The DLC are worth getting. The Chaos Unleashed unlocks new maps for Versus and a gamemode for Exterminatus.The drednought unleashed gives you extra maps for Versus and a new gamemode for Versus.There are a whole selection of VErtren skins you can buy and customise your character with.And there are 3 dlc weapons. In my opion the whole game is worth the price and all of the DLC's. Although I recommend you buying only one Vertren Skin set for Space Marine and Chaos Marine since you can only use one at a time. But the choice is yours.

												A fantastic representation of being a Space Marine in the 40k universe, although it lacked some of the elements i would have expected like RPG mechanics and deep single player customisation i thoroughly enjoyed the aggressive brutal combat and the proper representation of being a space marine.Relic have produced a visually stunning accurate representation of the 40k universe, the graphics while lacking ultra-high resolution textures and great and are sufficiently good looking. The animation feels weighty and powerful, even just walking around you can feel the heft and sheer Mass of the warrior you’re playing as. If you have ever wanted to take control of a Space Marine, the true space marines of sci fi I might add, this is the game for you.While multiplayer lacked depth it is a fun distraction, the customisation on display here is pretty great too allowing you to play as any of the chapters you like and even make your own. Im annoyed allot of the options such as the power sword are behind micro transaction DLC but overall the multiplayer is prey fun.I really hope relic get another chance with this IP, I would love to see a sequel.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												So I was looking through my list of owned games and realized I don't have anything with a hero or main protagonist as incredibly badass as Captain Titus from Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. I then made a ranking: second place is tied between Batman and Strider Hiryu while fourth place goes to the Boss from Saints Row the Third who narrowly edges out The Overlord for possessing better minions. This list isn't up for debate nor is it the topic of this review, though. The topic is how playing such an overpowering character can be an experience in itself. You are for all intent and purposes a giant superhuman walking tank whose main weapons are a fully automatic mini-rocket launcher and a chainsaw sword. You fly around on a rocket pack coming down with a hammer that produces an explosion of concussive force. You heal yourself in the blood and guts of your broken opponents. You can literally run through some of your lesser enemies. None of this makes the game a cakewalk: orks will mob you relentlessly with their oversized choppers, chaos forces have access to plasma cannons and there are always monsters greater in size than you. It doesn't matter. Being such a superhuman badass just pushes you to greater acts of heroism. The gameplay is basic but enjoyable enough: fire those bolt shells, melee the shooters, dodge roll a lot, throw a grenade into that mess of orks, use the Rage gauge before you die... The difference is that being in control of Captain Titus makes all of this so satisfying. There is weight in your run. The ground thumps as you do your dodge roll. Your bolter feels like the mini-rocket launcher it's supposed to be and not some standard machine gun. The execution scenes are barbaric, gruesome and as bloody as any Mortal Kombat Fatality. It enhances the gameplay, giving every one of your actions greater impact. At this point, I should state that no knowledge of the Warhammer 40K lore is required to get into Space Marine. What more, if by some strange circumstance you're a Warhammer enthusiast or a lapsed fan who has not yet bought the game, I can honestly say that THQ have written an Ultramarine Captain better than the current in-house team of writers. Again: the story is basic enough in a "save the empire" kind of manner but it's the glorious yet still humble Captain Titus who draws you in. This is actually the main shortcoming of this game. Outside of the main story you have Multiplayer Mode WHERE YOU DO NOT control Captain Titus, playing instead as a bog standard space marine. Instead of orks you face other space marines where you'll find yourself dying in seconds to lascannons, meltaguns and insta-kill thunder hammers; often with no knowledge over how you could've prevented your death. Unlike story mode, you die A LOT and obtaining perks that would increase the effectiveness of your weapons is a frustrating experience. You will lag, you will get stuck in walls and you won't want to play again. Exterminatus is an improvement and basically Co-op mode where you take on wave after wave of orks along with your friends. It's fun in a mindless slaughter sort of way but it's also a shame how the important perks needed to improve your space marine's weaponry cannot be unlocked here. It's the random challenges you'll hate the most, however. Imagine a spontaneous message tasking you to execute five headshots during a lull in the fighting where no orks are present. It just goes to show how far good but limited gameplay can go in keeping a player interested in his carnage when you'd rather play Titus with all his added abilities than chance a game with overall the same controls in a casual pick-up game of Multiplayer.Overall; the gameplay and the controls are enjoyable enough, Captain Titus pushes all this over the top and the Multiplayer isn't worth it. Therefore, I recommend that you buy the game whenever it is at half price and ignore all of the DLC. Half price for half a product. A Thumbs Up at over 50%.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												This game has aged surprisingly well considering I last played it on console.It's also still tough as Hel on any difficulty, since health packs only exist mostly in the form of giant Greenskins who are usually going around in packs of at least 5.Combat is still satisfying as all heck though, ranged weapons feel satisfying to fire, and jumping into melee after softening up the foe with Bolter fire, Chainsword/Power Axe swinging makes for some damn fun times.One issue though, is the camera is a bit slow, even with sensitivity turned to 100, and since some scenes need you to flick around fairly fast and drop certain foes before they misplace your colon, you can end up on the backfoot fairly quickly.Such instances are thankfully rare, and over quickly, so I myself wouldn't call that a major issue.Multiplayer is barely alive, mainly it's the same 'elites' who are all maxed level and such, so public games tend to be fairly unbalanced which is a shame since the multiplayer in this was always rewarding to play.It's still there though, that at least is good.Exterminatus, co-op last stand-esque is more alive, which is better, since there's something majorly enjoyable about 4 Marines slaying hundreds of Orks across the battle-stained maps in jolly co-operation.Considering the age of this game, the price is fairly high for some parties, so I would say wait for a sale before purchasing ideally, unless you really like 40k, in which case, splurge.Emperor be with you, and may your aim be true.

YouTube™ Video: IGN Reviews - Warhammer 40K: Space Marine Game Review 

			Views: 301,894		

			IGN gives its video review on the new game Warhammer 40K: Space Marine. Does the new SciFi shooter live up to the Warhammer 40,000 title?		

A very good exercice for the ones like me that have a stressfull job, its action from the get go until the end, its a diferent gameplay in the Warhammer universe, but i think the main objective was acomplished, deliver entertainement and on that regard, space marine worth it, even at current price with no sale discount.The graphics not being nothing awesome, they are still good, voice acting very good and the story is good enough to keep you playing, but the strong point of this game is the gameplay full of action, gore and some funny moments with Orcs, who doesnt like Orcs?Pros:+Pretty up to date textures+Nice amount of weapons that you can choose from+Smooth controls (I would recommend a gamepad if you have one, although M&Key is OK.)+Pretty great soundtrack++Amazing voice work+++One of your Ultramarines looks like Anthony Hopkins+Decently long game+Plenty of multiplayer contentCons:-Due to THQ going bankrupt, there will be no sequel to this *planned* trilogy. (Ends on insanely annoying cliffhanger) -The online playerbase is a bunch of elitist neck-beards that hate new players-Even on the hardest difficulty, the game was still pretty simpleIf you are fan of this universe theme, space marine will let you experience what you already know in a completly diferent perspective, recommend you to try out.

Posted: September 19, 2016
												I really love this game, it really brings the world of Warhammer 40k to life.  It tells a pretty entertaining story (I mean, it's not Bioshock levels of deep but still entertaining).  Gameplay it's not spectacular but still plays as a solid shooter (specifically a third person shooter).  You have a shield but it's relatively frail, you're main source of health is to use a melee combo that knocks other characters unconcious; when you see the cue, you can initiate a pretty gruesome finisher that's brutaly satisfying (possibly Doom 2016 brutal) and restores a bit of health.  I enjoyed the Exterminatus (1 to 4 vs. waves) and the various deathmatch type online gameplay (as expected of games this old, it's just not as populated as it used to be).  Back in the day I enjoyed the Dreadnought Assault DLC, During Multiplayer had all kinds of cool armors you could earn.  Unfortunately you might be hard pressed to get into a game as the online activity seems practically gone.  Perhaps they moved on to Eternal Crusade.Shame about THQ, they started making some really good games before they had to close their doors.  This is one of those games you wish they'd churn out a sequel for to see where the story goes but you know it will never happen.

number of helpful: 31 of 34 people (91%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game has been around for a while, and it never really got all the support it deserved. There are a few small bugs and some of the timing is cumbersome, but it's quite polished and fun to play compared to games that are coming out four years later. The netcode leaves something to be desired, but it's sound enough to compete with games like Eternal Crusade, which came out years later.Once you get past the large amounts of DLC skins for Multiplayer only, it's worth the price tag just on the basis of a couple of single-player campaign play-throughs. Getting multiplayer games is tough most days, but when you get into a match is can be quite exciting and entertaining. It's a mixed bag overall, but the pros definitely outweight the cons for a serious Warhammer 40,000 fan even as the game is aging.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												A well-crafted TPS game developed by Relic. Remember the trailer in which Lance Henriksen says he is a space marine? Gameplay-wise it is a very simple game: Titus, our protagonist, uses melee and ranged weapons alike to eliminate hordes of orcs attacking the marines. You also have a fury meter that is gradually filling up as you get rid of enemies. This allows you to unleash even stronger and deadlier attacks.The game has excellent graphics, voice acting and sound effects. While the plot is not something we have not already seen elsewhere, it has its great moments. It is unfortunate that the planned sequels were cancelled as THQ went bankrupt.I do not think multiplayer is played by anyone these days (after all, this is a 3-year old game), but as it is currently on sale (for 10 bucks) you can easily pick it up and spend some quality time with a squad full of ultramarines.

number of helpful: 21 of 22 people (95%) found this review helpful16 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 1, 2016
												Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is pretty cool I guess.Set in the distant future where mankind decided that skulls on everything was totally in. The Imperium of Man has spread thoughout the known galaxy with the guidance of a super powered god-like figure known as the Emperor of Mankind. But the Emperor was betrayed by his favored son, Horus, and after a bloody civil war and the defeat of Horus, the Emperor was left as a crippled body upon a golden throne, which is the only thing that's keeping him alive. Now 10,000 years later, humanity is beset on all sides by mutants, aliens, and the forces of Chaos. But it's not all hopeless, for the armies of mankind also have the Space Marines! genetically altered and augmented super soldiers clad in power armor and armed with weapons that would break your arm if you as much as tried to use them. These Space Marines are split into chapters, and no chapter is greater than the Ultramarines, warriors who lead and try to set an example for all Space Marines to follow. So basically they're the brown-nosing nerds of the 40k Universe.You play as Titus, a Space Marine captain of the Ultramarines. Which is to say he's the star quarterback on a team made entirely out of quarterbacks. You and your team of similarly jacked super soldiers are deployed on the planet Graia, a Forgeworld that focuses on military development as well as the development of super cool giant robots! Graia is under attack by Orks, a war-like race of fungus based aliens that consist entirely of soccer hooligans that come in sizes ranging from big to Big to BIG. Also little Goblins called Gretchins, but they don't matter. Titus must secure the giant robot making factory so that the orks don't strip down the giant robot sitting inside for parts. Which would be...Heresy? I think? Yeah, heresy! Space Marine is a third person shooter with an emphasis on getting down and dirty with your enemy. Which is sexy, but also not. You are given a plethora of weapons to carry, as well as a choice of melee weapon for when you have to put your arms up at 10 and 2 against the alien scumbags. While your weapons fill most of the essential shooter roles, one stands out the most, which is your standard issue Bolter, which is an assault  weapon that fires .75 calibre rounds which are explosive tipped and rocket propelled. I don't think understand what I just said. You are essentially firing the fist of an angry at anything dumb enough to not be born human, and sometimes humans as well because screw em. But sometimes the orks get close and you have to have a strong word with them, and what better way to do that then with a chainsword. A chainsaw sword.A sword that doubles as a chainsaw.It's a chainsaw on a stick.Am I even getting through to you right now? Not only do you have a Chainsword, but you also have a power axe, a weapon covered in a blue-hazy force field THAT IS CAPABLE OF DISRUPTING THE MOLECULAR BONDS OF MATTER WHEN IT STRIKESAnd a thunder hammer, a giant hammer... Also it explodes. How the game works is that you mix your two styles of combat together, engaging your enemies from a distance with your ranged weapons and then closing in with your melee weapon to give them a stern talking to.And by that I mean murder. Your enemies will always outnumber you, so 9 times out of 10 you're going to be in melee combat anyway. The melee itself isn't all that impressive, you have an attack button and you have a stun button, but you can also grab stunned enemies and turn them into a fine red paste for health. That's the only way you can get your health back, you execute the stunned enemies in a gory fashion which refills your health like you're some sort of buff vampire.Or you can get really mad  for a few seconds and let your health refill that way. Luckily, the weapons in this game are crunchy enough to feel rewarding for every playstyle so don't be afraid to mix it up. You're going to get into melee combat, either way. So at least the weapons feel nice to use. Titus himself, as a Space Marine, is a pretty heavy fellow, but don't say that to his face because you might hurt his feelings, and Titus is a nice guy. You monster.Oh yeah, also he can kill you. The Space Marines move with weighted thuds to every one of their steps, making them seem like lumbering oafs at first, until you get Titus to go into a charge. Now he's like a rip roaring retard rhino that can smash down everything in his way. Space Marines are surprisingly agile for their size, but I guess that comes with the whole Super Soldier thing. You'd think that at least their pauldrons get in the way, but they don't seem to have a problem with them. But should you play Battlemallet 40,000: Star Guys? It's pretty good, especially if it's on sale. I haven't played the multiplayer since it came out, but I remember having a little fun with that as well, so you at least have some staying power with the game, if people even still play. The 40k universe itself is fairly unique and the dialogue and characteristics of the characters might actually catch you off guard if you aren't familiar with the source material. I would say check it out, it's nothing amazing but it's still fun to play. The game can drag on near the end, which is a complaint I've been having a lot recently. Where a new enemy type basically forces you through a gauntlet of rooms filled with them before you can reach the end. It kind of feels like they almost ran over their dead line making this game since the last part of the game has encounters the game itself isn't really built for. Space marines in this game don't take cover, and there's a lot of shooting going on near the end.Also the last boss is bogus, but the boss before him is pretty good. Combatcroquet 40x1000 gets 7 giant pauldrons out of 10. It's pronounced Ro-boot-ay Gill-ee-Man, by the way. The Codex Astartes supports this Curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												This is the third person shooter + melee game. I am huge Warhammer 40k fan and if you are you should buy it and if you are not, it is passable. Buy on sale, and don‘t buy Collection ever because DLCs are for MP which is almost dead. I will talk about lore because gameplay is your typical TPS/M with 40k addition.It‘s obvious that devs were huge 40k fans. Game is set in parallel timeline where Titus (you play with him) is the commander of 2nd Ultramarine Company and in "reality" is famous Cato Sicarius. I can‘t complain about graphical details, they are fantastic lore wise. My main problem is very bad story. SPOILERSGame is set on planet Graia. That is Forge World in Segmentum Temperus, it‘s homeworld of Legio Astramana (Morning Star) and production grade is I-Secundi. So it‘s Adeptus Mechanicus domain. Whole game there is no AdMech except one Titan. Even when you force your way to Warlord-class Titan, nothing. Where are Skitarii, Relic? There is no way Orks can overrun one of the most protected AdMech Forge World. No way all Skitarii died. It‘s total BS that some IG regiments (even they are Cadian) can survive Orks and vastly superior Skitarii can‘t. It seems that only one Titan survived from the whole AdMech in planet.And then you found out video message from Inquisitor who has secret laboratory! Ha ha ha. Come on, this is even worse. Yes, in theory Inqusition is Emperor‘s right hand and they are above everybody else (in theory, again) but here we talk about AdMech which is allied Empire with Imperium of Man. It‘s impossible for Inquisitor to set up secret laboratory in Forge World. 1) It would be outright heresy for Cult Mechanicus and 2) AdMech doesn‘t share anything with Imperium because they have monopoly on technology by Treaty of Mars. Even if Inquisitor found out fully funcional STC, it would be still impossible. I get it‘s parallel timeline, but I don‘t like too much imagination or it‘s just lack of appropriate knowledge lore wise. P. S.Your Ultramarine captain Titus is *BLAM* Heresy!"Travellin' through space is boring. Well, boring unless da hulk yer on is full of dem gene-sneakers, or a base fer da chaos lads wiv da spikes, or already has Boyz on it. Or if humie lootas come callin', that's always good fer a bit a sport. Or unless yer have a mutiny or two to pass da time, or unless strange fings start happenin', which dey usually do when yer out in da warp. One time we had some bloody great ugly fing come straight out of Weird Lugwort's 'ed! It butchered half da lads, that was pretty entertainin'. Come ter fink of it, space is a pretty good larf. And that's before yer find yerself a nice world ta crush!"

number of helpful: 20 of 23 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Literally the single best shooter I have ever played. The netcode is horrendous, and the game is Peer2Peer, resulting in a frankly hilarious amount of lag, but the lag compensation usually makes up for the massive lapses in connection that occur. There are also a few unbalanced weapons, which have a tendency to break the game if people use them en masse. The campaign doesn't tell much of a story, which is disappointing, but to be expected from a game where the focus is chainsword enemas. The leveling system is reminiscent (as in, a carbon copy of) the old Call of Duty games, which is aggravating because if you want to use a specific weapon you have to play for a significant period of time before you get it.But aside from that the game is beautiful. The game plays like one would expect a Space Marine game to play; EVERYONE is overpowered! Assault/Raptor marines can traverse the entire map in a few short bursts from their jump packs, Tactical marines can level an entire room with some careful thinking and the right weapons, and Devestators can murderize anything that they can see in a matter of seconds. To this end, Space Marine is one of the few "Super Soldier" games that makes you feel like you are an actual Super Soldier. The combat is stellar, tactics and careful thinking pay greater dividends than being able to shoot well; this might be because everyone has a gigantic hitbox and the aim assist is practically palpable, but for me that's a good thing. Sneaking around your enemy and doing hit-and-run attacks are far more effective then just waltzing into a room and using your 10-years honed aiming skills to get 1337 360 headshots on everybody. Overall, this is a thinking man's shooter. I played it for about a week before I was able to pick that up, and realized that even with the most basic gear and perks (I still use the starting weapons), I could steamroll the entirety of the opposition with a few deft maneuvers. The campaign is more of an after-work/after-school thing, same goes for the Exterminatus gamemode; for those days when you just want to exert your views on religiously justified genocide. The multiplayer is the real gem with this game; a shooter where thinking is more important than skills.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												Brick Shithouse Simulator.Up until this point, all the 40k games i've played have been RTS games, where I had to move dudes around a battle map and make them shoot at things I don't like. Being able to actually control one of those dudes for once is kinda neat, even if I'm not particularly interested in this franchise: it just has some good games made from it.It's pretty much your typical 40k Space Marine plot in that you are sent to punch some Orcs, but a much greater threat looms that is unknown to you until you unwittingly assist them. Then it's a more serious fight as you are forced to confront this larger danger and ultimately beat it. Perhaps the most notable art of the plot are the questions asked about your main character, and whether or not they themselves are loyal and not falling into villainy. Sadly the game leaves this question ultimately unanswered. Guess they had to do something to leave the possibility of a sequel open. >_>Gameplay-wise it is fairly mixed. The combat and all the nice weapons to use are fun, but the entire game pretty much consists of going through linear areas and killing hordes of enemies. Also it's not particuarly long, and it has a multiplayer thing that means i'll never 100% this game. Raeg.If you are a fan of 40k and you always wanted to run around being a Space Marine instead of just commanding them in a smelly RTS, then I guess this is a game you can play to satisfy that itch. But for people who are not fans of this series, I wouldn't bother. In the end i'll say "yes" because it is, ultimately, a fan game, and those fans probably will enjoy this game to some degree.Bwee.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												WARHAMMER 40.000: SPACE MARINE™ is a Third Person Shooter from Relic Entertainment (the game-development studio responsible for the classic Space-RTS HOMEWORLD, as well as renowned RTS-series' COMPANY OF HEROES and WH40K: DAWN OF WAR) and was published in 2011 by the now-defunct THQ Inc. The game is based on the Table-Top tactical wargame WARHAMMER 40.000 (WH40K) by Games Workshop and features:A full-fledged SINGLE PLAYER STORY-MODE that will take between 6 - 10 hours to finish (depending on difficulty)A tacked-on but insanely addictive COMPETITIVE MULTIPLAYER MODE (with way too few maps or game-modes; also the worst internet-connection system for mp-games ever conceived by humans: Peer-to-Peer connection. Like, seriously, Relic, FFS!!!)And an even more tacked-on but also insanely fun 4 PLAYER CO-OP MODE (which suffers from the fact that it uses options and systems from the competitive mp-mode)STORY & GAMEPLAY:It is the grimdark future of space and there is only war, and as you may or may not know, war never changes. What this means is that everything absolutely sucks for everyone, especially if you are a human worker or a human soldier amongst the billions upon billions of other, unimportant human beings on one of the many planets belonging to the Imperium of Man. One such place is the forge-world Graia and it's being attacked by an overwhelming planetary invasion force of the ORKS, one of the many weird, disgusting and/or brutal Xenos-races threatening the Imperium, who like nothing more than to crush your skull and paint their cars red with your blood to make them go faster (obviously).There are, however, some people in the future of space who don't think that everything sucks! These people are, of course, the Space Marines™, who are the very best of the best in the galaxy and have been genetically modified and outfitted to deal with the absolute worst that the future, space and beyond have to offer. Space Marines™ enjoy nothing more than fighting (and eventually dying) for the God-Emperor of Mankind. And when they are not fighting or dying they are usually found praying to the Emperor for more fighting and the honour of dying a glorious death during fighting.So now imagine an 8-foot tall, towering half-god encased in mighty, shiny power-armor, equiped with an assault rifle that shoots grenades in one hand, a chainsaw in the shape of a sword in the other, wearing a helmet that looks more badass than that of Darth Vader™ and implanted with, among other things, a second heart to withstand the most brutal of heartbreaks (and I don't mean the kind that you and I go through when Megan Fox or Ryan Gosling never answer our phone calls) and you get an idea of what it is to be one of the Emperor's finest.Actually, stop imagining things and start playing this game because, quite frankly, there is nothing quite like it. This isn't Gears of War™, where you cower behind chest-high walls, sucking your thumb until your health regenerates and then sometimes take pot-shots against ugly-looking freaks. No, here you charge into a horde of said freaks and smash their heads in to regenerate your health back (your shield will refill on its own, though, no smashing and bashing required). Use a variety of ranged weaponry, such as your trusty Bolter, plasma weapons, grenades or sniper rifles and shotguns that shoot flames instead of bullets, as well as various melee weapons, such as the iconic Chainsword, the Power Axe and the epic Thunder-Hammer (long, strong and throbbing with energy) to vanquish countless waves of cartoonishly villanous beasts and demons. Please the God-Emperor by bringing death to his enemies and he will refill your FURY, granting you a temporary boost to your awesomeness with more head-smashing power for melee attacks and bullet-time™ for shooty attacks.Enjoy fluid and seamless combat that allows you to run into a group of enemies, shoulder-barge the lot of them, slap one, stomp another, then grab another one, cut him into pieces and then spray the rest of them with bolter-rounds until they explode into chunky bits, all in the matter of seconds and through the press of a few buttons/keys.The gameplay is solid, though repetitive; you'll spend hours upon hours fighting against the hordes of the Ork race, which, even though you continuously acquire new gear throughout the course of the campaign, can get tiring after an hour or two of playtime. This is especially true if brown, grey and more brown corridors and levels bore you quickly. On the other hand, to mix things up you get to use a jetpack (or jump-pack) from time to time, allowing you to take to the skies and crush your enemies from above. And we all know that jetpacks make everything better in video-games, don't we?Anyway, eventually you will get to fight some other enemies later on, but for most of the game it's Orks, Orks, Orks, big Orks, small Orks, bigger Orks, even BIGGER Orks and then more Orks.The story is serviceable and nothing ground-breaking (well, this isn't exactly Shakespeare: The Video-Game here), just your typical WH40K-fare. However, the voice-acting is solid enough, with a strong central performance by british actor Mark Strong (which you may or may not remember from films such as "Zero Dark Thirty" or the first "K i c k - A s s").OVERALL:Even though it is repetitive & brown I still I love this game more than any of the other repetitive & brown games that I have played within the last 4 - 5 years, simply for the fact that this game is unique in the way combat works; you feel like a walking tank and unstoppable when you cut through tons of enemies like a hot knife through kittens....er...I mean butter, yes....butter. Though, the threat of death is always present and you can easily lose yourself in the adreanline rush of power-tripping, only to let your guard down and allow enemies to surround you, swarm you and then kill you in the matter of seconds. You have to be mindful of your attackers, of your surroundings and you have to use everything to your advantage. Use your entire arsenal against your foes, think tactically, be mobile and never forget   to user cover - but without having to sit behind it like a little girl crying for her dead kittens.....errr...This is a flawed little gem of a game, but one that is definitely worth the price of admission.Seriously, if this game happens to be on sale, like, right now then just buy the bloody thing! Why are you even wasting time reading reviews when you could be single-handedly performing awesome bloody grimdark-genocide already? I would whole-heartedly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys action-games, especially players of classic shooters such as DooM, Quake, Blood, etc. or any other game that focuses more on mobility and diverse weaponry rather than staying stationary behind walls with marginaly different assault rifles.And while some hardcore WH40K-fans may cringe at some of the design choices in the game (because some things in this game do not conform to the established lore of the franchise) everyone should just take this game for what it is: A carnage-filled and action-packed power-fantasy (from an admittedly brown, bitter and boring-looking future).---A NOTICE ON THE DLC-PACKS:All of the DLC-packs are for the MULTIPLAYER only! Thus it is not worth having the various (cosmetic!) DLC- armors and weapons if you're not absolutely into the online-portion of the game. The gamebreaking bugs on the CHAOS DLC multiplayer-maps prevent them from being enjoyed by what's left of the community. You can still find people playing the Chaos Invasion map for the EXTERMINATUS CO-OP mode but you have to decide if that alone is worth paying full price.The DREADNOUGHT DLC, on the other hand, is an additional VERSUS game-mode that, while awesome, generally just isn't being played.

content:
Posted: March 23
												This is a game you play for when you want to turn your brain off and bulldoze your way through hordes of enemies. The game stays true to the source material and really makes you feel the part of an Adeptus Astartes. The sounds are great, the visuals are acceptable (though given the games location, I was pleasantly surprised with how they created variety), the story is pretty standard for a Warhammer 40K title with a twist that I admittedly didn't see coming, but where this game truly shines is in the combat.The guns are all fun, mostly portable with a couple turret sections scattered here and there, though eventually you find the ones that you stick with for the remainder of the game, *cough* Lazcannon *cough*. The melee weapons and the jump pack though are the ones that make you feel like an angel of death with the Chainsword, Power Axe, and Thunder Hammer all available for use. Executions are both the most satisfying and bloody kills you can get, but also the way you get health back something especially important on the higher difficulties.Ultimately, this is a fantastic title which offers a surprisingly challenging campaign on Hard and all the blood and gore you could ever want.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Do you enjoy a nice neon-paletted future where corporations rule and humanity is kept down by an oppressive government? Well then you'll like this, provided you don't want the neon palette. This is the vision of a future where humanity is past its' prime and is trying to fend off the slow decay of time; all while fending off hordes of aliens and daemons. The grimness of this universe is a refreshing twist, even after several decades as a series.Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine puts you in the boots and bulky armour of one of the Imperiums' chapters of Space Marines. If you like sitting behind a wall and occasionally firing over the wall, then just stop there. In this game, there ARE no walls (metaphorically speaking of course)! YOU are the wall. You are a shield for the weak and a sword to be swung by the powers that be. As much as the game preaches that life is the Emperors' currency; you are a sturdy block of gold, in a world populated by pennies and pound coins. So what makes you so valuable, apart from the shiny aspect of your nature?You are a block of Gold. Let's do a comparison. I want you to drop a penny onto your fingers while they are on a desk. Didn't hurt, did it? Now; drop a big block of Gold. If you actually did, I applaud your delusion of invulnerability, but I'm not going to kiss your boo-boo better. If you didn't; you're smarter than the person asking me to kiss the boo-boo. You see, logical thought dictates that there is a big difference in the damage a penny and a Gold Brick can do. You play the heavier of the two objects; that most delightful bringer of death. You are a big stompy thundering cannon comprised of flesh and muscle, located securely behind an energy shield and a hell of alot of metal. You don't fire a little 9mm pistol as you do in so many other titles. With your bulkier stature, you should be able to wield more mighty weapons and this game will allow you. Ever wondered what happens when a rocket propelled explosive shell (with a diameter of nearly an inch) comes into contact with the face of a 6 foot Ork, armed with naught but a club and a suicidal disregard for the laws of physics and mortality? If you answered "red?" then the klaxons in your room, set to ring with the sounds of victory when you are correct (at least if you're as egocentric as I) should be deafening you in reward for your foresight.In a world full of games with lots of brown or orange; this game decides that red is still a viable colour. VERY viable. In fact, so viable that often times you will encounter pools of red where once a green enemy stood. If you are discouraged by blood, this game isn't for you. If you like blood, this game delivers it in such vast amounts that even the least sadomasochistic of us would still require the unbuttoning of the jeans to alleviate the tightness the combat produces. While I recommend this game to women as well, this game has an undeniable reek of man about it. I would be surprised if the word "testosterone" was not included once in every five lines of code written for the engine. While there is a brilliant plot behind the title, it isn't one that I'd recommend you buy the game for. The plot isn't what you want in a game, is it? Plot is a nice addition but gameplay is what differentiates a game from a movie or book and this is a shining example of that ideology. You fire rocket propelled shells from a fully automatic death-cannon; when you aren't lobbing balls of corrosive plasma into the faces of a tiny little green fellow. But range is only a part of the game. To regenerate health, you are not allowed to cower. Your health is tied to your efficiency in combat, as it drops when your shield is depleted and raises when you execute an enemy in close combat. To replenish your red goo, you need to turn your foes into red goo, and presumably the splat perks your character up enough to make him healthy again. Still makes more sense than being eaten by a dog in an open world game and healing up by pulling a bullet out of your left arm. It sounds better too. There is a definite booming sound behind your guns and your mighty melee weapons sound vastly different when they smash into metal in comparison to tearing through flesh. Your chainsword revs pleasurably as you swing it and your heavy bolters sound exactly as the name makes you believe. They sound heavy, as if they were firing bolts. Now let us discuss multiplayer. Six big stompy fellows clash against six big stompy fellows and there are three types of big stompy fellow you can be. You can be a tactical marine, who lumbers across the battlefield with some medium power ranged weapons. The assault marines jet around the battlefield with jump packs, slamming with a mighty force into the ground before spinning their melee weapons viciously to rend the flesh of all who oppose them. If you are more of a heavy fellow, the Devastators will fit you perfectly. Armed with the biggest weapons of all three, they stomp and wield death at range. They are so heavily equipped that instead of shoulder charging an enemy to interrupt the swing of their sword; they kick them. Even as you walk, the camera shakes to give you the true sense that you are heavy, gifted the power of a ton of metal and muscle. The ground never seems to sit still when you introduce twelve armoured Goliaths upon a map.This is a game of David versus Goliath; except this time, you play Goliath and logic wins over storybook morality. Big stompy fellows don't get stopped by a stone, they club the sling wielder into the ground with fist and foot.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
												The Imperial Forge World Graia is under heavy attack by Orks. Since Graia is a place where War Titans are constructed it has to be defended at any cost. Unfortunately there is no army close enough to react in time, so a part of the Ultramarine's 2nd company which happens to be closer to Graia is sent there. The Ultramarine's Captain Titus is the protagonist of the game. He and two other Marines - Leandros and Veteran Sergeant Sidonus - barely make it to the surface of Graia since the Orks are already controlling the planet's airspace. Soon Titus finds out that Graia holds something even more valuable than War Titans and that something even more dangerous than Orks is at work here.Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third person action game. It cannot really be called a third person shooter because melee combat is an integral part of the game. Titus has access to various melee and ranged weapons. He starts out with a knife, a bolt pistol and a bolter. Later, more weapons can be found. The pistol and the bolter are not swap-able, they are however later changed into a plasma pistol and a kraken bolter. Titus can equip two more ranged weapons and one melee weapon at a time. Those can be swapped out for other weapons freely. Additionally Titus can have up to five grenades with him. Space Marine flips turret sections the bird. Yes, there are mounted guns that you can use from time to time. But you can just rip those out and walk around with them. There are also some sections in which Titus uses a jump pack. While using one of those he is restricted to melee weapons, pistol and bolter.Combat in Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is extremely visceral and satisfying. All of the weapons feel powerful. One thing the game gets extremely right is conveying what a Space Marine actually is. He is not just a heavily armored soldier. He is a genetically enhanced super soldier carrying weapons that normal people would not even be able to use effectively. A Space Marine's armor is pretty much the finest one humanity is able to craft and only works because of the servos inside of it. The size difference between the Space Marines and the soldiers of the Imperial Guard is highly noticeable. Also you can kill weaker enemies by simply dashing into them. Titus' armor regenerates after not being hit for a few moments. Health however is replenished by executing stunned enemies. Some weaker enemies can be executed right away without even hitting them first, further conveying the actual power of a Space Marine. This is the single thing the game does best in my opinion: making you actually feel like a Space Marine.The single player campaign is fairly enjoyable. It can drag a little in the middle part but it's not that bad. The only real gripe I have with the game is the final boss battle. In my opinion it is quite lazy and uninspired. It is also an unnecessary late difficulty spike since there is only one autosave during the whole fight as opposed to the other boss battle where there were regular autosaves between phases. Other than that the campaign is really fun.The multiplayer is surprisingly well done. It features classic modes such as team deathmatch and capture the flag as well as exterminatus that is basically a horde mode. Players play either as Space Marines or Chaos Space Marines and can choose from three classes: Tactical, Devastator (Havoc) and Assault (Raptor). Tactical Marines are the most versatile character and can equip a variety of different weapons. Devastator Marines carry the heaviest ranged weapons but are the least mobile class. Assault Marines are equipped with jump packs and focus heavily on melee weapons. Players unlock more weapons and equipment to choose from as they gain levels. Multiple loadouts can be saved for quick access. Also, every character can have two different perks in his loadout. Actually you unlock the second perk slot at level 15 but it does not take long to get there. Different perks and armor parts are unlocked via challenges that work pretty much like achievements. Armor is just for the looks, so players can pick whatever they like best. There are several armor sets but you can also choose to mix and match parts of them together to your liking. It can take a while to unlock the perks you want but that is partially negated by the ability to copy the loadout of the person who killed you instead of taking your normal loadout on respawn. The only shortcoming of the multiplayer is that it is peer2peer based and therefore can be laggy depending on who is the host.Long story short, Warhammer 40,000 is a really enjoyable game that is pretty much a must-have for warhammer fans but also worth a look for everybody who likes action games.More reviews here
