content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												It's not a bad game, but it has its issues. The game is generally fun but combat can become stale. Here's a breakdown:Pros:- Certain gameplay elements are quite fun, such as the jump pack (death from above!)- Follows 40K lore so the fans should be pleased.- Various weapons to use and you can choose which combination to go with- Be a space marine badass! Nothing like a furious charge into foes and giving them a taste of the emperor's fury delivered by your blade or thunder maul.Cons:- Gameplay is repetitive, movement is clunky. You're essentially moving from one area to the next to shoot then melee enemies. There are some dodge rolls but your character is about as agile as a rhino wearing metal boots trying to navigate a messy construction site. I get it, space marines are in power armour, but they're also supposed to be fast and agile (apparently).- From my understanding, space marines can heal faster than regular humans, yet at best he has some invisible shield that soaks some damage before breaking and your hitpoints go. Your health does not recover unless you stun and execute enemies, or you use your special ability to recover health. Perhaps some health vials or medipacks would have helped.- There is no upgrade system. Your marine is as weak or strong at the start as he is at the end. It's a little disappointing not being able to tweak things like in DoW 2.- There are a lot of orcs, but it feels like mowing them down is short-lived when the choas dudes appear. This is partially because of the linear nature of the game and when you're defending a point or person, they tend to resolve their issues quickly before the horde gets too overwhelming.- Be prepared to suffer the consequences of your poor weapon loadout choices. Oh, so you think that badass thundermaul is going to bail you out of trouble when you run out of bullets? Tell me again how space marines are supposed to be able to heal when you're eating bullets, lazer fire and grenades before you even get to the enemy.- The mechanics of the game leave a lot to be desired. It's not quite a cover-based shooter, but you can't melee your way through everything. There will be areas where you're pinned down, relying on a plasma pistol and unable to get to the enemy because they're on an unreachable platform. So you use up your bullets trying to take down the sponges while Renegade guardsmen chew through your armour...then come some grenades to flush you out, forcing you out in the open where heavily armoured chaos marines wait with bolter fire.- The AI is infuriating. Your AI team mates are stupid and sometimes don't shoot, they sometimes draw enemy fire but generally speaking you're the primary target. That is, the enemy will ignore your squad mates and charge straight for you. There is also a special place in the Warp for the chaos marines and orcs whose artillery fire is so accurate, they can fire while moving and still hit you.- Be prepared to get pinned down, a lot. If you were expecting a non stop action, orc slaying fest with your chainsword, think again. This game doesn't know what it wants to be at times. If you charge in to melee them, you can get overwhelmed easily, so you end up shooting first to thin their numbers before meleeing a few for extra health. The game is not quite a tactical shooter and not quite a melee/action hack and slash. Because you're so weak, going full on melee is not feasible, but the enemies can be bullet sponges so you may run out of ammo, forcing you to run in and most likely die. There is also a tendency for them to leave you with little room to move when the hordes + long range fire come in. So get used to pointing your pistol around the corner to get a few shots in before the enemy gets close enough to melee.It's not a bad game if you overlook those flaws. It's interesting and fun at times. But there are too many instances where you're walking from one room to access another, or from one elevator to access another. It would have been better if the game gave you more freedom to choose, such as a class or through upgrades. Would not have minded some terminator armour, either.I'd give it 6/10. Get it on sale.

number of helpful: 14 of 17 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												For me, THQ nailed the visuals and the sound for the Space Marines, Orks included! I can't stop slow-walking, just to listen to that steady clump-clump of my Marines' boots as he walks LOL! The power of the holy Bolter resonates beautifully, with amazing smoke trails off the shell. I do feel like I am firing a Godwin pattern Bolter. As with the proportions; I'd have liked the scale of MArine - Human a little bigger, but I am not disapointed :) The background scenery is some of the most beautiful I have seen in a shooter. Grand towers and ornamented architecture that soar high into the Industrial World's air, the sunset and fluffy clouds are very screenshot-worthy. The navigable scenery is very clumpy and I can tell I am playing a console game. No havoc engine destruction, no craters that remain...a PC could handle that, but a console cannot, so I do not like the reminders that I am having to compromise on gameplay yet still pay full price. It does get repetetive. I find myself having to constantly re-try checkpoints for some silly bit that I just can't get past - HOWEVER, after practice, you will find yourself succeeding.The main problem I find is the complicated controls. For a start, I cannot re-bind them. Secondly, to perform certain manouvers like simply throwing a grenade, you HAVE to read the rapidly appearing and disapearing prompt FIRST TIME, or else you have to play 'let's hit every key till we get it' game as there is NO controls menu (can you believe that???) for anything other than firing the gun and swinging the smashy smashy.Furthermore issues I have with the controls is that to perform tekken-style moves in order to regain your health is probably THE most annoying feature of this game. I want to conduct myself as a soldier, on a PC, not a tekken or streetfighter gamer on a console. This does smack of streets of rage in places I'll warn you now. But there is something slightly satisfying about taking down 6 orcs in one slash of my Chain Sword. Mounted weapons do not respond to the 'E' interaction move which I actually class as an in-game bug, (you'll see what I mean). However there is the option to tear the mounted heavy Bolter OFF it's mount! >:D This does not mean that you have acquired a new heavy weapon however, as he drops it after about 60 seconds or so. So make the most of them :) The inventory menu is based on 4 slots ONLY, whereby a more powerful weapon type REPLACES YOUR OLD ONE - which I found very upsetting, I cried.Again, with all linear shooters, this game can be completed in an afternoon <sigh> but I think you all have become accustomed to that eh? My advice, buy this in a sale. It is good fun, and if you want your Ultramarines brought to life somewhat beautifully, it's worth it for that alone :)If it wasn't for the horrible consolitis that this game suffers from, I'd give it 7/10 but it's gonna have to be a stingy 6/10.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
												Not a complex game, but fun and stylish. The level design and story progression are completely linear, and all visuals and dialogues are set in the cliché universe of Warhammer 40k - however, I like that dystopic sci-fi world. The game is not very hard either, as soon as you understood which weapon to use in certain tactical situations and when to pop your fury buff. A special mechanic is how to regenerate health: Not some food or med kits lying around guarantee your survival, but executing stunned monsters in close combat, which means that your regeneration is not handed out to you, you have to work for it, and I like that, too. The most remarkable thing about this particular W40k game, apart from the excellent sound effects and voice acting, is your character. It is not a story of "rising from nothing" and becoming a great hero - you already start as one. You are a captain of the Ultramarines, the genetically enhanced elite force of the Emperor in his war against the enemies of mankind, aliens and demons. You are a respected leader amongst your battle brothers, and as every Space Marine has a part of the Emperor himself in his genes, common humans in the Imperial army refer to you as "My Lord" and bend their knees to you. This setting makes it plausible that you are an invincible power armored fighting machine who can single-handedly defeat hordes of opponents with your arsenal of ranged and melee weapons. Plausability is good for immersion, and besides, it feels good to be revered a little!I was a bit underwhelmed by the final boss fight. After several waves of mobs you already encountered before, you switch to a falling scenario and press buttons prompted to you on the screen. You win by - clicking your mouse as fast as you can. That feels cheap and breaks the immersion almost completely. With a little more variety in regard to the mobs and a more creative ending, this game could have been very good - like this, it is just "good enough": 6.5/10 from me, for the solo campaign. I have not tried multiplayer yet and cannot comment on that part of the game.

number of helpful: 24 of 36 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												Skip to "Will I like this game?" at the bottom if you want the summary!Pro's:Campaign - Fun smashing orks with brutal and varied finishing moves. Combat employs  both melee and ranged attacks seamlessly. Ripping off a mounted heavy bolter and mowing down Ork grass is always 400 bullets of pure joy. The voice acting is good and a decent story line. The audio books you find along the way add a nice touch.Exterminatus - Co Op survival vs hordes is also fun with a group of guys, gets very challenging at the end!Con's:Campaign - This is really the best part of the game. The only con is the levels seem pretty plain as far as design, variety, and fine details. Much of a halo 1 type feel.Exterminatus - The 2nd best part of the game. Pretty good, but really disappointing you don't get the very useful finishing moves and some of the melee combos you get in the campaign. There are also only a couple of maps so variety isn't there.PvP - This is where the review starts to take a big negative. I'm not sure if the game originally had dedicated servers, but it sure doesn't now. It uses peer to peer connections. Since the game is a little old, the player base is pretty small and scattered worldwide. Playing peer to peer across continents in an FPS game is a nightmare. The worst offender to game experience is assault marines warping all over the place. It looks like you've dodge rolled out of the way and they aren't swinging even close to you but your guy just falls over dead. The fall speed from jump packs is way to slow. Once an assault marine jumps they can just float in the clouds for 2 min until you show up and slam down with their laggy swings to lock you in. While the jump pack is on its few second cool down they get very boosted "mini" jumps. If the game didn't suffer from horrible lag every single match I could work with it.Plasma Cannons are annoying with grenade launcher like shots all over the map. But I guess I can't blame people for using them. You need to cover a lot of ground to hit a warping assault marine.Another problem is every time someone joins a match the games slows to a crawl while they connect to all other players(another benefit of P2P). It's incredibly disrupting to game play.Yet another constant disruption during matches is "host migration". I'm not sure if it only changes when the host leaves or starts to have poor performance, but it happens many times during matches and you guessed it, the match comes to a complete stop until the new host is in place then resumes. The game usually waits until you are in an important fight to screw you.Achievement Hunters - Stay away!!! The campaign achievements are fun. It's when you get to multiplayer where you will get killed. There are 3 really bad achievements here.       1. Completing all 90+ weapon challenges . It takes a very, very long time to get and will make you depressed if you want 100%. They aren't all just based on getting x amount of kills with x weapon. They include things like kill streaks, multi-kills, and head shot only kills(not terrible but keep in mind the lag).       2. Getting 40k kills(combined all game types). The best way is playing exterminatus where you fight waves, but the game will get boring way before that.       3. The 3rd is having a 10 KD on annihilation. That's a problem because either no one plays it or the match is too short to get in the 10 kills in time. You could boost in a private match to get, up to your standards.Will I like this game?Achievement Hunters: No!! Do not buy. You will suffer greatly.Single Player: You will love it! Wait for a sale though.DLC: Do not buy, no one plays it.Co Op: Limited amounts of replay ability since only one mode and a couple of maps, worth it on sale only.PvP: Although has potential to be fast paced, brutal, and constant action; it's just drowned out by aweful P2P lag. Do not buy at any price.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												One of the most fun single player campaigns I've played in a hack and slash game ever, even more so if you already enjoy the W40K universe.Gameplay is solid with a decent challenge given and intuitive controls. Though not overly difficult, it is still challenging enough that you feel satisfied when you manage to gun down or hack apart the few hundred orks blocking the way to your objective.The devs have done an amazing job with the weapons. Bolters sound and feel exactly like they should when firing rounds into mobs of Greenskins, while ripping them apart with your chainsword is equally satisfying, visually and audibly. For me though nothing beats flying around in a jetpack, thunder hammer in hand, crushing heads into the cement.The rest of the game as far as atmosphere and overall feel goes is supurb, really feels like a Warhammer game and won't leave you disappointed.Storywise the game is nothing mindblowingly original as far as W40K goes but it does keep you interested until the end.  Originally meant to be a trilogy, THQ went bankrupt before they managed to make the sequels so we don't ever get to find out what happened to Captain Titus, but even so it's worth playing for the story if you're a fan of the lore.The multiplayer was fun back in the day but is completely dead now so don't get this if that's what you're looking for.I wouldn't say the replay value of this game is especially high, but I enjoyed it enough the first time through to eventually play it again a couple more times, and probably will again in the future, though your mileage may vary.If you're a Warhammer 40K fan or just of hack and slash games in general, I'd say definitely give Space Marine a go, especially when it goes on sale if you're still unsure.I give it 7 Imperial Aquilas out of 10

content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												This is a fantastic game that is well worth the money (during one of Relic's annual sales). A must-have for any Warhammer 40k fan, as it continues Relic's tradition of trying to be as accurate as possible to the feel and spirit of the 40k universe.The gameplay is a good balance between third-person shooting and melee combat. It is challenging while still making you feel like the superhuman killing machine you are. It has a good variety of weapons, including bolters, plasma guns, lascannons, and melta weapons for ranged, and chainswords, power axes, and even thunderhammers for melee. My favorite combo is a jump pack with a thunderhammer, which allows you to smash the God-Emperor's enemies with the necessary amount of righteous fury.The music and sound design was surprisingly good, with very good sound quality and an appropriately epic tone. It has some fantastic setpieces for the levels, like giant cathedrals and bridges decked out by the Adeptus Mechanicus. In general, it has very high production values and stays true to the lore.It had me truly awestruck at times, as I am a huge fan of the 40k universe and have read tons of the books, but even people new to the franchise should appreciate the grand scale of it all.Get it as soon as it goes on sale.The Emperor protects.

Posted: April 28, 2015
												TL;DR: The epitome of Warhammer 40k in a third-person format, done completely right.+ Solid storyline befitting the WH40K universe.+ Solid mechanics that seamlessly flows from shooting to melee.+ Excellent thematic carry-overs from the written word of WH40k depicted in videogame format. Boltors feel *exactly* like how they're supposed to. Visceral combat feels exactly like how its depicted in the lore, etc.+ Pacing that leads from one segment of the Adeptus Astartes to another easily.- You play the Ultramarines, arguably one of the most boring chapters of Space Marines.- You dont get to play anything more than Space Marines.- Multiplayer is basically Horde mode vs Orcs, or Space Marines vs Chaos Space Marines. Great, but nothing more.- Ends somewhat quickly, and simply demands a sequel, that sadly will never happen as the original developers are bankrupt :(

content:
Posted: August 14, 2016
												A tentative recommendation for fans of 40k and/or @ a discount.This is an old game, with elements of classic arcade in level design and game play features. This translates into linear corridor style gameplay with fixed/scripted encounters that have to be overcome via the only means possible before the area is unlocked and player can progress forwards with the level. The levels blend seamlessly into one another with cutscenes dialogues and animations delivering characterbackground and plot elements between major events and chapter ends. The single player campaign relies on an autosave checkpoint system but once played the different chapters become available for replay directly from the menu.SP levels include static defense against waves, i'll drive u shoot mobile defense, advance and clear (vast majority) and boss style arenas, and jumppack sections. There are 16 sections split across 6 chapters, which i completed within 12 hours as a casual gamer.The game controls are simple and fairly responsive albeit a little clunky in design. Gun play is as expected 1 button to shoot another to zoom another to reload and some guns have an additional quirk or feature like charge up/overheat or delayed activation. The play carries 1 pistol, 1 bolter and upto 2 specialist weapons at any point with limited ammo and pickups through the levels on all but the pistol. Periodically through the mission one will find weapon caches where they can reconfigure their gear and resupply on ammo and grenades.Melee combat is more complex 1 button to attack another to stun each weapon has its own combo animations and lastly a recharge health mechanic called execute which locks the player into a sychronised slow motion animation of varying lengths that recharges ones health a certain degree upon its completion (all enemies remain active during this time leaving the player incredibly vunerable). There are 4 melee weapons in single player, 1 of wich prevents the use of specialist weapons firing. The game feels like a console port at times, levels have invisible walls or ancle hieght impassable terrain giving one the impression of more freedom and better visuals. Certain points of the game have additional mechainics requiring one to spam a certain key or active the keys in sequence as prompted on screen. There is no jump feature as such but the inclusion of the jumppack as a mechanic means some levels/sections are more 3 dimensional by design. The graphics are functional, the faces of the characters being decent, while the armour texture and details is lacking when close up, namely dialogue scens. The levels convey the atmosphere, but won't have you stopping to take in the scenery much like some games do.The music score and sound effects are all decent, or atleast not immediately irritating after hearing the same thing ad infinitum. The voice acting and audio logs one finds are also note worthy, and while the script isn't all that it is atleast consistently delivered with the characters remaining true to themselves throughout. For those that know 40K they'll understand when i say the Titus would have been more plausable as a Spacewolf than an Ultramarine.The multiplayer is split into 2 aspects, PvP and PvE. They are however, somewhat empty at this time and requires using the autofinder so jumping on a pug game isn't easy but Steam intergration allows friend invites. Both modes can however, be launched without being filled meaning they can be self hosted as SP if one so desires. The gameplay and handling of weapons is slightly different in MP for balance reasons, as one might expect.The multiplayer also has a cosmetic customisation and skills rewards system based on various unlocks through online gamplay. This adds incentive and rewards failure in addition to success helping new players find their feet against the better equipped and more experienced community. Alas these don't work in Sp, which is to relaint upon fixed animations to allow for customisation.Played on I7, win10 64bit, GTX970, Keyboard n Mouse.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												This game was a purchase on a sale, it had been on my wishlist for a while but was fairly low priority. Boy were my expectations low (what with Relic being sold) and the poor general sales of this contributing to Relic's downfall.I was surprised and delighted, and have never been more flipped when trying something new. Relic really got this spot-on. This is a way better W40K game than many others that have come before it. This is really on par with the Dawn of War series in terms of the attention to detail. As a fully controller-supported, console-style game, this plays a very differently to Dawn of War, and is like a breath of fresh air on the PC. It is not a FPS and really does play mostly in third-person, but I like this, it allows you to see the detail and revel in the bloody destruction and orc blood splatters all over you. This is third-person done right, with an over the shoulder zoom for sniping play, so you can still pull off headshots before running in chainsaw-whirring. And it is that mish-mash that makes it damned good fun.The online portion, while not well-populated on STEAM, is a sturdy, challenging defense against the hordes, and I hope more people buy this to help boost the multiplayer appeal of the game, which is surprisingly glorious havok.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												From Relic, the same people made 40K 'Dawn of War', which is still the most popular 40K RTS. Space Marine is still the most popular shooter in the Warhammer 40K universe.It's a fantasy/military 3rd person shooter with a decent single player and a dedicated multiplayer fanbase for versus (mainly 'Seize Ground' mode) and also for horde mode ("Exterminatus").The voice acting in the main game is a bit of an uncomfortable mix of well spoken English people and a very extreme military regime, that's a bit like Rome and *ahem* others that were influenced by them. But this is true to the tabletop games of Warhammer 40K and it's all in good fun.There are elements of gore as you slay the Orks, but whilst they're often grizzly, there's nothing truly objectionable about the visuals or the theme. It will appeal to people with less than moderate world views, but no more so than the endless shooters based in current real world conflicts. At least this is a heightened fantasy world and can just be enjoyed as a game, without being politically incorrect.Many other 40K games have tried to capture the same enthusiasm these games by Relic still enjoy, but none has a five year history of online games every day of every year.'Chaos' DLC does get played, the only one you'll want to join groups to find players for is 'Dreadnought' - there are regular arranged games for that, but if you log on randomly, you won't find a 'Dreadnought' game usually.The rest is all alive and well every day.There's no developer support, Sega took the title a little while back, but has not done anything to it.And there are no dedicated servers which means on the plus side, the game will continue so long as people wish to play. But on the minus, there are host migrations in game as it flips to find the best host - these can sometimes take a few seconds, which seem like hours in the heat of play.In all, you'll get your money's worth from this if you enjoy online shooters with a fun array of Sci-fi weapons, equivalent to pistols, shotguns and rifles in other games.Here you can level up to make your Marine better, weapons cool down or get melee abilities etc. But you can use jump packs and things right from the off.There is a skilled player base. Some hackers and the usual racism, sexism and abuse to be found in all online games, alas. But don't let that put you off a good game - there is a mute button for each player if you tire of the "banter" and you can happily ignore text comments if being picked on for your nationality, political views or player ability is getting in the way of the fun.There are far more friendly people than hackers and abusers. And the vast majority of your experience will be an addictive team battle arena you want to come back to :)

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												PROS- The aesthetic of the game is perfect, the Space Marines exactly like they should, as do the daemons and the orks- The story line is very interesting and isn't just a "There are bad guys here, go kill them" sort story-The multiplayer allows for a person to not only choose from a selection of pre-made designs, but to also design their own chapter or warband-Captain Titus, while he is an Ultramarine, is not a rigid, "the Codex Astartes doesn't say we can do this, so we shouldn't character"-While limited the selection of available weapons includes some of the best weapons available to Space Marines-The sound effects of each weapon sound realistic-Accessible to both fans of 40k and new people, without having to have a section of the game that is about universe buildingCONS-The main character is an Ultramarine (I don't dislike the Ultramarines, but there are other chapters)-The game takes place on a Forge World, but there are no Skitarii-Leandros is an example of why people hate the Ultramarines-The choice of weapons is limited-The final boss is a quick-time event-Unique armour sets only available through DLC-No Chaos campaignOverall, I think this game is very well made, despite the flaws.FOR THE EMPEROR or if you prefer FOR THE DARK GODS

content:
Posted: September 19, 2015
												7/10Anyone that knows me even a smidge knows that i'm a huge warhammer fan, and i enjoyed space marine quite a bit. both melee combat and ranged combat are just as viable as the other and flows seamlessly between the two, allowing for entertaining and gory combat while purging the enemies of the Emperor. The story within the campaign is decent as is the voice acting and soundtrack, and there a lots of nice little touches within the game such as even the random battlefield objects such as ammunition boxes being actual games workshop models in the present - something i thought was a cool little feature. Character development is interesting; which is why we all hate Leandros and love Sidonus/Titus.. and there are some highly unexpected plot twists, ones that you wouldn't normally suspect from warhammer! Even the warboss Grimskull is fricking awesome, likewise with the chaos lord Nemeroth.The bolter was done so extremely well that it just has to be mentioned - a doof-cannon of explosive destruction with a realistic rate of fire for such a large shell being loaded automatically and the chainsword is just as satisfying as you "vroom" your way through orks and chaos. In fact the entirety of the sound design is top notch, such as the heavy stomping of casual marine steps and the general atmospheric sounds. However, despite these gems within the game it does possess some things i found to be issues... - Now, while the combat in this game is rather highly acclaimed, it does not have a parry button; the only way to stop your opponent's spamfest of attacks is to stun them. This is rather...weird... as in multiplayer it's basically just two marines constantly shanking eachother and then throwing in the odd backhand to knock them back for a moment. This results in no skill needed to effectively melee..at all. It's just spam the attack button. - The game isn't too accurate to lore either. In saying that it's not exactly butchering it though. For example Lascannons only instand kill marines on headshots. If it was more accurate to the lore it would kill a marine outright. As would the plasma cannon...and melta... - THQ no longer exists and SEGA isn't doing much, so no updates apparently to fix any bugs/issues (despite myself not actually discovering any bugs but anyway) - DLC has segmented the already splintered online playerbase somewhatNow, don't let these negative words sway you from the game itself though, i found it to be quite fun, the campaign is of a suitably long length and remains fun if you play it in bursts of an hour or so, the combat is oh so much fun and last but not least...it's warhammer! What isn't to love in the grim darkness of the far future!? "SPESS MAREEN, WAZ DAT SUPPOZED TAH HERT?"

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
												I've played nearly every Warhammer 40k game to date but this one is easily my favorite. The combat is simple and loose but very intense and enemies come at you with everything they're got. It makes you feel like one BAMF but more than that it makes you feel like you've earned it. If you've played very many WH40k games or are familiar with them at all really, the plot will feel pretty predictable. I wouldn't go as far as saying it's weak, but honestly it's not the story that's going to keep you playing. I can't say I've encounted very many bugs in the game either. Overall it's a neat peek at the WH40k universe, a great way to get the space marine experience, and a downright excellent stress killer.As for playing online, unfortunately the player base is just about dead and only one PvP mode is actually played anymore. The game is honestly pretty underrated and most people have simply moved on over the years since it's release. Matchmaking for either PvP or co-op survival can take anywhere from 10 minutes to 45 on a bad day. On the bright side, just about everyone I've run into playing online have been really pleasant and there's very little whining and moaning like the 9 year olds you'll find populating the majority of matches in games like Call of Duty. Really it's just a bunch of WH40k nerds that just enjoy playing the game. PvP is fairly balanced, nothing like the cluster**** you'll find in similar WH40k games like Eternal Crusade. As you progress, you'll unlock new weapons you can use and all armor unlocks are cosmetic. There is a perk system but the really nice perks have to be earned with weapon and armor challenges. The effects are nice, but they don't make you vastly overpowered and it's not uncommon to see players with noob gear whooping maxed ones. Armor customization is pretty neat and all in all it's a fun challenge working towards unlocking them and building your own look.The co-op survial mode is definitely where I've had the most fun in this game. It takes a really solid team to actually make it the whole way to the end and also beat the bonus wave, but it's one hell of a ride if you do and a lot of fun with friends. If a team doesn't work together, a whole match can fall apart before you know it. If your team gets wiped out, it allows you to start over from the last "checkpoint" and most are more than willing to keep trying over and over to beat it. Players can drop in after it's started if someone leaves the game, which is good because it's pretty hard to beat without 4 players. Like PvP, it can take some time to find a full group through matchmaking though.Due to the lack of player base online, I highly recommend you skip the Dreadnaught and Chaos Unleashed DLCs if you buy this game. There's few enough players as it is and even less that actually have those DLCs. It's a shame because Chaos Unleashed's co-op maps are actually a lot of fun, but unless you have friends you can coordinate a game with it's just about impossible to get one going through matchmaking. I would also skip the armour set DLCs since you can customize your space marine to look nearly identical to them anyway.The Space Marine game was originally supposed to be a trilogy, but with Sega acquiring Relic and sticking mainly to strategy games, it's pretty unlikely it's ever going to happen. Personally I'd love to see it and support the idea, but if you're wondering if you should expect more it's probably safe to say no.

content:
Posted: April 21
★★★☆☆If I could describe this game in a one word, than that would be 'brown'. Not only because most of the levels are colored brown (despite these being indoors and outdoors), but also because it only seems to be monotonous in its game design (its generic and almost invisible among the hundreds of other brown gameworlds created in the last generation). Ironicly, the orcs also aren't really creative with their words as I heard "Space Marine!" about a hunderd times. I'd say this isn't necessarily a bad thing for a game that tries to show of a grim, dark episode of the Warhammer universe, but it does leave a lot to be desired in thematical exploration (not much to learn about the lore here) and gameplay. As for replayability, I'd recommend first time players to start the campaign on Hard, as the first two-thirds of it are a boring slog to play through.Don't get the game at full price (which is currently 20 bucks). The campaign is only about 6-7 hours long, the multiplayer is basicly dead (daily population around 60 players, as of 2017) and by now there are tons of other action games out there of the same caliber or better. I bought this game because I wanted to explore the lore a bit, but like I wrote above, it doesn't particulairy show that off here.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												Space Marine is a third-person, over-the-shoulder shooter. You play as the Adeptus Astartes Ultramarines Captain, Titus. His mission is to save the planet by doing what no human could ever do: brutally murder Orks and Chaos forces by repeatedly shoving  a chainsword in various orifices. Is this game good? Definitely. Is it fun? Fantastically so!The gameplay is your simple shooter affair: center the middle of your screen on something you want dead and pull the trigger to watch it be made so. Accompanying that is a wonderfully gory melee system using chainswords, power axes, and thunder hammers to wonderful effect. The bolter rounds feel like they punch the enemy and the melee weapons can send them careening across the map. The combat is most excellent and definitely worth the money for that, if you enjoy rampage.The story is equally compelling. While it is set in a "parellel timeline" where Titus is captain of the second company as opposed to Cato Sicarius, it still feels just as real of a Warhammer story. Titus is strong, dutiful, and is more than ready to destory xenos and heretics in equal measure. He comes off as abrasive, but that only adds to his character as a soldier eager for battle. The other characters, however, are not so noteworthy. The game tries to make us like them, but none of them really hit home or even provide much more than expositional dialogue. The over-arching narrative was also quite excellent, but it did feel like it went on too long and one story was abandoned for another halfway through. I understand the reason, but it really felt hollow.Now, my biggest complaint is with the difficulty, namely that there isn't any. My first playthrough was on Hard, and I performed quite admirably. The few times I did die was do to my stupid mistakes rather than the game being difficult. For me, this felt too easy. Fun, but without enough challenge. For experienced shooter players, Hard difficulty should be an easy ride. I happily recommend this game to veterans and newcomers alike. The gameplay is easy to get used to and fun to play and the story is interesting and keeps moving forward, if slowly at times. The multiplayer will also provide hours of enjoyment either before or after the campaign. Now go purge some xenos filth in the name of the Emperor!-------------------------------------------------------------------If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page [ http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

Локации вполне симпотичные хоть и не замысловатые.Сами уровни коридорные, есть тайники (которые не найдет разве что слепой)Приятная и простая система боя, приятные бои от которых иногда кипит кровь.НО! Штурмовик, опустошитель, Тактик.С 4 уровня дают выбрать отряд, а потом переодеть персонажа, изменить раскраску.Имеются комплекты брони, которые открываются с прохождением испытаний.Оружие которое открывается с новым уровнем.А в режиме экстерминатус, ооо, я промолчу)) сами испытаете этот адреналин))Говоря проще кампания простенькая но приятно греет душу, с учетом что это первая игра Warhammer от 3-го лица, можно поставить разработчикам твердую 4.Вытягивает эту игру невероятный мульитплеер где вы с братьями плечом к плечуопусташаете болтеры и окровавливаете цепные мечи.Советую к покупке и обязательной игре в мультиплеере.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												Do you like 40K?  Do you like crushing your opponents?  The single player for Space Marine is a fun, short romp through the battlefield of the 40K universe fighting against orc and chaos factions.  Fun, short, and sets up well for a sequal that is unlikely to come.Multiplayer is balanced well between Chaos Marines and Space Marines.  You cannot choose which faction to play, but Chaos Marines are just a reskin of the Space Marines; so no big loss.  Weapons and equipment are identical.  There are a ton of unlocks for three different classes:  Assault, Jetpack, and Heavy.  There are many loadouts and weapons for each class, but most are locked behind an experience wall.Balance between new players and veterans is achieved by coping the loadout of the person who killed you.  If you died to a hammer-weilding jetpack player; choose to respawn with their loadout.  Died to a sniper?  Respawn with their loadout.There are also cosmetic unlocks for different armor pieces (helmet, check, gloves, etc.) gained by playing that class or faction and earning specific achievements.Overall, Space Marine was fun in single and multiplayer.  I would recommend the game to anyone who enjoys third person shooters.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I really wish there was a middle ground recommendation button... But before you become too  judgemental about my negetive recommendation, I suggest you read it first. After my game lagged to  the point of crashing to desktop, I felt it was finally time I gave my word on this game. Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine is a fun little hack n' slash style action game game which throws you  into the grim-dark world of Warhammer where you play as Captain Titus of the Ultramarines. The story  is about as good as you can expect for a Warhammer game with pretty decent gameplay for it being a  transition from Relic's normally RTS style play to a third-person shooter. The campaign isn't terribly long but not terribly short either, with unlocks for the Captain as you  go. While it could have been done better, I suppose I can't complain about what we got. After your  7-8 (at most) hour story is over, you'll pretty much be done with the game which leaves you with  either completeing the game again on a higher difficulty if you haven't already. Or playing one of  the two multiplayer modes available to you. With a good to mediocre suggestion for the story thus  far, I'm sure you can see where this is going... The EXTERMINATUS mode allows you and three other space marines to band together and fight the green  skin menace in a co-op mode where you'll be flung into an arena where you must fight through five  ways and continue to the next zone, confronting more and more difficult enemies as you go. I highly  recommend playing this with friends, as the public matches are completely random with who you get  paired with, often matching you with new or inept players or outright ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. You'll usually know  what you're in for when people refuse to help you, shoot at you whenever there's a lull in the  fighting, or swipe ammo from out beneath your feet. Which leads me to the next portion. Multiplayer. Multiplayer can be fun. It can be frustrating. Too often it's frustrating. The  aforementioned people can be found most commonly here. I've yet to play a multiplayer game with a  'good' community, so I can't really hold this against Space Marine alone. Expect lots of weapon/perk  abuse with cookie-cutter loadouts and over-powered weapons with little hint to any actual game  balance to be found. Assault marines will darken the skies and tacticals will roll about the  landscapes, burning away everything with the one-hit wonder meltagun. Unless you plan on fighting  fire with fire, I suggest avoiding multiplayer. Feeling more reminiscent of Call of Duty, this  gamemode feels very 'tacked on at the last minute' than anything else in the game and offers little to  nothing new to the rest of the game apart from the ridiculous armory challenges which grant you perk  and armor unlocks for customizing your multiplayer character but unless you plan on grinding for a  very long time, they aren't something you can achieve in the short-term. Latency... I've played good games. I've played bad games. I've played games with amazing  connections, and I've played games with bad connections. And then... I've played Space Marine...  Never in my life have I played a game with such pathetic connection ability, with frequent lag and  constant 'host migrations' (Which if you plan on playing multiplayer, be prepared to view this  screen: 


Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 
A Screenshot of Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




 A. Lot.) the lack of  dedicated servers and actual lobby browsing leaving you to the mercy of the the dice roll on whether  or not you get a good server from the two or three that ever seem available grows very tiresome very  quickly. This is the number one thing that suggests to me that multiplayer was just an afterthought  once the game was made. Overall, I would indeed Recommend Space Marine to my friends who were interested or to any  Warhammer fan, if not for the story mode alone and possible co-op. Even non-fans looking for a fun  hack n' slash could possibly enjoy it. Though I leave with an actual POSITIVE recommendation, I  won't for the $30.00 dollar price tag this game sports. While fun, the shoddy multyplayer and lack  of being able to unlock things through exterminatus mode leaving you with a short, and underwhelming  campaign and ending leaves me wondering why this game is still so pricey. If you must buy it. Please  wait for a sale. $10-$15 dollars at most.TL;DR: 6/10 - There's better, cheaper games out there, should prolly go play them insted.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												When I first heard about this game, I wanted it. I was finally getting an action game from Warhammer instead of a typical RTS that usually happens with Warhammer games. I bounced up and down in joy, I flew across the room and hit my face against a door. In happiness.But anyways, I was a huge fan of the Warhammer games, and I wanted this game. I picked it up during the 2012 Christmas Sale, and haven't regretted it once. It's one of the few games where I go back and play it after finishing the game. I loved this game, so much. The gameplay involves you slicing orks, stomping a body and making it explode, removing limbs entirely, and just for lack of trying, you can blow their heads off. With a sword. It's one of the few games where it combines melee and ranged combat fairly seamlessly (There are a few holes here and there.), where it makes you feel like neither the melee or the ranged is overpowering the other. I played through the campaign, where I was expecting to just use melee, but that was not the case. I ended up using a variety of ranged weapons to get through the game.The healing system is rather interesting for this game. You have shields that regenerate out of combat (Like in Halo, for lack of a better comparison.) but your health doesn't regen out of combat. You have to do special kill moves to regenerate health. These can include shoving a chainsword through an Ork's body then moving it upwards and removing pretty much their entire spinal cord. They can also include exploding an ork's face. With your foot. There are some things that could be changed though to make it a more enjoyable experience. For example, you regain the health after the kill move, and you can be killed during the animation. There's no way to cancel the move, but for the most part this doesn't get in the way too much.This game really made me feel like I could take on an entire horde of Orks by myself and come out barely scratched. I also did that in the game. However, it has a checkpoint system that could be vastly improved. Or at least make cutscenese that you can skip. They stick a checkpoint before an unskippable cutscene then shove you into a fight you could die fairly quickly in, and you have to watch the cutscene again. That's one of the only design flaws.When I heard there weren't going to be anymore games after this, I was super bummed. I was hoping for Space Marine sequels even after THQ died. And then I read an article saying it had been canceled. Even if we didn't get any sequels, we got an amazing first game.In short, I loved it. This is one of my most favorite games of all time.

I have not played the story for this game in quite some time so I apologize in advance for any outdated/vague information about either it or the multiplayer.8.5/10Must-PurchaseIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!ProsGraphics


YouTube™ Video: Space Marine in a Nutshell | GREENSKIN BUTCHERY 

			Views: 253		

			SPOILERS! Critical Max does a summary of all the best, important and funny moments in his warhammer 40k Space marine playthrough.		

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=279190745This game looks stunning.Environments ranging from the doors of the Manufactorum straight to the Titan Invictus itself you will experience some of the most well crafted settings you could ask for in a WH40K game.GameplaySpace Marine is a 3rd person shooter/hack and slash. The melee is some of the most satisfying ive ever seen in a game and it works incredibly well with the provided weapons. Hacking through your enemies with a power axe or ripping them to literal shreds with a chainsword you will not be disappointed with the melee system in place here. There's alse an execution mechanic that you'll be constantly using to replenish your health in the longer battles.The game isn't just hack and slash though. You also have a fair variety of ranged weapons including but not limited to,the Stalker Pattern Boltgun,the Plasma Cannon,and the Storm Bolter. All of the ranged weapons have a satisfying kick that you would expect from a 40K game.Co-ophttp://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=305262741Space Marine features a co-op "Exterminatus" mode.The mode itself features either chaos marines or space marines(depending on if you're playing the DLC or not) holding out against waves of enemies on one of two different missions sets,Assault on Hab Center Andreas or Escape from Kalkys Facility.The mission sets include 4 different arenas with 5 waves in each.Multiple small objectives are inserted every little while as well. The objectives are mainly just hold a point for 2 minutes or something like that. There's also challenges that pop up during gameplay such as "kill 20 enemies in 10 seconds" or "kill 5 shoota boys in 15 seconds". ConsMultiplayerI personally didnt care too much for the multiplayer.It gets stale rather quick due to there being only around 5 maps and 2 objective types.The maps make up in quality what they lack in numbers but still its just not enough to keep the gameplay from becoming stale.StoryThis is more of a middle ground.The story wasn't bad but it sure was incredibly average and the story ended on a cliffhanger. That wouldn't be a problem if THQ hadn't gone bankrupt and the 2 other planned games in the series been cancelled. As it stands the story is just average. Average characters,average dialogue,and an infuriating ending.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

												----------SPOILERS KINDA----------Titus waited. The lights above him blinked and sparked out of the air. There were heretics in the base. He didn't see them, but had expected them now for years. His warnings to Graia PDF were not listenend to and now it was too late. Far too late for now, anyway. Titus was a Ultramarine for fourteen years. When he was young he watched the spaceships and he said to dad "I want to be in the Spehs Mahrens daddy." Dad said "No! You will BE KILL BY HERETICS" There was a time when he believed him. Then as he got oldered he stopped. But now in the Manufactorum Ajakis on Graia he knew there were heretics. "This is Thrax" the vox crackered. "You must fight the heretics!" So Titus gotted his botler and blew up the wall. "HE GOING TO KILL US" said the heretical scum "I will shoot at him" said the chaos mahren and he fired the plasma missiles. Titus botlereded at him and tried to blew him up. But then the ceiling fell and they were trapped and not able to kill. "No! I must kill the heretics" he shouted The radio said "No, Titus. You are the heretics" And then Titus was a ongoing investigation into heresy.

content:
Posted: February 24
												Space Marine is a fun hack and slash/ 3rd person perspective(the camera is right behind your' character) shooter game set in the Warhammer 40000 sci-fi universe. The game is simple, intense and sometimes frustrating, and makes you feel like a mighty astartes without going overboard. For example, when you walk or run, you can hear the booming footsteps of your character, but it doesn't sound cheesy or deafening, and the weapons seem godly powerful, but again not cartoonish. the music is instrumental, and pretty good, especially the more battle themes, but there is no sound galery, something that Is definately a good idea. The game doesn't have a save file system, but there are many checkpoints that you can start from to replay a certain part. A lot of running between fights, but there is plenty of detail to examine, some of it gruesome, but truly paints the grimdark setting well. In the beginnning, u can look up and see ships continuously getting shot down, gunfire and explosions in the distance. The "voice of Graia" the voice that anounces things like when you get a new weapon sounds callous and serious for example, lines like "Public disturbances will NOT be tolerated", help to paint the grim, brutal sci-fi setting. The final boss is a let down gameplay wise, but the story makes up for it. You feel like a hero, arriving in the imperial guard's darkest hour to save the day, and the cutscenes and dialogue portray this well. Titus is a true hero, doing what is right, even if he will be betrayed by comrades and punished by the inquisition for it.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
												Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a game that involves the Ultramarines, Orcs and Daemons. The overall of the storyline without spoilers is for Space Marine to take back the planet that the Orcs have conquered. This review is conducted in a manner where I have not played any Warhammer 40,000 games, and Space Marine is my first one, so I would not know if there is a continuing storyline. This review does not contain Multiplayer comments, only single player.Campaign: Space Marine includes a solid campaign. The campaign clocks in for me at 8.5 hours on "normal" difficulty. As stated without spoilers, the elements of the orcs, the ultra marines and eventually the daemons add a lot of twists to the storyline that make the game interesting. Throughout the campaign, you get that feeling that "oh wow, the game is about to finish and this is a great way to finish it", but it extends to another chapter, which is good, however whilst that happens a few times, it does drag. The ending was strong and gave me excitement for a new Warhammer, which most likely will not happen. The campaign involves sections that overwhelm the player (and you know, make the player respawn) and gives a strong surprise factor in certain scenarios. The boss battles are cool due to the gameplay (more on that in a little bit) that may make boss battles repeatitve, but a fun experience.The cutscenes in Space Marine are above-average to good. Some cutscenes intrigue me (especially the earlier campaign cutscenes due to seeing the environment in Space Marine), other cutscenes bore me as in my opinion, I got the same thought of "same old, same old". In saying that, some cutscenes are repeatitive and predictable. Another criticism of cutscenes is that it is disjointed. For example, before a cutscene, I am holding a Power Axe, the cutscene happens, I am holding a Chainsword. To add to this, the cutscene in a few particular scenes did not correlate with the gameplay at all. For example, in one cutscene I was beaten up (minor spoiler) and the cutscene finishes and it is like nothing happened, it was ridiculous and happened very occasionally in the campaign.Gameplay: The gameplay in Space Marine is very good. Using Melee is basically hack and slash, which is very fun. The gun gameplay is pretty cool with the sounds, look and gunfights in the game, which I enjoy. Again, the main criticism of this section is that whilst hack and slash is fun, it gets dull further into the game. The involvement of jet packs added another layer to gameplay in this game, and created refreshment in the campaign.In the final mission of the campaign, the gameplay involved was different than seen throughout the campaign, and I say it was actually very strong. Without spoilers, it involves flying and punching and I found this to be awesome, considering I don't play many games that have that sort of gameplay involved.Negative Comments: Space Marine contains quite a few bugs, some very visible, some not visible at all to some, but visible to I. The other negative comments have been explained above with the gameplay, cutscenes, and campaign.  Whilst the pros outweigh the cons in Space Marine, the cons impact the game more than expected.Overall: It is a very solid game, filled with bugs galore, but a fun experience. For I that was introduced to Warhammer 40,000 through Space Marine, I enjoyed a refresh from the typical FPS campaigns, but it is a genre I am not still not eager to play. My friend purchased a Humble Bundle which included Warhammer series, and for Steam's price of $39.99, I personally would not recommend it. If I had to purchase this game again after playing it, I would not purchase it for higher than $29.99. I feel this is a fair price point because I have not checked out MP, and considering this game is four years old, no one most likely plays MP. I don't know about the modes so I cannot comment extensively, however older games I tend to purchase knowing I can only play the campaign, and don't have an overly interest in MP. If you play through the campaign on all difficulties, the player can probably get about 30+ hours out of this game. 7/10.UPDATE #1: I have just found out that there is two co-op modes in Multiplayer (one was patched in, other has to be purchased for $12.99) meaning with four people, you can probably get an extra few hours out of the game.Also to mention, all DLC is multiplayer-based according to a forum post.----Thanks for reading my review! If you like my reviews and care to read more, feel free to join Antwog's Analysis (Reviews). http://steamcommunity.com/groups/AntwogReviewsIf you have questions comment below or post in Antwog's Analysis (Reviews) general discussion page. If you liked it, give it a rating.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												I am going to say first that looking for all the aspects it's a good game, but i do not recommend buying for the price at this tiime. The campaign is pretty good, you feel like a space marine. Good looking enviroments, hordes of enemies, a decent variety of weapons. Captain Titus doesn't know fear or the meaning of impossible or defeat. He is unstoppable. The history is linear, you don't have any choices at the entire game.  Even with this, it's a good campaign. Now, let's talk about the Multiplayer. There is all the weapons. 3 classes of spaces marines, achiviements that let you unlock porwefull upgrades to weapons and armors to customize the look of your space marine. Ok, that's the good part.The bad part is a few maps and, the most important, there is no dedicated server.  The multiplayer uses P2P,  for me it's impossible to play.  I lost the count of how many times i got killed behind a wall, or a grende exploded while i was flying. I stopped playing Multiplayer.So, summarizing, buy for the right price, the campaign is good and the multiplayer sucks.I hope that  I could help.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												What happens when you combine a surprisingly good interpretation of a(most dull voted) marine chapter, combine it with a pretty fore-seeable plot from the get-go & action that is second to none?Nothing stale, I assure you. - Where this game excels is its rock-solid gameplay, "beginner to 40k" friendly story writing, with a killer ending that makes you crave for more. This game is a hidden gem in the "3 person view" games.I hated Gears of War/other 3PV games, this one though... is a whole different story. Every shot you fire from a pistol or a "boltgun" you can feel as it connects with your enemy. Heads pop and blood flies wherever you strike at.- I only wish Relic would have had the opportunity to continue this, as the ending of the game really sticks with you, on an emotional level.Do not play on the easy mode though, stick with the Normal(its not harder, its more enjoyable).

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a third-person shooter set in the universe of Warhammer 40,000 that follows one captain of the Ultramarines, Titus, on his mission on the Forge World Graia, which is under heavy attack by a Ork horde seeking to posses the powerful weapons built in the planet's factories. Later in the game, Titus and his two accompanying Ultramarines, Sidonus and Leandros, must also face the threat of a Chaos Warband lead by a dangerous Chaos sorcerer named Nemeroth.The main beef of Space Marine's gameplay is using the weapons you are given tocut through the hordes of enemies preventing you from advancing and then proceed in the levels. You are given both long ranged weapons (like pistols or sniper rifles) and close quarters tools (starting from a chainsaw and arriving at a huge electrified mallet): you must learn to switch between the two constantly, given you'll face various kinds of enemies (some of them dangerous on the long distances while others extremely weak if chopped down in close combat). Each weapon has different versions that are unlocked advancing in the game, each with its pros and cons. On top of his health pool, Titus can take advantage of a recharging shield that can protect him against some of the enemy fire and a super mode of some sort: the mode is charged by dishing out damage and, whenever unleashed, allows you to recover health over time and aim at enemies in slow-motion. Finishing enemies when they are weak also allows you to boost your health.The main campaign is extremely faithful to the Warhammer 40,000 universe, both in design of the environments and characters and the references made to the general lore of the series. It lasts for aboutsix or eight hours or so and, aside from fighting your way through Graia, you can find hidden servo-skulls bearing audio recordings that further expand the game's story. There are three different difficulties (easy, normal and hard), but I'd say that even the normal mode manages to be challenging enough.Warhammer 40,00: Space Marine also spots a rather interesting multiplayer mode. You can either play as a Space Marine or a Chaos Marine, and the game offers a customization menu that allows you to deeply personalize your marine (armor pieces, colours, insigna, ...). The multiplayer mode offers several game modes, the same you could expect into a big retail multiplayer shooter: capture the flag, capture the control point, ... The mode also features co-op missions. The player actually makes progress in multiplayer thanks to a level system, unlocking new armor pieces and/or weapons and perks as he/she gains more experience. As I'm writing this review and four years after the game's release, Space Marine's multiplayer is still really populated.Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine, along with the Dawn of War series, is a great example about how a complex series like Warhammer 40,000 can be boiled down in a rather charming game capable of offering a great time both to the fans of the series and newcommers just wanting to enjoy some good third-person shooting action

Posted: April 4
												If there is one thing Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine succeeds at, it's making you feel like a powerfull ultramarine!The whole weaponry, melee weapons and jetpack combo really help empowering the player and feeling like a war machine.The world is beautifull, the scenery and enviroment really impressive and grandiose.It is a shame that such effort and details were not put into the characters and story.The people you encounter are all bland, with monotone voices and no expressions.The story is also very predicable, I mean laughably predictable.Hopefully, some really epic moments here and there help making the game interesting.What is hard forgive, is a last boss, that simply is quick time action.let that sink in for a moment!I do recommend this game for anyone who like a very simple hack and slash type game and are fan of the warhammer 40k world.If you do not intend to play but wish to see only the best, funniest and important story moment of the whole game, all edited with added special effect and commentaries, make sur to take a look at this video I made.Warning: SPOILERS!

content:
Posted: March 23
												This game came out a long time ago, but it is still a visceral, thematic, Bleak, Gothic exploration of the Future of Mankind. One of the few games that made me feel I was actually a powerful character in a setting that could dispose of smaller foes with ease, while still keeping the larger threats imposing and honestly dangerous. Players of moderate skill should expect to die once or twice on the normal mode, but even veterans may struggle with the harder modes. It is not without it's flaws, but none of them managed to subtract from my enjoyment of playing the game for long.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
Review For Warhammer 40,000: Space MarineReview by: DEHUPros :- Good graphics- Great Story- Good voice actors- Fantastic controlsCons :- The game a bit too short.Review :Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a Third Person Shooter with great story and great gameplay.The game follows a Command Squad of three of the Ultramarines, 2nd Company Commander and playable character Captain Titus, his immediate subordinate Veteran Sergeant Sidonus, and a relatively inexperienced and by-the-book Tactical Marine named Leandros.Initially upon arrival the squad provide assistance to the outnumbered and overrun Imperial Guard regiments fighting on the planet's surface, which after the loss in battle of all higher-ranking officers are now being led by the sole surviving junior officer, Second Lieutenant MiraThe Space Marines then move on to continue with their own mission and, amidst securing the Titan Invictus, a weapon that can destory the orcs. The titan need a power source that can found in a reactor. Titus retrieves it and activates the Psychic Scourge, but the Orcs doesn't die, but a Warp Gate to the world of Chaos and unleaches a horde of demons.Later the Chaos Lord Nemeroth emerges from the portal. Using his Warp powers, he subdues the Space Marine squad as Inquisitor Drogan arrives via lift and approaches Nemeroth, revealing his allegiance to the Chaos Lord.The Scourge opened a growing Warp portal around the Orbital Spire, allowing Chaos forces to pour in; seeing this, Titus forms a plan to destroy the portal and the Spire by using one of the Titans they had secured earlier. The Titan Invictus is brought to full activation by the Power Source, and destroys the Spire. However, Sergeant Sidonus is killed by Lord Nemeroth, and the Power Source is stolen and taken to the floating remains of the Spire.The reinforcement fleet now having finally arrived, including a company of Blood Ravens Space Marines as well as the rest of Titus's company and large numbers of Imperial Guard, Titus leads them in an attack through the remaining Chaos forces to stop Lord Nemeroth from performing a ritual to ascend to the status of a Daemon Prince using the power of the deviceNemeroth has partially ascended to Daemonhood when Titus finally faces him again; both are knocked off the spire in the struggle, and the Captain defeats him in single combat while falling towards the ground. He then breaks the experimental device in half with his hands. Titus survives the exposure to the raw Warp energy again, and is rescued by a Thunderhawk dropship before he can impact the ground.The end scene of the game involves a new Imperial Inquisitor by the name of Thrax, accompanied by Leandros and escorted by several Black Templar Space Marines, who places Titus under arrest. Leandros believes that his Captain has been corrupted by Chaos, based on his resistance to warp forces.Additional Infomation :Developer: Relic EntertainmentPublisher: THQ (former), Sega (current)Genre: TPS, Released on Playstation 3: September 6, 2011 Released on Xbox 360: September 6, 2011Released on Steam: 9. sep 2011Follow my Curator page :http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6858371/This review is written for :The Panda's Corner

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine, while quite underrated and unplayed, is quite a fantastic game. It's blend of genres make it quite unigue when it comes traditional Third Person Shooters ( I know there are other melee based TPS games like Bayonetta ). Though it is not without it's flaws, the variety of game modes means there is something for everyone. Want a great story? Play campaign, want some good team based action? Exterminatus is for you ( PLaying with randoms can leave you with  afeeling of RAGE!!! sometimes ). And of course there is the multiplayer, which in my opinion isn't the strongest part of the game.The setting and sound design for some people might be considered a bit dull but for any 40K fan it could be considered some of, if not the best in any 40K game to date. The color scheme is a lot of browns and greys but that fights in nicly with the grimdark setting. We also finally have decent sounding bolters for once, they actually sound like powerful weapons they are supposed to be.There are, as I said, a few things wrong with it. For traditional Codex fans there will be some small problems such as the obscene amount of damage you can take from even the weakest Orks and the use of Lascannons in an anti-infatry role. Such things are quite minor and shouldn't stop you from ejoying the game. Other problems can just be the extreme level of difficulty in both the campaign and Exterminatus. enemies can take quite a few shots before they go down and in return, as  i said before, they can take you done rather quickly if you don't play smart. In contrast to other TPS games, Space Marine has no cover system. As such you must use your mobility to your advantage, with the use of combat rolls, sprint and later on (in limited fashion) the jump pack.In Exterminatus and Multiplayer, the game is actually a class based game, meaning that you can choose one of three classes to play. In these modes you play as either Space Marines, fighting for the Imperium. And the Chaos Space Marines, fighting for the glory of the dark gods. Both sides are exactly the same in terms of classes and abilites. The three calsses are: The Assault Marine/Raptor, Devastator Marine/Havoc and the Tactical Marine/Chaos Space Marine. Each class has different parks, abilities and weapons. The Assault Marine/Raptor is the master of close combat, is armed with a close combat weapon and a pistol and has a  jump pack. The Devastator/Havoc is a beast at long range, armed with the heaviest armor and heaviest weapons, he can however be beaten quite quickly in close combat without support. And the Tactical Marine/Chaos Space Marine is a very flexible all rounder, with neither the close ranged power of the Assault Marine/Raptor, or the longe range fire power of the Devastator Marine/Havoc. He does however have a lot of options and weapons that neither of the other classes has access to.There are also an extreme amount of cosmetic customization options. you can have up to five saved custom marine appearences for both the Space Marines and the Chaos Space Marines. There are also a lot of different parts of your armor that can be customized from the helmet and chest plate, to individual legs, arms and pauldrons. Relic also released some DLC  specific sets of armor including: Blood Angel, Salamander, Legion of the Damned, etc for the loyalists. For the traitors there are sets like: Death Guard, Iron Warriors and Emperor's Children. these were not only colour schemes but had custom bits of armor like the Legion of the Damned skull helmet and the salamander shect plate with Drake hide attached. These were unfortunately unchangeable but the community did figure out a workaround.There are a few over sights and missed opportunities, such a s a lack of vehicular combat. There are a  few turret sections in the campaign and there was a DLC released that let you play in a dreadnaught but that is largely considered unbalanced and is rarely played now. Also the absence of dedicated servers means that multiplayer is often plagued with constant latency issues. And the combat can be consdiered repetative.tl;dr+ fantastic campaign+ setting and sound design+ varied roles in multiplayer and Exterminatus+ customization options- repetitive gameplay- general difficulty- lagg issues- lack of players for multiplayer modesIn summary: Just play it. Rent it, buy it, borrow from a friend. Just try it for yourself, it's still a fun game despite it's flaws.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2014
												A beautiful game that met it's end at a flurry of unfortunate circumstances - circumstances both unforseeable and otherwise. It's an audacious game, bringing to the table strikingly personal and beautiful graphics, a wildly bloody slash-and-bolter combat system, and the grinding, metal bang and fleshy, ripping spletch that I've come to synonymously expect from Warhammer. The story may be dry, the mulitplayer a sad husk with no dedicated servers, and the smell of lost opportunity a bit pungent on the coarsing winds of ash and char; but it's still a must for any 40K fan. Recommended.

												This is simply one of the most fun action titles I've ever played. It has really great gameplay that made me feel like a tanky space marine. The class-based multiplayer is pretty well-balanced, and the horde mode is challenging, and great for playing with friends.Pros:Really cool weapons.Plays well with a gamepad or kb/m.Really smooth gameplay jumping between ranged and melee.Pretty good plot that fits well in WH40K universe.Good flavor in fighting orks vs. chaos - orks have overwhelming numbers, chaos have beefy units to rival your own strength.Jump pack scenes work well.Cons:Lack of split-screen local co-opIt's a console port, and this shows up in the menu design, graphics options, and obnoxious checkpoint save system.No moddabilityAt this point they should remove the grind for unlocking stuff in MP mode, at least if you just want to go play co-op.The entire game, including a really tough mid-game boss, has consistent mechanics and skill use, then the final boss is just a game of simon says. content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
												This is the first review I have ever written, but this game needed it.  I haven't played a 3D shooter in 16 years because the genre became so stale.  But, I love the 40k universe so I thought I would try this title.  normally I play MOBAs and RPGs.  TLDR - you will have jaw dropping moments throughout the course of this game.  Space Marine has - 1. epic space marine combat you might envision from the books.  full on, hard core, kick butt action.  2. Titans.  yes.  there is a titan in the game and I wont spoil anything.  it was cool.  I want more titan action though if they have ever make space marine 2.3.  Holy crap... you are a gunner on a storm bird in one mission, it was epic.4. good warhammer 40k story line.  inquisition, imperial army, responding to a distress call from a hive world invaded by orcs.  Things get dark and the plot thickens.5. totally awesome, mind blowingly huge visuals you probably envision in the 40k universe.  the game puts you right into them.  Huge manufactorem, drop pods screaming out of the sky, chain swords, bolters, las rifles, melta guns6. I want more space marine games.  too bad the maker went bankrupt.  and too bad I just found this game now.  cons:Would like better script and voice acting in the future.  Main characters were ok.  leandros... not good.  recommendations if the game makers ever read this review.  why not borrow a script author from the horus heresy, like dan abnett?  I think there are people dying for good story content.  same reason game of thrones TV show is successful.  it is rich in content and story with a great cast.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												You can play as the freaking Adeptus Astartes, what is not to love? Though, seriously, I am friggin' sick of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Ultramarines...Beyond that, the story is forgettable and the characters flat. Single Player doesn't really have much to offer aside from the beauty of WH40k rendered with loving detail. The grandness of the universe is well represented; everything is huge, and even the towering Astartes feel small.The multiplayer, both cooperative and adversarial, is much more interesting than the SP.Exterminatus, though very flawed, is a fun take on Wave Survival/"Horde Mode". With more polish and care, it coud have stolen the show, but as is, it remains obviously what it is: a tacked on extra.Versus, on the other hand, it extremely fun. Yes, Peer 2 Peer across oceans is lagtastic. Yes, it could use some balance. Yes, the maps are stale after 2 years. But it's still the most fun I have in gaming, and it's the only game that lets me play as the Adeptus Astartes. I can't help but love it.In all, the game is a wonderful first step for Relic into the Third Person Shooter genre, and is amazing for the studio's first ever action game, but whether or not they will continue this trend under SEGA remains to be seen...It should be noted that the animation quality in Space Marine is top notch, AAA, 5 star, all that and bag of chips. As a person who appreciates aesthetics in motion (i.e. good animations), I find it an absolute joy to watch.
