content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Chainswords, Space British, and Orks with a K. Those are a few things to expect when playing 40k Space Marine. You play as Titus captain of the Ultramarines, and wow your whole team just look so badass. You have giant shoulder pads with skulls on them, you rip guys apart to get health back, you don't use cover because ♥♥♥♥ that and your dude just looks even cooler by the end of the game. The game starts off with you flying over this planet getting ready to land. When you spot Ork airships flying by. Then Captain Titus (you) makes the call and says were jumping, so that we can take out those airships. You do and you blow them up and of course you get separated form your squad. You then go out to find them and last survivors. The story defiantly takes a turn that I didn't really see coming, and it was a good one it changes up the story and the gameplay. For the most part of the game it just has you ripping through guy and tearing them apart weather it be with your Chainsword or with your guns, and it feels like they have mastered ripping guys apart because they just blow up in to the mist of red when you shoot them our when you gut them in half with your sword.  Just going into a group of 100 Orks and just coming out the other end covered in blood feels amazing, looks so cool,and is so much fun.    The story mode will take you about 8 to 10 hours to beat if you play it on normal. It feeds you new stuff pretty frequently so it feels a little different now that you have this new gun or this new melee weapon, it never gets dull I'll just say that.Now on to the multiplayer, which has variety of different modes 2 competitive, deathmatch and a point capture mode, then it also has a horde mode with waves of enemies and different objectives. It is class based you have a melee, a stationary gunner guy, and just you all around gun guy. It plays pretty well and has the call of duty carrot on a stick aspect of unlocking stuff as you progress but not only do you unlock weapons and perks but you also unlock a bunch of cosmetic items through achievements and leveling up, which personally I spent a lot of time just dressing up both my dudes. One of the main issues I had with it was that in the beginning it felt like I was really at a disadvantage, because it was just getting killed instantly in some cases. That might turn some players off but stick with it you unlock a lot of cool stuff from new stuff like a jetpack to all the guns you had access to in the campaign.The game is a great package with a satisfying campaign, some great multiplayer fun. It's centrally not perfect though, there's not that many different weapons, it can get dull and feel like your just doing the same thing over and over again, but those points are few and far between.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I'm going to start this review with how impressed I am at this game's optimization. I have a crappy PC with a dual core processor, and this game is frequently hitting 60 fps with some infrequent stuttering here and there when the particle effects and environments get a little thick. Even at the lowest graphical settings, this game still looks good, so props to Relic on making this run like a dream on PC.Now, to the review proper. A lot of 3rd person shooters focus far too much on stale cover-based shooting, ever since Gears of War did it relatively okay. Space Marine says to hell with cover and lets you tromp around and stomp the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of xenos and heretics while using movement to keep yourself alive.It uses a system where you have regenerating shields, but your actual health has to be recovered by getting into the thick of things and execute enemies when they're stunned. You need to make intelligent use of your dodges and know when to stun certain enemies and keep them out of combat while you work on the other guys in melee. While the combos themselves aren't particularly complex or challenging, they provide a surprising depth in your approach to close combat.As for the shooting, Space Marine gets it right. If you're going to commit yourself to mid or long-range combat, you need to be constantly mindful of what pillars or walls you can use to peek around and use to run through, breaking up the enemy's fire. You can't just sit in once place forever, since the AI will know what you're trying to pull, and will make use of grenades to get you in their line of fire. They will also attempt to flank you and surround you all of the time.This, combined with the melee combat system, makes for an actually challenging game that has you constantly scanning your surroundings and flushing out your enemies. There's hardly ever a dull moment, and each encounter tests you on what you've been learning throughout the game. While newbies are going to be frantically hunting for a spot to rest and be on edge in every battle, more experienced players can make it look hilariously easy.Sound DesignThe bolters are so damn punchy in this game. Everything is punchy. Even the steps taken by you and your fellow space marines sound massive and thud like you'd expect. Every aspect of this game sounds authentic, and never leaves you dissatisfied. This is also part of what keeps the shooting aspect of the game so fun, as the bolter makes thunderous noise and your enemies blow apart in juicy blood splatters.When it comes to the narrative, it is standard 40k fare, but the characters themselves are, for me, the most memorable thing in the story. Mark Strong does a great job voicing Captain Titus, and the captain himself is a pretty badass dude. The Ultramarines are often mocked as ponces and an obnoxious, uptight chapter. While this does hold true in many cases, Titus shows the best attributes of the chapter, and embodies the ideals of his primarch. Hell, I'd say the guy is the spitting image of Guilliman.Sidonus is a cool guy, Leandros is a whipped little ♥♥♥♥♥, the Blood Ravens make an appearance along with the Black Templars, the IG is as manly as ever, and the the chaos lord is actually kind of cool; while he doesn't match up to the likes of Eliphas, he's still leagues better than other chaos lords we've seen in the past. The ork warboss, Grimskull, is probably one of my favorite orks ever, right behind Gorgutz 'Ead 'Unter.Overall, I'd say that this is a game that certainly does 40k justice, and is a great starting point for anyone who wants to get more into the lore side of the setting. As a game, it's pretty damn good, and keeps me coming back constantly with its campaign and multiplayer. I would love to see Relic revisit Space Marine sometime in the near future, and finish it off proper, since the cliffhanger at the end is downright criminal. So, yes, I do recommend Space Marine.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2, 2013
												So, I have this to ask of you. Why haven't you gotten this? Have you at least tried out the demo? No? *Smacks you upside the head* Go try it! It's a gore filled, bloody as Hell (No, wait, it's Orks. But oh, how they bleed.), and it's a VERY simple control system that'll have you taking on Hordes of Orks in maybe a minute after the start.And speaking from my experience on the 360 version, the Online is INCREDIBLY fun (Though I was limited due to buying the game used), and, believe it or not, I could find people. Yes. Actual people. In ALL the game modes I had. Exterminatus, Versus, the likes. Even though I was level 5 most of the time, I was doing a large amount of work for my team, keeping them well placed. I can only wonder what I would've been like at a higher level, with more weapons... <3And then I get to the campaign. It's a camping trip gone astra- And I'm going to stop there. No, it's a typical Warhammer 40,000 story. Orks, suddenly, *Censored*. Whoah. Since I'm still new to the series, it caught me off guard, but, hey. It's still well done. The final fight is a gory mess of blood and fun and gore. But that final game movie, it's a painful one. The people in Warhammer 40,000, especially Space Marines, are♥♥♥♥♥holes. No bars hold,♥♥♥♥♥holes. GLORIFIED♥♥♥♥♥holes, them Space Marines are. But somehow, Relic has, once again, created a sort of relate-able glorified♥♥♥♥♥hole who has a heart of light (Or so we may think, depending on how you take the game.), and is a good character for the 40,000 universe. Upon arriving to the first Guardsmen outpost, he tells the lead Guardsman there that they saved themselves, and told him to rise. Captain Titus seems to treat Guardsmen as a form of little brother. It's very amusing to me.And oh my Emperor, the music. The music is very much, to me, the highlight of Space Marine. It's an absolute blast to listen to, and every second of it sends chills down my spine. It's like listening to Dawn of War II's "The Green Horde Rises" in 19 songs, ESPECIALLY "A Hero's Legacy". Holy crap (That plays during the end video, before the credits).Over all? I'd recommend getting it while on sale, but get it. It may not be your cup of tea, but try the Demo out. The two levels included (Well, level and a half because of the SHEER size of the Jump pack mission in game) are essentially copied and pasted out of the game itself. They give you a basic understanding of how the game works, and plenty of ways to test your skill.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												Space Marine's singleplayer campaign is a thoroughly generic third-person action game, but multiplayer is where this game really comes through. There's the standard slew of competitive modes (plus Dreadnought, which nobody ever plays) and co-op against waves of Orks in the exceptionally fun Exterminatus mode. The controls are cumbersome and take a bit of getting used to, and you'll need to put in the time to level up before you'll be competitive in multiplayer, which can be an annoyance to newcomers short on patience. However, if you like third-person shooters and are willing to put in some substantial time, Space Marine can be a very fun and rewarding multiplayer game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												This game is another solid hit from Relic. They have mostly captured what I conceive a Space Marine to be, which is a ♥♥♥♥ing mega tank that can run around exploding everything with its hands, feet, guns, knives, swords, chainswords, powerswords, poweraxes, grenades, and mouth and a variety of body parts. Space Marines will mother♥♥♥♥ing KILL you and then eat your face to ascertain how much badonk your mom's butt has, using their flesh memory powers. The single player campaign has you as an Ultramarine who doesn't really strike me as a standard ultramarine, because he's kind of Khorny and that's just weird. However, you bulldoze your way through hordes of Orcs and later Daemons to the end, which is a visceral experience. The feedback is pretty good as you can tell how powerful this guy is. The story is a tried and true Good Guys get duped but overcome everything in the end type thing. THe multiplayer is another animal entirely, you play as either a Space Marine or Chaos Space Marine in several modes which are all fun. The best part is unlocking new armor pieces to customize your Space Explosion Dude so he can look like whatever mary-sue chapter you want. The worst part is the matchmaking which isn't region locked, so you may very well end up getting teamed up with some dude from Tokyo who is hosting the match and you get terrible lag. Also some of the weapon augments give a slightly unfair advantage and they all take some sort of skill in order to unlock. My biggest complaint is that hardly anyone is playing anymore and that SUCKS A♥♥♥♥♥♥ Please play this game, I'd like to try out the DLC I purchased that I can't play since no one that plays has it or just doesn't start matches in it. You can be a ♥♥♥♥ing DREADNOUGHT that crushes and splatters dudes. Come in a be a SPAES MAHRENFinal score 15 billion out of 10*2

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												I really like this game, but then, I am a 40K fanboy. The game is a linear, point to point slaughter fest. A lot of the negative reviews mention it is repetitive it is. Then again so is every shooter in recent years. What the game does have is faithful to the lore art and information, great sound effects and a combat system that seamlessly switches between ranged combat and melee. The combat is visceral and very satisfying.  Despite being nearly four years old the engine has aged well.It is, I find amusing, that some reviews talk about the story being basic when the vast majority of games available are even worse and titles with grander production values fair worse. This game isn't Deus Ex and nor is it Wolfenstein Old Blood, i,e the only two shooters I can remember that have a good campaign.  It is satisfying, fit for purpose and gives you an excuse to kill lots of things. There are a number of enemy unit types in the game and most of the core Ork units are there, boyz, nobz, weirdboyz, gretchin, ard boyz and the warboss. Chaos units are fairly limited to psyers, cultist, tactical and devestator marines, champions and Khorne bloodletters. The campaign is the usual 7-8 hours odd depending on how much time you spend looking for things and difficulty you play on. This is pretty much standard to most Single Player games. The game is very well presented and polished. Negative reviews mention a number of issues, AI, geometry and scripting errors and I've yet to come across any issues, nada not one. One down side is the multiplayer which can be difficult to find games on, although it does have a large amount of customisation it could do with more variety. Even the horde mode is quite limited and perhaps should have went down the Dawn of War 2 route and allowed players to also play as Orks and Imperial Guard. I've gifted copies to friends and family to try and drag them into the game. Space Marine is game I will play again and again, it is the perfect game to just to unwind with, slaughter a few Orks and move on.

												This review is single-player-centric.The feeling of power from playing this game is hugely satifying. The weapons are all exactly as you want them to be, and balanced to boot. The combat mechanics encourage fighting you way out of situations rather than hiding, and are perfect for maintaining flow. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I'm going to start this review with how impressed I am at this game's optimization. I have a crappy PC with a dual core processor, and this game is frequently hitting 60 fps with some infrequent stuttering here and there when the particle effects and environments get a little thick. Even at the lowest graphical settings, this game still looks good, so props to Relic on making this run like a dream on PC.Now, to the review proper. A lot of 3rd person shooters focus far too much on stale cover-based shooting, ever since Gears of War did it relatively okay. Space Marine says to hell with cover and lets you tromp around and stomp the living♥♥♥♥♥♥out of xenos and heretics while using movement to keep yourself alive.It uses a system where you have regenerating shields, but your actual health has to be recovered by getting into the thick of things and execute enemies when they're stunned. You need to make intelligent use of your dodges and know when to stun certain enemies and keep them out of combat while you work on the other guys in melee. While the combos themselves aren't particularly complex or challenging, they provide a surprising depth in your approach to close combat.As for the shooting, Space Marine gets it right. If you're going to commit yourself to mid or long-range combat, you need to be constantly mindful of what pillars or walls you can use to peek around and use to run through, breaking up the enemy's fire. You can't just sit in once place forever, since the AI will know what you're trying to pull, and will make use of grenades to get you in their line of fire. They will also attempt to flank you and surround you all of the time.This, combined with the melee combat system, makes for an actually challenging game that has you constantly scanning your surroundings and flushing out your enemies. There's hardly ever a dull moment, and each encounter tests you on what you've been learning throughout the game. While newbies are going to be frantically hunting for a spot to rest and be on edge in every battle, more experienced players can make it look hilariously easy.Sound DesignThe bolters are so damn punchy in this game. Everything is punchy. Even the steps taken by you and your fellow space marines sound massive and thud like you'd expect. Every aspect of this game sounds authentic, and never leaves you dissatisfied. This is also part of what keeps the shooting aspect of the game so fun, as the bolter makes thunderous noise and your enemies blow apart in juicy blood splatters.When it comes to the narrative, it is standard 40k fare, but the characters themselves are, for me, the most memorable thing in the story. Mark Strong does a great job voicing Captain Titus, and the captain himself is a pretty badass dude. The Ultramarines are often mocked as ponces and an obnoxious, uptight chapter. While this does hold true in many cases, Titus shows the best attributes of the chapter, and embodies the ideals of his primarch. Hell, I'd say the guy is the spitting image of Guilliman.Sidonus is a cool guy, Leandros is a whipped little ♥♥♥♥♥, the Blood Ravens make an appearance along with the Black Templars, the IG is as manly as ever, and the the chaos lord is actually kind of cool; while he doesn't match up to the likes of Eliphas, he's still leagues better than other chaos lords we've seen in the past. The ork warboss, Grimskull, is probably one of my favorite orks ever, right behind Gorgutz 'Ead 'Unter.Overall, I'd say that this is a game that certainly does 40k justice, and is a great starting point for anyone who wants to get more into the lore side of the setting. As a game, it's pretty damn good, and keeps me coming back constantly with its campaign and multiplayer. I would love to see Relic revisit Space Marine sometime in the near future, and finish it off proper, since the cliffhanger at the end is downright criminal. So, yes, I do recommend Space Marine.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2013
												Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine is one of those games that is absolutely perfect for unwinding after a hard day's work.  Co-worker's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off? Grab this massive chainsaw-sword and go chop up some Greenskins.Space Marine isn't a narrative masterpiece in the sense it has a rich story. While a lot of the storytelling is done through short bouts of exposition and sometimes in the middle of - you guessed it - tearing Orks to ribbons, Space Marine is none the less considered by me to be a stealth parody of not only the modern shooter franchise - what with its developers offing cover-based combat in the favour of charging headfirst into the enemy - but also a stealth parody of the playable Chapter in question - the ubiquitous Ultramarines Chapter, which has had a rather lengthy history of discontent by Space Marine players in Warhammer 40k.All in all, the Multiplayer and the Campaign aren't substantial, but they're definitely enough to satisfy you. 8/10, remember to play in short bouts, not every day, to keep the appeal running.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2012
												Fans of Warhammer 40k will absolutely not be disappointed, as this game has hours of Ork and Chaos slaughtering fun, with a careful attention paid to the game's lore (though nitpickers will note that the Ultramarine companies are an alternate version). Expect to see a number of beloved units and weapons from the Ultramarines, Chaos, Orks, and Imperial Guard. But you don't have to just be a Warhammer fan to appreciate it. Beautiful visuals, really visceral combat, and an exciting (and long) single player campaign make this game certainly one of the more fun third person shooters to come out. Similar to Gears of  War in playstyle, but definitely not a "cover shooter" -- cover is for cowards!

												Alright so first off some context. Roughly one and half years ago my friend introduced me to warhammer. He told me about the "Adeptus Astartes" and the "Imperium of Man" and all that good stuff. I quickly fell in love with the universe. Definatly reccommended for any 40k fan. Get some friends together and purge some xenos in the name of the emperor. Amazing customization, many different armor sets and you can paint yourself up as any chapter you want. ThunderHammmers.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2012
												Pros:Visceral combat system with two popular PvP modes (capture point, team deathmatch) emphasizing teamplay. A blast to play with friends, if a bit anemic to play alone. Still active enough to have games running most of the time. Armor customization is detailed, even if the colors do not provide the large RGB spectrum like Dawn of War. But the amount of armor pieces, patterns and color combinations means that you will be hard pressed to create the same thing as another player unless you do it on purpose. Though not free of flaws, many of the early ones have long since been ironed out.Cons:A play-once campaign, with no supporting DLC to keep you going back, trains new players the wrong way for PvP. Anemic DLC adds very little to the game other than a small spattering of maps, unplayed modes, and an expensive lineup of unique armor that cannot be completely picked apart for custom outfits. P2P connectivity provides the constant, irritating spectre of lag and host switching. The graphics were already pushing middle-aged when it came out, but the animation and design made up for that. Nowadays, you'll either not mind or it'll drive you bonkers.The game's been out long enough that it has some fairly entrenched players that can be an overwhelming challenge to newcomers. And with obsessive veterans comes the abusive verbal treatment seen in many communities that have been destroyed by it.Other thoughts:People disagree on the weapon balance. I've used them all, and I think each one is fine, with distinct strengths and weaknesses. The exception being the axe, which is neither as fast as the sword nor as strong as the hammer, striking a balanced surpassed in utility by both alternatives.The community itself is hit-and-miss. While most of the players are amiable, there are a few grudge-bearing sour grape obsessives who will spend hours striving to verbally troll you out of an enjoyable evening. Like in most other online games. But since there isn't really any community control, simply block or don't respond.The game does have cheaters, but they are very rarely encountered. If it isn't something lag-borne like being shot through a wall, and is instead obvious like plasma cannon teleporting to high ledges to release charged shots, then teleporting back to safety, then you'll know for sure.And since this game now has defunct support, there is very little chance we'll see any more content for it, or even a sequel.My opinion's jumped around on this thing like a flea on hot coals. My initial overall landed on around six, but then it grew on me until I bumped it to seven, then finally eight at the peak of my interest. But as long as I keep playing, it's subject to change. Weighing the pros and cons together:7/10I've played for 1,200 hours. Of course I recommend it, with the understanding that the cons are taken into consideration before purchasing.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												A solid interpretation of what its like to be a space marine. Murder your way through hordes of orcs with both ranged and melee weapons as you try to stop an invasion. The orcs are trying to capture one of the Imperiums manufacturing worlds where the mighty battle titans are created and only Captain Titus and his Ultramarines can stem the tide until help arrives. The action is gory and brutal and with solid mouse and keyboard controls its easy to switch between aiming with your arsenal of ranged weapons and wading into the fray with your chainsword. The story is actually quite good all up and I got a kick out of playing through it. Its a good action game but if you are a fan of the 40K universe and its lore, its very good.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2011
												It's a mix between Gears of War and Devil May Cry.  It looks and feels like Gears of War, but then feels like Devil May Cry as enemies barge in screaming at you by the hundreds, only to be splattered as quickly as they came with satisfying gun and melee mechanics, rather than stick yourself behind bits of wall and play whack-a-mole.  Regardless of the aforementioned foes being very much kill-able, the campaign still presents a challenge, and while it is indeed only a 7 hour one, it's still fun, even for those who never touched the Warhammer lore in his life like myself.  The multiplayer, while a touch frustrating at first with spam and a leveling system that withholds equipment, quickly becomes addicting with well balanced, variable combat, and best of all, it's very easy to kill campers.  I heard that in October 2011, Steam users will get a free co-op campaign mode, but at the time of writing this, there is no co-op.  Still, a fun and very well optimized experience well worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 2, 2012
												Space Marines are the best thing ever to come out of tabletop games, the insanely over-zealous boistering, the overly elaborate and bulky armor and the sheer ridiculousness of the grim dark future setting are all to be loved greatly. Aside from the setting and characters which are always very good, the gameplay is everything what you would expect from combat with dudes 3 metres tall and weighing at least a tonn. It's clunky, bulky, slow and yet a very, very fast paced game. Combat rolling adds great mobility, jetpacks create great mindgame set-ups and because of it's third-person nature you can essentialy spy around corners without getting seen. A great game that's utterly silly and knows so.If i would rate this it would probably score a 5,860 on the GARthulian-scale.(which is almost as much as riding a flaming crocodile on a tsunami of dead dictators while eating a spicy rib-eye).

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												A solid interpretation of what its like to be a space marine. Murder your way through hordes of orcs with both ranged and melee weapons as you try to stop an invasion. The orcs are trying to capture one of the Imperiums manufacturing worlds where the mighty battle titans are created and only Captain Titus and his Ultramarines can stem the tide until help arrives. The action is gory and brutal and with solid mouse and keyboard controls its easy to switch between aiming with your arsenal of ranged weapons and wading into the fray with your chainsword. The story is actually quite good all up and I got a kick out of playing through it. Its a good action game but if you are a fan of the 40K universe and its lore, its very good.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 28, 2011
												It's a mix between Gears of War and Devil May Cry.  It looks and feels like Gears of War, but then feels like Devil May Cry as enemies barge in screaming at you by the hundreds, only to be splattered as quickly as they came with satisfying gun and melee mechanics, rather than stick yourself behind bits of wall and play whack-a-mole.  Regardless of the aforementioned foes being very much kill-able, the campaign still presents a challenge, and while it is indeed only a 7 hour one, it's still fun, even for those who never touched the Warhammer lore in his life like myself.  The multiplayer, while a touch frustrating at first with spam and a leveling system that withholds equipment, quickly becomes addicting with well balanced, variable combat, and best of all, it's very easy to kill campers.  I heard that in October 2011, Steam users will get a free co-op campaign mode, but at the time of writing this, there is no co-op.  Still, a fun and very well optimized experience well worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2012
												Pros:Visceral combat system with two popular PvP modes (capture point, team deathmatch) emphasizing teamplay. A blast to play with friends, if a bit anemic to play alone. Still active enough to have games running most of the time. Armor customization is detailed, even if the colors do not provide the large RGB spectrum like Dawn of War. But the amount of armor pieces, patterns and color combinations means that you will be hard pressed to create the same thing as another player unless you do it on purpose. Though not free of flaws, many of the early ones have long since been ironed out.Cons:A play-once campaign, with no supporting DLC to keep you going back, trains new players the wrong way for PvP. Anemic DLC adds very little to the game other than a small spattering of maps, unplayed modes, and an expensive lineup of unique armor that cannot be completely picked apart for custom outfits. P2P connectivity provides the constant, irritating spectre of lag and host switching. The graphics were already pushing middle-aged when it came out, but the animation and design made up for that. Nowadays, you'll either not mind or it'll drive you bonkers.The game's been out long enough that it has some fairly entrenched players that can be an overwhelming challenge to newcomers. And with obsessive veterans comes the abusive verbal treatment seen in many communities that have been destroyed by it.Other thoughts:People disagree on the weapon balance. I've used them all, and I think each one is fine, with distinct strengths and weaknesses. The exception being the axe, which is neither as fast as the sword nor as strong as the hammer, striking a balanced surpassed in utility by both alternatives.The community itself is hit-and-miss. While most of the players are amiable, there are a few grudge-bearing sour grape obsessives who will spend hours striving to verbally troll you out of an enjoyable evening. Like in most other online games. But since there isn't really any community control, simply block or don't respond.The game does have cheaters, but they are very rarely encountered. If it isn't something lag-borne like being shot through a wall, and is instead obvious like plasma cannon teleporting to high ledges to release charged shots, then teleporting back to safety, then you'll know for sure.And since this game now has defunct support, there is very little chance we'll see any more content for it, or even a sequel.My opinion's jumped around on this thing like a flea on hot coals. My initial overall landed on around six, but then it grew on me until I bumped it to seven, then finally eight at the peak of my interest. But as long as I keep playing, it's subject to change. Weighing the pros and cons together:7/10I've played for 1,200 hours. Of course I recommend it, with the understanding that the cons are taken into consideration before purchasing.

												I didn't know what to expect since I didn't really follow this game and by the pictures I did imagine more of a Gears of War gameplay, but what I actually got was something closer to Darksiders without RPG elements.  The single player game took me about 5.5 hours in this Hack/Slash shooter.  The melee combat was really fun and I enjoyed all the guns as it was really fun killing the orks. I really enjoyed kickin butt and mixing up melee combat with shooting. I'd recommend this to anyone who loves straight up action games without the need to learn complex ideas/controls.  I'd play it again if I didn't have so many games to play.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2011
												The complete first person W40K Space Marine experience. Ten Ton Boot Stompin' Bolter shmorgasborg is pretty close. Single player campaign combines the dark, dreadly feel you'd expect (if you air-dropped into a Imperial Manufactorum overrun by Orks... and something even more deadly) with surprisingly satisfying and easily mastered combat styles. Those of you familiar with the GoW series will feel completely at home with the visceral execution system of regaining health, while the ability to customize your methods of dealing Death to the Heretics and Xeno Scum by picking weapons that excel in whatever medium you prefer combined with the effortless switch between ranged and close combat equals getting yelled at by my wife at 3:33 AM for screaming " FOR THE EMPEROR!!!!!".The online multiplayer is quite difficult but amazingly rewarding. Co op multiplayer is supposedly coming soon.

content:
Posted: March 3
												Fun, rather old school game, set in the WH40K universe. What I like:- Great gunplay..the weapons have nice sounds, both ranged and melee weapons.  Melee weapon combat has a well executed sense of weight and when you hit an enemy hard, there's a brief slo-mo to add more sense of ludicrous force. The Chainsword's roars and the eventual rough flesh tearing sounds never get less awesome either for example.-Blood and gore..there are nice execution animations for stunned enemies and the blood splash and dismemberment are well made, though there's not many dismembernent variations.-Fluid, brutal and just damn intense combat. No cover shooter stuff. Mostly you fight hordes and I wouldn't have it any other way. You can smoothly switch between melee and ranged combat.No regenerating health ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t! You have a Halo style infinitely regenerating shield, but health is static and there isn't medikits or the like to heal you..you must stun an enemy and perform an execution, it will restore either about 33% of total health or even about 60% depending on executed enemy's type.Overall great sound design. Explosions, the Orks' trademark WAAGH and whatnot.What I rather don't like:Simplistic plot, not saying though it even needs to be complex.Only 3 factions in the game..could have been lots of extra awesomeness potential if more factions were in the story.In conclusion a fun 3rd person shooter with intense combat, the plot is not to be minded, the sheer catharsis of the combat makes up for it.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												Gears of Warhammer is great!Patch in a curb stomp and finish this bad boy.Seriously speaking -Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a game which sits in a heap of awesome lore. You Commander Titus of the Space Marines (Ultramarines Chapter) are the only hope of stopping an ork invasion over a man made Forge World. The purpose of this planet sized workshop is to produce the machinery for the Holy Emperor to fight in the countless wars the Warhammer 40k universe hosts. As the most useful option by calculation Titus and his men are called to the duty. They bravely jump strait into battle to stop the Orks from abusing a so called Titan, a massive war machine of great powers!Do you have what it takes to be the Commander of the Ultramarines? One of the most feared and iconic figures in the Warhammer 40k universe they have become the most honorued by all Space Marine Chapters in the whole Imperium of Man.As they say with holy speech:We are the Ultramarines, the sons of Guilliman.Whilst we draw breath, we stand. Whilst we fight, we prevail.Nothing shall stay our wrath.I fully recommend this game, thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: March 7
A Sci-fi fantasy lovers Dreams  TL;DR Warhammer 40k: Space Marine is a very violent, loud and satisfying Warhammer game. The guns are all super fun to use and sound like hand cannons. The story is the usual affair with Warhammer games where orcs are running amuck but the chaos space marines are the real enemy, its never been the most complex or very interesting story, the gameplay is the main factor which can be a little repetitive but very entertaining for the first while. The multiplayer is also quite fun with multiple game modes and fighting styles to use. It’s also a pretty accurate game to the Warhammer universe.Follow us here Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipPros  Fun & loud weaponsAccurate to Warhammer universeFun combatJump packs Cons Mediocre storyRepetitive gameplay eventually---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- GameplayThe Gameplay in Space Marine is the best part of the game for sure with loud and badass guns everything has explosive shots and make enemies just pop. Throughout the game, you will be given a variety of weapons to switch out and all of them are satisfying to play with either using a giant hammer your regular chainsword or a jump pack is super fun to play with. The problem is once your about half way through the game it get repetitive as you will tend to stick with certain weapons and you’ll be fighting hordes of the same enemy, it will start to feel more like a wave based shooter than an action game. StoryThe story pretty predictable with an odd twist at the end that I wasn’t sure that I liked. The rest of the game it’s just the regular Warhammer jargon of orcs are bad let’s go stop there waaaagh and oh the chaos are here doing demon stuff let’s stop them now. It’s a basic Warhammer game story but it’s still nice to hear and fits nicely. Characters The characters are forgettable as they essentially all warriors conversations are like listening too two slabs of concrete talk, they do stick to their race stereotypes orcs sounds like lobotomized Scotsmen , chaos all sound like angry and overconfident warriors and space marines sound like slabs of concrete.  Art/Graphics The game looks great and all the models look like what your imagine, bulky space marines cant jump or run really fast and the orcs are of varying sizes and easy to distinguish.  Everything in the game looks like actual Warhammer models. The sound design is great as well you are submersed in an actual waaagh and have to be cautious at all moments throughout the game.Bonus Notes If you like this join us here to get the latest Reviews:Steamship Discord: https://discord.gg/XbsKrtKSteamship Steam group : http://steamcommunity.com/groups/thesteamshipWhat would you like to see for our next review ? Ask in the comment section!

content:

												The multiplayer's full of griefers and hackers and is generally unpleasant. But who cares when the Single Player Campaign and the Co-Op mode is soooooooooooooo GOOD ! Great story, great action, The violence is completely over done and over the top. Even the method in which you heal yourself is beyond brutal. Most definitely one the most under-rated games of the last generation. A fantastic Third Person Shooter and a personal favourite with solid mechanics, awesome guns that both perform and sound great (seriously, I can't think of any other game where the weapon sound is as awesome as this. Even your standard side arm gives new, fresh insight into the term "hand cannon"). Giving you all the help you'll need to face down the onslaught of an Ork Waaagh !In the MP / Co-Op the customisation options are numerous and many, As well as being able to choose straight paint jobs from Space Marine chapters of the 40K universe. The Multiplayer itself, instead of being a tactical ground shooter as it probably should be. Just turns out to be half a dozen or so game modes. Where any advance you wish to make is usually thwarted by hammer wielding Space Ninjas. Something which I have never really found a decent footing with. The MP does serves somewhat of a purpose though. As it is the only mode in which you can unlock extra perks and special bits of armour. Though you rely on these extras in the Co-Op, Exterminatus mode. The Multiplayer is the only place where you can obtain them for use. Which is a bit inconvenient and bad planning on Relics part. Multiplayer tends to be pretty much dead. And when it's not. The games are usually squalid affairs, mad rushes of chaotic nonsense in which team communication is non-existant. Running a gauntlet of God Mode kids and aimbots. The major downside of all this is, if you want those weapon perks, then you'll need some good friends to MP with. Either that or go about it in the boring way and do a bit of "Perk farming". Although nice to have. The Weapon Perks themselves don't really add all that much in the Co-Op. It's all really down to how you utilise your loadout and what you're comfortable with using. It certainly won't make things any easier. As the Exterminatus has to be one of the toughest Co-Op game modes out there. No matter how experienced you get. Victory is never a sure fire thing and these three sets (one as DLC), of four horde arenas are an absolute nightmare. Relic really wanted to make you feel that you survive it rather than "Kick its @$$". And provides you a hellish slice of button bashing, trigger pulling warfare. That puts your tiny four marine team into a green-meatgrinder for 21 Waves of unfettered violence.Some might say that the Single Player campaign is a little on the short side, rolling in at around 8 to 10 hours. But that just means that it doesn't out stay its welcome anytime. Keeping the story snappy and to the point, but leaving plenty of room for wanting more (hint, hint SEGA/Relic). And if you can't already tell from the Store Page Vids and Screenies, the graphics and animations are more than competant. Can't praise this enough.Bloody, BLOODY brilliant....And any chump who says different is a heretic of chaos and should be tossed into the WARP to rot along with their squalid collection of girls games !FOR THE EMPEROR 10 / 10***WARNING*** Win 10 users will regularly need to check cache integrity of the game after each time your OS updates. Because, MICROSOFT "/. Don't be dissuaded ! It would just be a shame if you allowed a little technical hitch to keep you from purchasing this wonderful title.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Do you enjoy a nice neon-paletted future where corporations rule and humanity is kept down by an oppressive government? Well then you'll like this, provided you don't want the neon palette. This is the vision of a future where humanity is past its' prime and is trying to fend off the slow decay of time; all while fending off hordes of aliens and daemons. The grimness of this universe is a refreshing twist, even after several decades as a series.Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine puts you in the boots and bulky armour of one of the Imperiums' chapters of Space Marines. If you like sitting behind a wall and occasionally firing over the wall, then just stop there. In this game, there ARE no walls (metaphorically speaking of course)! YOU are the wall. You are a shield for the weak and a sword to be swung by the powers that be. As much as the game preaches that life is the Emperors' currency; you are a sturdy block of gold, in a world populated by pennies and pound coins. So what makes you so valuable, apart from the shiny aspect of your nature?You are a block of Gold. Let's do a comparison. I want you to drop a penny onto your fingers while they are on a desk. Didn't hurt, did it? Now; drop a big block of Gold. If you actually did, I applaud your delusion of invulnerability, but I'm not going to kiss your boo-boo better. If you didn't; you're smarter than the person asking me to kiss the boo-boo. You see, logical thought dictates that there is a big difference in the damage a penny and a Gold Brick can do. You play the heavier of the two objects; that most delightful bringer of death. You are a big stompy thundering cannon comprised of flesh and muscle, located securely behind an energy shield and a hell of alot of metal. You don't fire a little 9mm pistol as you do in so many other titles. With your bulkier stature, you should be able to wield more mighty weapons and this game will allow you. Ever wondered what happens when a rocket propelled explosive shell (with a diameter of nearly an inch) comes into contact with the face of a 6 foot Ork, armed with naught but a club and a suicidal disregard for the laws of physics and mortality? If you answered "red?" then the klaxons in your room, set to ring with the sounds of victory when you are correct (at least if you're as egocentric as I) should be deafening you in reward for your foresight.In a world full of games with lots of brown or orange; this game decides that red is still a viable colour. VERY viable. In fact, so viable that often times you will encounter pools of red where once a green enemy stood. If you are discouraged by blood, this game isn't for you. If you like blood, this game delivers it in such vast amounts that even the least sadomasochistic of us would still require the unbuttoning of the jeans to alleviate the tightness the combat produces. While I recommend this game to women as well, this game has an undeniable reek of man about it. I would be surprised if the word "testosterone" was not included once in every five lines of code written for the engine. While there is a brilliant plot behind the title, it isn't one that I'd recommend you buy the game for. The plot isn't what you want in a game, is it? Plot is a nice addition but gameplay is what differentiates a game from a movie or book and this is a shining example of that ideology. You fire rocket propelled shells from a fully automatic death-cannon; when you aren't lobbing balls of corrosive plasma into the faces of a tiny little green fellow. But range is only a part of the game. To regenerate health, you are not allowed to cower. Your health is tied to your efficiency in combat, as it drops when your shield is depleted and raises when you execute an enemy in close combat. To replenish your red goo, you need to turn your foes into red goo, and presumably the splat perks your character up enough to make him healthy again. Still makes more sense than being eaten by a dog in an open world game and healing up by pulling a bullet out of your left arm. It sounds better too. There is a definite booming sound behind your guns and your mighty melee weapons sound vastly different when they smash into metal in comparison to tearing through flesh. Your chainsword revs pleasurably as you swing it and your heavy bolters sound exactly as the name makes you believe. They sound heavy, as if they were firing bolts. Now let us discuss multiplayer. Six big stompy fellows clash against six big stompy fellows and there are three types of big stompy fellow you can be. You can be a tactical marine, who lumbers across the battlefield with some medium power ranged weapons. The assault marines jet around the battlefield with jump packs, slamming with a mighty force into the ground before spinning their melee weapons viciously to rend the flesh of all who oppose them. If you are more of a heavy fellow, the Devastators will fit you perfectly. Armed with the biggest weapons of all three, they stomp and wield death at range. They are so heavily equipped that instead of shoulder charging an enemy to interrupt the swing of their sword; they kick them. Even as you walk, the camera shakes to give you the true sense that you are heavy, gifted the power of a ton of metal and muscle. The ground never seems to sit still when you introduce twelve armoured Goliaths upon a map.This is a game of David versus Goliath; except this time, you play Goliath and logic wins over storybook morality. Big stompy fellows don't get stopped by a stone, they club the sling wielder into the ground with fist and foot.

Posted: July 1, 2016
												This had been languishing in my backlog as a pickup from a Summer sale 4 years ago.  It's too bad it just now caught my eye as it really is a gem.  The combat has it's quirk, but is generally tight and responsive.  It was billed at the time as the "anti-Gears of War" - it's a 3rd person shooter but not intended to require abuse of cover mechanics.  Unfortunately, the last quarter of that game punishes the player for playing it that way; ditching melee and focusing on ranged firepower is the only way I was able to beat  this very difficult part of the game.This is also nice in short clipping in at 8 hours, so it doesn't overstay it's welcome.  If you like W40K, or 3rd person action games, you can't go wrong picking this one up.  Recommended.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												I don't really know anything about Warhammer, so I can't comment on whether or not Space Marine is faithful to the source material. What I can say is that Space Marine is a good game, and I enjoyed playing it. Even though its a few years old, it still compares favourably to newer games in some ways.Gameplay is really fun. Its a fast paced third person shooter where you're constantly fighting dozens of enemies at a time. There's a decent mix of short and long range weapons, and a few different enemy types. In some sections you fight alongside two other space marines, and their AI is surprisingly helpful. I tended to hang back and use the two variations of sniper rifle, and my allies actually did a good job of keeping melee enemies out of my face.After about an hour you unlock a "fury" meter, which is filled by damaging enemies, and when activated will increase your damage output while regenerating your health, which is really useful in tough fights. There are also a couple of sections where you get a jetpack and a massive, powerful warhammer, which allows you to jump high in the air to avoid enemies, then smash down on them for an AOE attack that will either kill or stun a group of enemies.Level design is entirely linear, and this means the game is also quite short. I finished it in just under 6.5 hours, on normal difficulty. It would have benefited from having a few side paths containing optional objectives.The story is okay, but fairly basic. The Orcs are attacking a Human world, and Captain Titus of the Ultramarines (that's you) is trying to stop them. It gets a bit more interesting about halfway through when something happens that I don't want to spoil. But it never really gets any deeper than "the enemy is over there, go shoot them". However, it does have a fun, ridiculous, over the top but not too serious atmosphere. And it really feels like you're caught up in the middle of a massive war, with other battles in progress around you.As a player who is new to the Warhammer universe, I would have liked a bit more detail so I could properly understand the story. There's lots of jargon, technical terms and faction names such as "codex astartes", "inquisitor" and "psyker" and it seems like the developers just assume that the player is already familiar with the lore. (One of the reasons that I decided to play this game is that there seems to be alot of Warhammer games coming out these days, so I want to try to learn what its all about).The voice acting is pretty good, and features an experienced TV/film actor Mark Strong as Captain Titus. Controls are fully rebindable and I didn't encounter any bugs.I definitely recommend picking up Warhammer 40K Space Marine, and you should be able to grab it on a 75% off deal during one of Steam's many sales.

												Well, the campaign is nice. Everything works fine there.I played it on the Xbox 360 when it first came out, and it was okay. But now, with it being so old, I haven't been able to find any multiplayer matches that have any kind of quality connection. The game was great back then, but now...the campaign is only interesting so many times, and lagging through half of a match isn't what I enjoy.Most of the multiplayer unlocks, equipment and armor, is only unlockable in Versus mode. I wasn't able to find a match. Exterminatus is four players versus waves of orks and stuff, and that has a few minutes on the que time. It also doesn't unlock any new equipment for you to be able to use.I can't recommend this game unless you already have people to play it with. Finding any sort of multiplayer match is not worth waiting more then fifteen minutes and still be waiting. If you're a fan of Warhammer 40k, and want to see the story, then the campaign is there. I got it on sale, so it's not a big waste of money.

Its nerdy  and im a Warhammer 40k fanboy, I get that, but this game delivers even for the non Warhammer 40k fans. It was a solid shooter and campagin with acheivments and trials to put any gamer to test.  This game really deliverd what we havnt seen before and it really broke the mold of what they can do with the Warhammer 40k games and universe with upcoming graphics and tech.  It still can stand up as one of the best Warhammer 40k games out there even with the new and upcoming games. It was that well done.

												Relic have really captured the feel of the 40k universe here and to take on a project as big as this given the fan base from the table top game they have done an outstanding job. 												In the darkness of the 41st Millennium, there is only war. And Aliens. And Daemons. And things that go BOOM!Yep, a day in the life of a Space Marine, involving close combat mechanics, dodging enemy fire and zapping/powing/kersplatting the alien hordes. The mele combat is nice and visceral, and the shooting mechanics are pretty solid to boot. Fun little game, marred only by repetition and lack of scope. By no means a bad game, its fun, but a little lengthy in places and sometimes has yopu crying out for something new along the journey. Still, if you are a Games Workshop afficionado, this is a very faithful game to the lore of 40K.An 8/10 for fans of the IP, 7/10 for everyone else. Good little game but needs a bit more oomph.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2014
												WARHAMMER 40,000 SPACE MARINE is true to the deepest black hole core to the legendary gaming series created by Games Workshop and all its video game conversions bringing the non-stop violent nightmare reality to a excellently executed third person point of view.Grisly graphics, heart pounding tense audio effects, immersive voice acting, epic battle inspiring music, fun detailed game mechanics which are easy to get into yet have a surreal learning style to them such as using the very satisfying jump packs while trying to master manevouring while in flight all makes one feel like they are an actual Space Marine bringing the Emperors will to the enemies of mankind.Enemies are varied and downright scary at times especially with the creepy sound effects.Weapons and melee combat come with many easy to use combo moves which increase damage to a most brutally satisfying visual display. Truly gut wrenching euphoria.Once more RELIC has dared as they did with WARHAMMER 40k DAWN OF WAR 2 and once again they have shown with jaw dropping success to the fan masses change is a good thing.Here is hoping there will be many more chapters unfolding in the huge potential of SPACE MARINE. Praise the Emperor and purchase this violent strategic kill fest if killing Orcs and seeing little Gretchins run for their lives gets your blood going.Thank you RELIC for always making your fantastic creations worth the price of admission :)

												By the time you're done with the first level, you will want to scream 'FOR THE EMPEROR!!' On paper, this seems like your standard third person shooter, there's bullets coming out of stuff, and there's regenerating shields, so all we need now is the cover, right?... What do you mean there's no cover function? What do you mean that what cover there is, is fully destructible? What do you mean shields are depleted easilly? What do you mean I won't be shooting at stuff most of the time? What do you mean I have to wade in there and execute stuff to regain my non-regenerating health?Welcome to Space Marine, where taking cover is HERESY, and where the best way of dealing with problems is to chop its head off or crush it with your BARE HANDS!In the grimdark future of Warhammer 40K, there is only war. And it is glorious, fun to play, and a relief from the mediocrity of other third-person shooters with cover.

												This a 3D shooter in which your avatar (a 3 meter tall superhuman wrapped in baby blue battle armor)  wades through a broken, post-apocalyptic landscape, using a selection of unlikely, anachronistic  gadgets to dissolve hordes of near mindless enemies into piles of gore and clouds of splattered blood.  If that description alone is not enough to make your heart beat a little faster and your palms a little sweaty, you are probably browsing the wrong section of the Steam store.Seriously though, this is a game well worth buying (when it is on sale, anyway).  The gameplay is fairly solid.  The mechanics are entertaining.  And the single-player storyline is actually about as good as gets for a video game, let alone a 3D shooter.  In a genre filled with over-the-top action heroes, pseudo-military jargon spewers and gangster wannabees, Captain Titus, is a genuinely decent , believable hero-type.  Its a nice change of pace.  And the dialogue and voice acting for all the human characters is outstanding.  They really come to life.  I have several much lengthier, deranged rants about playing this game on my blog, accessible from my profile page.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2012
												The metacritic rating for Space Marine is about right (74%), but I thoroughly enjoyed it because the developers painstakingly recreated the 40k universe. I don't think I know if another franchise-based game that feels quite as spot on. With that said, the gameplay does have a few issues. Combat borrows heavily from God of War, with the addition of a solid shooter component (sans cover mechanic, thankfully?); which is to say the combat has variety but lacks real depth. Multiplayer has serious ups and downs, due mostly to the lack of dedicated server support and MASSIVE lag issues if the host is not on your content (which happens about half of the time). The "unlocks" and leveling component offers a few gameplay options without breaking multiplayer. Also included is a co-op "survival" mode (up to 4 players), which only has a few maps but is a riot when you can pull together a few buds for a match. When Space Marine is on sale, it's a great buy for any Warhammer 40k fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												This game is greatly underappreciated.  It perfectly matches the atmosphere of the Warhammer 40k universe.  The game takes place over a short period of time during which the action and importance of what is going on quickly escalates.  Playing as one of the Ultramarines provides a great look into the world of 40k by allowing the players to become a seemingly unstoppable weapon as you fight hordes of enemies.  The game does a great job of making the events feel significant, and by the end of the game I was completely invested in the story.  Sadly, no sequels will be made to follow up on Space Marine, but the game completes what is necessary for the players to guess as to what could happen next.  I would highly recommend this game to Warhammer 40k fans and gamers wanting to be a part of a gritty adventure.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 11, 2014
												This is a great game for Games Workshop, offering strong gameplay and a nice long campaign which covers a small selection of enemies to the Space Marines from the 40K Universe. Though the generic Ultramarine chapter has been designated for the SP campaign, the MP game allows for infinite chapter colours as well as some great DLC chapters. Acquiring all the achivements can take some doing as there are some very specific demands for a lot of them in order to gain bonuses, whereas levelling up to 41 is simply about playing for a long time. The MP co-op is pretty good fun, against the Orks, in a Left4Dead fashion you have to face wave after wave of hoardes of greenskins with a few specialist troops thrown to make things tough. There is also a Chaos version offering a variety of Chaos themed foes. The voice acting is good, gorefest is high, the AI can sometimes be quite tactical and tricky to overcome. There is a strange grenade launcher, original to the game and not a GW concept, it takes some getting used to, though to be fair the most fun comes from using bolters and the chainsword in melée. During MP get used to annoying players who spam metagun and plasma or lascannon attacks, as they are instant kill weapons which generally require less skill than the rest of the armoury. MP's biggest weakness is the lack of an open server list, you are thrown into the lobby of a match the game decides on and that's it.. shame, as this game could easily have attracted a bigger player base had it been more flexible with regards to offering hosting options.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2012
												After an hour of playing, I was severely disappointed. In the game, in the 40K universe, in everything. This was my introduction after having friends nag me to play Dark Heresy with them for the past few months, and me always making hasty assumptions on the Warhammer 40K uni based on the stereotyping inherent in this game's very title that made me cringe. It doesn't help that I'm no fan of hack 'n' slash.As I continued to play, however, I found myself sucked back in again and again, thinking of this game in my off-hours, and suddenly the depth to the game's world and gameplay and the flat-looking characters started showing through, and gosh dang, I'm now seeing what keeps my hombres so enthralled in this self-consciously macho 'n' manly Warhammer business. These MFin' space marines are Zen, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ it. It's a fun diversion, this game, and the story, while predictable, was pretty well-done and -paced--for the most part (the Ork waves did get a tad exhausting).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2015
												This game is seriously the most fun you can have with your pants on!If you want THE quintessential Warhammer 40K experience, this is it. It is brutal, alredanline pumping, blood soaked fun! The game follows a Command Squad of three of the Ultramarines (you play as 2nd Company Commander Titus), called in as reinforcements to the war torn Forge world of Graia. You are big, you are hulking and nothing stands in your way. You ARE a Space Marine and this game gets MASSIVE praise for making me feel like one!In terms of Gameplay, Space Marine plays a lot like the love child of 'Gears of War' and 'God of War' in relation to its shooting and melee mechanics. The controls are slick, the game looks fantastic and it was very fun to just pick up and play. This coupled with a FANTASTIC story ripped straight out of the 40K universe makes it a must have title.25 out of 10. Would absolutely reccommend!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												Now this is one of few 40k games that have the best: settings, story, gameplay and graphics. From the first to the last mission in campagin you will be butcher of Forge World Graia, the number of Orks that you will kill is beyond any reasonably number and it's feels so good. When you get really angry or you feel overrun , just use "Fury" mode and you're done with them. Now here you will feel too much overpowerd but again it feels so good. The game is fully in 3rd person view mod, you can only get in 1st person view mod if you aim with the scope. I must say that I like settings and visual graphics of the game. Everywhere you look you will get that feel of 40k battlefield, completely destroyed city full with bodies of fallen Imperial Guardmans, sad like every other 40k story. When you finished with killing Orks and Chaos legions in campaign you can launch CO-OP which has only one mod, a wave mod. Here you need to defend against 20 waves of Orks and Chaos. Today with lacking players for PvP multiplayer you will spend more time playing only CO-OP mode. When comes to Multiplayer and PvP gameplay, you will get problems. Problem number one, lack of players. Peek number of player daily is ~300 players. Problem number two, playing this game in 3rd person MP is not really interesing to play, you will die often and even when you kill other player, you will get that "meh" effect. It's just that MP game mode looks so simple and boring, very boring. Don't buy this game for MP !Pros:- Great visuals- Great 40k settings- Good story- Good gameplay- Plenty of Orks to kill- CO-OP mode- Space Marines are OverpowerdCons:- Multiplayer - Lack of people playing it- Multiplayer gameplay- Killing Orks gets little boringI highly recommend this game mainly and only for Campaign game play. CO-OP is also fun but it lacks maps. But If you want to play Multiplayer against other players, then you will be disappointed, people just don't play this game. As a 40k fan this is a must have game. Oh and don't buy it for a full price, try to buy it on the sale or something like that.We March for Macragge !!!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												In the darkness of the 41st Millennium, there is only war. And Aliens. And Daemons. And things that go BOOM!Yep, a day in the life of a Space Marine, involving close combat mechanics, dodging enemy fire and zapping/powing/kersplatting the alien hordes. The mele combat is nice and visceral, and the shooting mechanics are pretty solid to boot. Fun little game, marred only by repetition and lack of scope. By no means a bad game, its fun, but a little lengthy in places and sometimes has yopu crying out for something new along the journey. Still, if you are a Games Workshop afficionado, this is a very faithful game to the lore of 40K.An 8/10 for fans of the IP, 7/10 for everyone else. Good little game but needs a bit more oomph.

content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Space Marine is a third-person shooter set within the Warhammer 40k Universe featuring a strike team of Space Marines from the Ultramarine Chapter intent of halting an Ork invasion of an Imperial world.The plot centres around Captain Titus and two squad mates who arrive in the midst of an Ork invasion of an Imperial Forge world with orders to slay the Ork Warlord and crush the invasion. As their mission goes on events unfold to reveal the Greenskin invasion is not the only hazard facing our Ultramarine protagonists.Definitely recommended for fans of the 40k Universe, the settings, characters, weapons, locations, events, set pieces are all very faithful to the source material and are enjoyable to see on screen. The game itself does get a tad repetitive after a while, similar enemies’ crop up again and again but ultimately enjoyable.

There is also a sequel to this series which is Dawn of war 2, and expansions Chaos rising and Retribution.FOR THE EMPEROR! FOR TERRA! (sorry, 40k geek)

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												     This game is a grippin thrid person shooter that pulls you into a world rich with lore right from the start. From the very beginning you feel excited to be a Space Marine and can tell that there are politics going on around you that can only be guessed at. This really adds to the feel of the game. As far as enemies go the orcs can be repetitive and you can start to wonder when you will have a new enemy, but seeing as you are attacking the orc planet its hard to criticize too much on that. They do mix it up well with different orc bosses and increasingly massive and heavily armored or infantry though.     My favorite thing about this game is the mutiplayer. Its crazy addictive and levelling up is a blast in it. I recomend this game to anyone who enjoys a game through the eyes of a true Lawfully Good alligned protagonist who values righteousness and honor above all else, and to anyone who enjoys a glimpse at a vast world that you are directly thrust into.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												This is a fun game and really gets the idea of an Astartes being a walking war machine. It is a mix of shooting and melee, big swarms of enemies, bullets flying, blood spraying and lots of noise !. Pros:The only game representation of a Space Marine i have ever seen to actually nail it. They are straight out of the Black LIbrary Fiction.The Orks are really well done, again, proper 40K style.I like the scenery, the bleak imposing architecture of the Manufactorums contrast with the tighter hab levels. Its not far off what i imagined a Hab world to be. The Melee combat is great, you feel like you are doing some awful damage.The guns, while not as much fun as melee, still have a satisfying punch. The bolter especially captures that big calibre bang well.Even on normal, it can be quite tough, you need to think as much as button mash. You are not invincible.Cons:It is essentially a corridor. A long pretty one but still, a corridor.I sometimes found the camera a bit wonky in tighter spaces, it would zoom in to the point i didnt realise quite how many Orks i had on me or, crucially, allow me to register how many Ork Shootas had me in LOS. I do suck at games mind you !.I tried playing on M/Keyboard at first..... You will need a game pad. It works nicely on a pad but obviously this limits control options.Overall i would say if you like action games and you like the 40K Universe then this is worth your time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Being a Warhammer 40,000 collector and fan of the amount of history in the universe, loving the Space Marine army. This game is great for giving you a chance to see a Space Marine in action as well as the world in the 41st Millennium where there is nothing but war.The campaign was great, really enjoyable combat against the toughest enemies to Mankind along with how the Imperium of Man's Forgeworlds are, especially the Titan Invictus. The multiplayer is the weakest part of the game, especially if you played on PS3/Xbox 360 due to the UI bug but the community gathered together and added members to play prearranged games and it rocked!Seeing what Space Marine had to offer, I saw it as a solid first step that had potential to evolve Space Marine into a better game with future sequels, sadly that chance won't come anytime soon since THQ went down and seeing what Warhammer 40,000: Eternal Crusade has to offer. Having seen some gameplay of 40K:EC, it seems that the combat system is coming back with vengeance.But with every game comes at least one sin. If you know the Ultramarine history of the 2nd Company, Titus isn't the 2nd Company Captain, it's Cato Sicarius. Seeing Black Templars with an Inquisitor, a psyker?! Black Templars hate psykers due to their chapter's vows etc. Those are the only issue I had with the game story wise but still really enjoyed what Titus had to offer, a very solid character and inspirational. The last boss could of been better, more of a titanic clash.Scoring the game? I'll give it a big thumbs up and is a must try for any 40K fan!

content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												Best Warhammer 40K game that gets to be on 3rd Person format.A very interesting story that needs you to exterminate your enemies to satisfy your thrill of whats going to happen next. There are Weapons to choose from and annihilate however you please which makes it just as exciting, and what's more is executing them brutally, either to regain your health or just for the fun of killing. Still graphically amazing even though its been years.Love the action and its animation. Though, it can get quite repetetive and can get boring after a few chapters. Where everything seems to be the same. But because of its story that reels you, there is some kind of balance that hides that boredom. Battle can get pretty challenging, a little sad for me because at each fail you can't even skip the cinematics. This game was an eduction for me as it is the first Warhammer 40K game that I have ever played. Learned a lot through it. It was quite the adventure. Definitely recommended.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												-+-Single player only Review-+-[Before we start this review, let me say, I'm not one of the best gamers, in fact, I'm pretty bad at games, but I enjoy them alot, I love being part of the story and blowing things up]First half of the game, I really love.  There were some flaws, but killing endless waves of stupid green orks was a blast.  Ammo conservation was a minor issue, but I was having a really good time playing this game.As the story and progress went on, these flaws I encountered earlier, really began to be a problem.  Enemies don't drop ammo, there is no real cover system, and the controls were a bit clunky.  I love shooters to death, but Warhammer 40K: Ultramarine wants to be a special hybrid between a melee combat game as well as a shooter.  With clunky controls, it fails to pull off a seamless transition between melee combat to ranged.Another flaw, is your squadmates.  As you play alongside with your team, you get used to your allies being around you, and learn how to use them to your advantage, but during various points of the campaign, your buddies will leave you, and you have to face waves of enemies by yourself, which by then, being accustomed to having comrades to aid you in combat, the game becomes unbalanced and have to find new strategies to take down your enemies.Now, its time for me to address the issue with executions.  One of the few ways to regain points in your healthbar is by performing executions on your foes. This can only be done using melee attacks, and sometimes the animation of an execution may take 3 full seconds and can't be interrupted.  That being said, if you need health desperately you may have no other option.  While attempting an execution, it leaves your character exposed and he won't be able to defend himself as he's stuck in the middle of animation.  I've actually died several times during one of those events because there's no way out of it.The most unfair thing about this title are the boss battles.  In most games, its just player vs the boss.  Sometimes in the middle of the fight in those games, the boss would retreat and bring in his henchmen while he takes a break.  Not in this game.   While the boss is pummeling away at the player while firing all cylinders, all of his companions will be aiding him.  While there are not many of these fights, they are enough to want me to turn the game off.   Some enemies will be throwing grenades, others sniping, while the rest come fighting face to face.  There is no safeway out of boss battles, you basically have to roll around, dodge, and shoot hoping for the best outcome.As I progressed through the game, I learned to hate it.  It had alot of fun moments, being one Ultramarine vs 10,000 Orks was a pretty badass concept and helped my drive to beat the game, but I kept wondering what  unfair disadvantage will the game deliver next?  I once exited a corridor and the game came to a cutscene that introduced a new enemy.  In the cinematic my foe began firing at me.  As the game resumed, my character was standing out of cover while taking damage.  The final boss battle did me in. I finally gave in to its cheap tactics.  I could not finish the game.  I am angry that I fought this far, but could not finish the fight, it was just too difficult and unfair, I spent 98% of my ammo in my inventory before my enemies slain me, they would not go down and there was nowhere to replenish the ammunition. This game couldn't find its identity.  It borrows elements from Gears of War and Devil May Cry, but it didn't know what it wanted to be.  With all the complaining, the game does have some good moments. I really enjoyed the first part of this title and a few other moments in between the final chapters. Killing thousands of orks was satisfying. Very action packed, Michael Bay would be proud.  The storyline is kind of simple, but expands the imagination.Single Player Campaign Review Overall: 6.45

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												This game, although it doesnt seem to be the best graphical game or best shooter around, its definately a great game. Everything in this game adds up to a great experience. The story line of this game and all the settings make this a beautiful game. Some of the graphics aren't top notch but the way they are used and the well designed levels make you feel like your in a large open world with amazing designs. I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys the hack and slash shooter genre or anyone that likes Warhammer as this game does both justice. The game revolves around a Space Marine Captain who you play as and the event of an Ork invasion upon a Imperial Planet, fighting with the Gaurdsman you must stop the invansion at all costs. It seems like a basic shooter, but the weapons and enemys plus the twists and story will keep you entertained as you slash your way through hundreds of orks or blow their bodies apart with massive Laser Cannons. This is a very enjoyable game and although got a few glitches and bugs, still an amazing grab. Its definately worth the price. 8/10

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												For a person that just got introduced to the Warhammer Lore, it's really good...for a THQ game that is. I'm not the type that plays online but the gameplay is very satisfying at times. The gameplay is somewhat similar to Gears of Wars where you hack n slash, shoot, and throw grenades at enemies as you progress in the story. There are no items to regain health, the only way to regain health is that you need to execute an enemy. If I'm going to be nitpicky, I have to say that the execution animations is somewhat off at times, but I'll let it slide seeing it's THQ that made this. There is this special that you become more powerful and regain health for the moment if you're being overrun by enemies.The story, as I got so far in the game, is that you play as Titus, Captain of the Ultramarines, to turn the tide on retaking the Forge world from the Orks and must defend the Titan "Invictus" from the Orks before they will kill the entire planet...I won't go any further on the story...but I can tell you that the ending is a cliff hanger...there was suppose to be a trilogy of this game but since THQ is no more and it's under another company, we will not see anymore sequels to this game.The game is good at the time of 2011. Personally, I do love the Space Marines."We are the Spehss Mahreens! We are the emperor's fury!"
