number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												Every Warhammer game I have played I have liked.  And 40k Space marine is no different.  This game is just ok though.  When we choose to play a game in this day in age I feel if there is no true player progression in stats, leveling up, or points system in the single player campaign I feel a little flimflamed as my fun was not maximized.  And even new weapons and scheduled upgrades can stop the game from feeling devoid of true evolving space marine.  This game is a pure third person action games that isn't to long and should be easy on your wallet.  Fun steam achievement and a good time are reason enough to get this game if you have the time and find Space Marine on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												Really, really, really good stuff.If you ever wandered how it is to be this tactical, assault or devastator Space Marine you command in all earlier titles, how it is to smash orcs and chaos troops with your power weapon, now here is your chance.There is single player story mode, which introduces all weapons and enemies step by step in quite engaging story.There is 4 players coop in which you face waves of enemies getting more and more difficult. In this mode you select and play of of roles - tactical (standard hand weapons), devastator (heavy toys) or assault (jet pack, melee weapon and pistol). Each role is quite different, have it's pros and cons. With DLC you can also play as Chaos Marines (same roles) facing orcs, guardsmen and Space Marines [this mode is more difficult and more rare]. Downside of this mode is that only way to upgrade weapons is from pvp and it carries to this mode, you cannot earn weapon upgrades in this mode.Last is standard team PVP, few maps, good shooting, however I'm not a fan of it. However you can earn weapon upgrades here to boost your coop experience.Best if you have some friends who play, if not you are forced to play with random players, some of them are bad so it is quite hard to each last or bonus waves.Game is great for all fans of the series and fans of action games.Have fun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2012
												The metacritic rating for Space Marine is about right (74%), but I thoroughly enjoyed it because the developers painstakingly recreated the 40k universe. I don't think I know if another franchise-based game that feels quite as spot on. With that said, the gameplay does have a few issues. Combat borrows heavily from God of War, with the addition of a solid shooter component (sans cover mechanic, thankfully?); which is to say the combat has variety but lacks real depth. Multiplayer has serious ups and downs, due mostly to the lack of dedicated server support and MASSIVE lag issues if the host is not on your content (which happens about half of the time). The "unlocks" and leveling component offers a few gameplay options without breaking multiplayer. Also included is a co-op "survival" mode (up to 4 players), which only has a few maps but is a riot when you can pull together a few buds for a match. When Space Marine is on sale, it's a great buy for any Warhammer 40k fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												     This game is a grippin thrid person shooter that pulls you into a world rich with lore right from the start. From the very beginning you feel excited to be a Space Marine and can tell that there are politics going on around you that can only be guessed at. This really adds to the feel of the game. As far as enemies go the orcs can be repetitive and you can start to wonder when you will have a new enemy, but seeing as you are attacking the orc planet its hard to criticize too much on that. They do mix it up well with different orc bosses and increasingly massive and heavily armored or infantry though.     My favorite thing about this game is the mutiplayer. Its crazy addictive and levelling up is a blast in it. I recomend this game to anyone who enjoys a game through the eyes of a true Lawfully Good alligned protagonist who values righteousness and honor above all else, and to anyone who enjoys a glimpse at a vast world that you are directly thrust into.

												Relic have really captured the feel of the 40k universe here and to take on a project as big as this given the fan base from the table top game they have done an outstanding job. Campaign storyline is involving, and gameplay is excellent with the camera moving well during melee combat and a wide selection of ranged weaponary, and a good spread of foe types, mission objectives are varied and challenging. Multiplayer is equal in it's enjoyment offering already three different game types with more and works very well in all, and the option to totally customise your characters armour and weapon loadouts keeps it interesting. It's too bad that the Orkish walkers Killa Kans were not in the main game dispite being featured in the trailers and screenshots. Still this was Relic's last Warhammer game.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												In the darkness of the 41st Millennium, there is only war. And Aliens. And Daemons. And things that go BOOM!Yep, a day in the life of a Space Marine, involving close combat mechanics, dodging enemy fire and zapping/powing/kersplatting the alien hordes. The mele combat is nice and visceral, and the shooting mechanics are pretty solid to boot. Fun little game, marred only by repetition and lack of scope. By no means a bad game, its fun, but a little lengthy in places and sometimes has yopu crying out for something new along the journey. Still, if you are a Games Workshop afficionado, this is a very faithful game to the lore of 40K.An 8/10 for fans of the IP, 7/10 for everyone else. Good little game but needs a bit more oomph.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												8/10 ITS LIKE A KFC FAMOUS BOWL (MANY OBSCURE INGREDIENTS STUFFED INTO ONE PACKAGE BUT ONCE ONE BITE IS TAKEN, YOU'LL BE BEGGING FOR MORE)PROS:- great story - great gameplay- crisp graphics- short campaign (depending on your perspective)CONS:- no replay value- short campaign (depending on your perspective)- cliffhanger ending- sequels most likely not happenBELOW IS MY PERSONAL OPINION ON WARHAMMER 40K SPACE MARINE, READ IT IF YOU HAVE TIME!I have played many shooters in my day across many different platforms and even though space marine didnt have anything unique to offer besides the warhammer setting, somehow i was very captivated by it until the very end.Its story is well paced and its gameplay fast paced and challenging. its gameplay is a combination of gears of war and dynasty warriors. its like drakengard with guns. The game had me by the edge of my seat and with every chapter that passed by i got closer and closer to the edge i was afraid i would fall out of my chair! I can hardly find anything to complain about this masterpiece of a game but if i had to mention something i would probably say "it has no replay value" but that only if i was forced to find a negative about the game itself. i can easily see myself giving this a secondplaythrough within the year. after watching the ending of this game however i began to wonder to myself "ok, so wheres space marine 2?" unfortunately since the game didnt receive alot of attention at its launch and it wasnt producing "call of duty" numbers, sequels are unlikely. hopefully the current IP holder (sega) decide one day that this work of art deserves a sequal that all fans of the space marine game will be able to enjoy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a 3rd person shooter.I've played all Warhammer 40,000 video games. Some were good, and others were so great that I still play them, even several years after their release.This is one of the best 40k games, period. It nails everything- from what makes a good 3rd person shooter, to what makes a true-to-lore 40k game. To start off, This isn't your standard 3rd person-totally-not-gears-of-war game. Whilst most 3PSs focus on a cover system, Space Marine removes that entirely. You ARE the cover. You can wade into a mob of enemies, without dying every 3 seconds. It perfectly encapsulates what makes a space marine a space marine, and lets you experience that firsthand.The combat is divided into two parts- ranged and melee. You are given a wide variety of weapons to slaughter your enemies in different and uniquely brutal ways. Each weapon feels (and sounds!) exactly how it should. The shot of a bolter, the hiss of a meltagun, and the roar of a plasma cannon. And although the ranged weapons are cool, the melee weapons are even better. Chainswords (chainsaw-swords) evicerate and rend flesh whenever they strike, turning a large horde of orks into a bloody mess very quickly. Thunder hammers, although slow, deal tremendous damage and completly pulverise your enemies. The combat (especially in single player or the horde-mode) is immensly satisfying and one of the best parts of the game.The game has both a single-player and a multiplayer. The single player has a decently lengthy campaign (10-12 hours) with a pretty good story. It does have its faults (unfinished story arcs that will probably never get finished b/c r.i.p THQ). The multiplayer, although good and reasonably well balanced, gets repedative with the 4 maps (excluding expansions). You also can't choose which side you are on pre-match, meaning you might not even get to see your shiny new color scheme for a couple matches. The multiplayer also follows the standard 'level up to improve' philosophy, with special perks unlocked by completing challenges (some of which are brutally difficult without help). Overall, this is a fantastic 40k game that really makes you feel like you are playing a space marine.It's practically a badass simulator, 10/10 from me.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												This game, although it doesnt seem to be the best graphical game or best shooter around, its definately a great game. Everything in this game adds up to a great experience. The story line of this game and all the settings make this a beautiful game. Some of the graphics aren't top notch but the way they are used and the well designed levels make you feel like your in a large open world with amazing designs. I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys the hack and slash shooter genre or anyone that likes Warhammer as this game does both justice. The game revolves around a Space Marine Captain who you play as and the event of an Ork invasion upon a Imperial Planet, fighting with the Gaurdsman you must stop the invansion at all costs. It seems like a basic shooter, but the weapons and enemys plus the twists and story will keep you entertained as you slash your way through hundreds of orks or blow their bodies apart with massive Laser Cannons. This is a very enjoyable game and although got a few glitches and bugs, still an amazing grab. Its definately worth the price. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2011
												У меня нет на руках статистических данных, но предполагаю, что вселенная Warhammer 40.000 — одна из популярнейших на сегодняшний день. По ней частенько выходят книги, на игровых сайтах регулярно появляются переводы рассказов и выдержек из кодексов. Но поскольку создавался этот мир для стратегической настолки, то и на компьютерах мы видели Warhammer 40.000 только как стратегию. И было здорово, конечно, но далеко не все любят этот жанр. Да и в роль вжиться не получалось — не было возможности почувствовать себя настоящим космодесантником.А когда она появилась, все «Вахолюбы» ринулись в бой сразу же. Причем часть из них признала проект шедевром буквально после трехминутного знакомства: «Тут можно самому управлять десантником, он на ЛКМ стреляет, на ПКМ рубит — что ещё надо?!»Всем нравится хорошая драка!Хоть такое обычно можно услышать про орков, в Space Marine именно главный герой — зачинатель потасовок и самый большой любитель их. В первые минуты после запуска не совсем понятно, какой именно будет игра. Все-таки вселенная богатая — тут вам интриги, простор для тактики, глобальность. Есть много всего, что из этого выберут для проекта разработчики — бог весть.А выбрали они грандиозное рубилово с участием тысяч врагов и крошечной группы десантников. И у нас есть два варианта действия: либо мы стреляем, либо мы рубим. Еще мы, конечно, пафосно разговариваем, но на такие мелочи жизни внимание не особо обращаешь.В каждой главе мы просто бежим сквозь уровень, где на нас валят толпища противников. Мы их неустанно мочим, а разработчики щедро дают добавки. Порой настолько щедро, что даже не понимаешь, с чем связано такое гостеприимство и на хрена нам так много драться.Если проводить аналогии, то перед нами что-то вроде Gears of War или God of War — рубилово, где все задачи сводятся к одному: УБЕЙ ИХ ВСЕХ!Не много о сетевом режиме.Тут у нас есть три режима («Захват точки» , «Командный бой» и «Экстерминатус» ) и система развития героя. То есть имеются готовые классы с базовыми умениями и оружием, но постепенно мы открываем что-то новое. Получение уровней тоже идет по проверенной схеме. За полезные действия (убийства, поддержка, захват точек) дают опыт, который накапливается… Ну и так далее.Получилось весьма интересно. Все-таки выбор способов уничтожения врагов велик, тактика за каждый класс своя. Можно тут и с реактивным ранцем попрыгать, и в ближнем бою врагов рубить, например.Сетевой режим в целом получился куда веселее, чем кампания. Он не надоедает дольше и вносит разнообразие. Все-таки кромсать других десантников увлекательнее, чем шинковать нескончаемые орды орков и хаоситов.Плюсы: боевик во вселенной Warhammer 40.000; масштабные поединки; весьма хороший арсенал; реактивный ранец; сетевой режим; орки!Минусы: однообразие действий; мало карт и режимов в сетевом режиме.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												-+-Single player only Review-+-[Before we start this review, let me say, I'm not one of the best gamers, in fact, I'm pretty bad at games, but I enjoy them alot, I love being part of the story and blowing things up]First half of the game, I really love.  There were some flaws, but killing endless waves of stupid green orks was a blast.  Ammo conservation was a minor issue, but I was having a really good time playing this game.As the story and progress went on, these flaws I encountered earlier, really began to be a problem.  Enemies don't drop ammo, there is no real cover system, and the controls were a bit clunky.  I love shooters to death, but Warhammer 40K: Ultramarine wants to be a special hybrid between a melee combat game as well as a shooter.  With clunky controls, it fails to pull off a seamless transition between melee combat to ranged.Another flaw, is your squadmates.  As you play alongside with your team, you get used to your allies being around you, and learn how to use them to your advantage, but during various points of the campaign, your buddies will leave you, and you have to face waves of enemies by yourself, which by then, being accustomed to having comrades to aid you in combat, the game becomes unbalanced and have to find new strategies to take down your enemies.Now, its time for me to address the issue with executions.  One of the few ways to regain points in your healthbar is by performing executions on your foes. This can only be done using melee attacks, and sometimes the animation of an execution may take 3 full seconds and can't be interrupted.  That being said, if you need health desperately you may have no other option.  While attempting an execution, it leaves your character exposed and he won't be able to defend himself as he's stuck in the middle of animation.  I've actually died several times during one of those events because there's no way out of it.The most unfair thing about this title are the boss battles.  In most games, its just player vs the boss.  Sometimes in the middle of the fight in those games, the boss would retreat and bring in his henchmen while he takes a break.  Not in this game.   While the boss is pummeling away at the player while firing all cylinders, all of his companions will be aiding him.  While there are not many of these fights, they are enough to want me to turn the game off.   Some enemies will be throwing grenades, others sniping, while the rest come fighting face to face.  There is no safeway out of boss battles, you basically have to roll around, dodge, and shoot hoping for the best outcome.As I progressed through the game, I learned to hate it.  It had alot of fun moments, being one Ultramarine vs 10,000 Orks was a pretty badass concept and helped my drive to beat the game, but I kept wondering what  unfair disadvantage will the game deliver next?  I once exited a corridor and the game came to a cutscene that introduced a new enemy.  In the cinematic my foe began firing at me.  As the game resumed, my character was standing out of cover while taking damage.  The final boss battle did me in. I finally gave in to its cheap tactics.  I could not finish the game.  I am angry that I fought this far, but could not finish the fight, it was just too difficult and unfair, I spent 98% of my ammo in my inventory before my enemies slain me, they would not go down and there was nowhere to replenish the ammunition. This game couldn't find its identity.  It borrows elements from Gears of War and Devil May Cry, but it didn't know what it wanted to be.  With all the complaining, the game does have some good moments. I really enjoyed the first part of this title and a few other moments in between the final chapters. Killing thousands of orks was satisfying. Very action packed, Michael Bay would be proud.  The storyline is kind of simple, but expands the imagination.Single Player Campaign Review Overall: 6.45

content:
Posted: January 7
												As an assault marine, you can't kill someone with a thunder hammer which does OP damage. However, once they kill you, your exploding jumppack will kill them for you. 10/10 would jump pack kill again.Edit: I felt that I should make an actual helpful review. Campaign is amazing, and unlocks both a skin for Chaos and the Ultramarines in MP if you beat it. In MP, lascannons are two-shot kills, one-shot headshots. Thunderhammer is good if you can sneak up on someone. Lots of higher tier weapons are good at one-shots. The only MP servers are siege control standard, and exterminatus.Exterminatus is amazing. You and a team of up to three others [solo is allowed] fight five waves of orks before moving to the next arena. There are five arenas total, each with stronger enemies. Tactical is good for when using dual weapons, devastator has certain spots that make it OP, and the assault isn't that good at anything except escaping. Exterminatus is good for low level players since the PvP servers are full of max level people. Also, exterminatus lets you kill hundreds of orks without mercy for no other reason than you can.

I click it and it crashes instantly.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9
												It was about time a development team took on an action/adventure game based on the Warhammer 40K universe given the endless possibilities for epic battles and complex story-telling and boy does this game pull it off. Intense endless battles through hordes of Orks and cheeky little (if somewhat predictable) plot twists make this game a must buy especially for those who have never ventured into the Warhammer 40K universe.8/10Pros/Cons+ Graphics are very good, especially for a game of this scale in terms of world and battles.+ The collectible servo-skulls added a nice backdrop of storyline at a steady pace.+ Diverse enemies and encounters keep the plot and game play from going stale.+ Combat is very fluid and mixes from gun to melee use extremely well.- If you know anything about the Warhammer 40K universe then the story will be predictable.- The storyline was a tiny bit too short for me even with the collectible servo-skulls feature.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												I know nothing about Warhammer.  I don't know why orks who are basically scrapyard junkers can fly spaceships, why it's the far future but humanity worships a machine god, why some of the dialogue is vaguely medieval, or why Space Marines are all at least SEVEN FEET TALL.  What I do know is that this is a pretty decent third-person shooter.  It's basically Warcraft (which I DO know about) meets Gears of War.  The campaign will only last you 7-8 hours, and from what I understand, the multiplayer has several modes (thanks to AFatalPapercut for correcting me on this)  but no campaign co-op.  If it's on a good sale, pick it up.  Graphics are pretty decent, but with few customization options.  Voice acting is good, optimization is so-so considering the game is 5 years old.  There are occasional absurd difficulty spikes, but the controls are easy, and mingling a fair amount of melee weapons and combat into the game works surprisingly well.

												Campaign is a fun romp through an ork infested forgeworld, short but enjoyable, final boss is a little dissapointing but otherwise ok.Obviously i put alot of hours into multiplayer and despite being several years old at this point still has an active if somwhat small playerbase for online matches. Multiplayer itself consists of standard versus modes, TDM, CTF and control points capture with chaos marines v space marines. Exterminatus is four player co-op against ai orks and chaos at later stages.Sadly some maps are DLC which means you may have some difficulty finding matches for chaos map pack or dreadnaught mode.Pick it up on sale, it is cheap and you'll get your money's worth out of the single player if you enjoy 40K and action games.If you do play multiplayer prepare to rage at assault marines as they zip about on jump packs and stove your face in with a power axe.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												So much about this game solid, even great at times, and the storyline is a treat for any fans of the 40K franchise. The voice acting is often remarkable, considering the content, and the character design and even the weapon loadouts are solid. The great problem is that it's all let down by incredibly lazy and infuriatingly repetitive gameplay. Endless waves of the same mobs, generally unimaginative level design (although it looks great) and totally ineffectual allies make for little more than a lazy, dated shooter.The tedium is very occasionally broken by flying segments, but all-in-all someone at the top has wasted the fantastic work of their underlings and a potentially unparalleled IP. If for no other reason, buy it so that new leadership might be able to justify a sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Relic took solid third-person concepts and crafted them into an excellent atmospheric piece that boasts their same care and attention to detail that they bestowed upon the Dawn of War titles.  Space Marine’s main strength is its well balanced combat system that makes the transition between ranged and melee combat seamless; blasting at a hoard of Orks with your bolter before wading in with your chainsword is tonnes of gory fun. The visuals are still fantastic, really capturing the dark and foreboding atmosphere of the 40k universe. While the story is straightforward enough for 40k veterans and laymen to understand and enjoy equally, that said the single player is somewhat short and the level design while beautifully detailed is restrictively linear at points. Unfortunately, with the collapse of THQ Space Marine will not be getting the two sequels it deserved leaving the cliff hanger ending somewhat bitter sweet.I recommend this game to anyone be they 40k enthusiasts or just a fan of the hack and slash genre in general.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												Warhammer 40,000 Space Marine is an interesting game. It's a linear hack-and-slash / shooter, and it's got some good flavor to it. I criticize a lot of shooters for a lack of variety in enemies, but in Warhammer 4K Space Marine it's more about crowd control and being extra careful with the huge guys than bottle-necking and taking cover (because there are no cover mechanics). It's about pushing through but doing so in a calculated manner and it feels rewarding.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												"For the Emperor, Space Marine"       - Imperial GaurdsmanWarhammer 40k: Space Marine is a third person hack and slash, shooter hyrbrid developed by Relic (renowned for their success witht he Dawn of war series). PlotSet in a paralell Warhammer 40k universe, you play as Captain Titus, commander of the famous Ultramarines 2nd Company. Your task is liberate forge world, 'Graia' from a massive ork invasion. All is not as it seems however, as secrets lay hidden on this forge world, ones which links to the age old foe...GameplayAs mentioned previously, game plays between third person shooter and hack and slash. CampaignThere are chapters with each one having levels which are unlocked as you progress through the campaign. At the start of each level you need to clear the area of enemies and continue moving foward. The map design is quite linear so you won't find yourself getting lost much. Ocassionally there are other objectives which involve activating switches, collecting items defending area and elminating all hostiles. Although starting off with a simple combat knife and pistol, you can find new weapons later on including a bolter, marksman rifle, plasma pistol, plasma rifle as well as grenades. You can carry four weapons at once, but they are can only be swapped between certain weapons e.g. bolter pistol swap for plasma pistol, bolter rifle swap with plasma rifle etc. You can only re-supply at specific weapon crates either in between levels or on the battle field.  There are a variety of foes including shooters, nobs, rokkit boys, slugga boys, weird boys, bloodletters, heretics. Boss battles are also prevailent, testing your mettle a warboss, gunship and chaos lord. You have a energy shield which recharges when you are not under fire. You also have health is recharged at the start of each level or by executing enemies. I did face a few glitches such as enemies failing to spawn, which prevented me to progress in the game. I also didn't like the fact that health was only recovered via executions as they left me vulnerable at times.MultiplayerMultiplayer is a blast to play. There are two game modes Exterminatus and VS mode. Exterminatus pits you (either by your self or up to 3 other players) against up to 20 waves of foes. There are three classes two choose from which are: Tactical, Devestator and Assault. Tactical is basically your jack of all trades. Able to wield rifles and combat knife. Devestator is a range power house who excels at range, but poor in melee. Assault marines have jump packs to get quickly to foes, equiping unique melee weapons and pistol to excel at close range, though lacking against further foes. As you play you can level you earn scores based on the number of foes you defeat. After each match, you gain expereiince which is used to unlock new classes, weapons and perks. There are a few maps to choose from with each one pitting you against the Orks. You will face a variety of foes including sluggas, shooters, rokkit boys (basically all the guys from campaign except the bosses). After the last wave (i.e.20)  there is abionus round which pits you against the forces of chaos. Vs mode pits the loyalist vs the ruinous powers of chaos. one team plays as space marines while the other as chaos space marines. Your goal is to capture the points located in the area. The team that has the most tickets wins at the end of the match. You start with all classes available to you, but you have to unlock new weapons by completing challenges. Such challenges include defeating a certain number of enemies with a particular weapon for instance.AudioAudio is excellent. Weapons sound powerful to wield. Voice acting sounds the same as 'Dawn of war' which I felt was great.GraphicsThe graphics are good, but not spectacular. Models and textures are decent. Plenty of blood and gore though, so it fits the 40k universe quite well.Overall if you are a fan of the 40k universe or want a fun hack and slash game, get Space Marine.

content:
Posted: January 7
												As an assault marine, you can't kill someone with a thunder hammer which does OP damage. However, once they kill you, your exploding jumppack will kill them for you. 10/10 would jump pack kill again.Edit: I felt that I should make an actual helpful review. Campaign is amazing, and unlocks both a skin for Chaos and the Ultramarines in MP if you beat it. In MP, lascannons are two-shot kills, one-shot headshots. Thunderhammer is good if you can sneak up on someone. Lots of higher tier weapons are good at one-shots. The only MP servers are siege control standard, and exterminatus.Exterminatus is amazing. You and a team of up to three others [solo is allowed] fight five waves of orks before moving to the next arena. There are five arenas total, each with stronger enemies. Tactical is good for when using dual weapons, devastator has certain spots that make it OP, and the assault isn't that good at anything except escaping. Exterminatus is good for low level players since the PvP servers are full of max level people. Also, exterminatus lets you kill hundreds of orks without mercy for no other reason than you can.

content:
Posted: January 9
												It was about time a development team took on an action/adventure game based on the Warhammer 40K universe given the endless possibilities for epic battles and complex story-telling and boy does this game pull it off. Intense endless battles through hordes of Orks and cheeky little (if somewhat predictable) plot twists make this game a must buy especially for those who have never ventured into the Warhammer 40K universe.8/10Pros/Cons+ Graphics are very good, especially for a game of this scale in terms of world and battles.+ The collectible servo-skulls added a nice backdrop of storyline at a steady pace.+ Diverse enemies and encounters keep the plot and game play from going stale.+ Combat is very fluid and mixes from gun to melee use extremely well.- If you know anything about the Warhammer 40K universe then the story will be predictable.- The storyline was a tiny bit too short for me even with the collectible servo-skulls feature.

content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												Brilliant Single-Player campaign exhibiting Warhammer 40,000 lore. I don’t know anything about the Warhammer or Warhammer 40,000 world, but despite my ignorance I enjoyed the gameplay. The game also contains an 8 vs. 8 multiplayer mode allowing you to fight off hordes of Orcs and Goblins!Playing Titus an Ultra Space Marine with his Bolt Gun on his right and huge hack sword on his left that makes this chain saw sound every time I slash through my foes tells me that the developers have spent great time exporting a tabletop wargame to a 3rd person videogame flawlessly.It’s a very engaging game. I think you'll like it!Peace.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7
												As an assault marine, you can't kill someone with a thunder hammer which does OP damage. However, once they kill you, your exploding jumppack will kill them for you. 10/10 would jump pack kill again.Edit: I felt that I should make an actual helpful review. Campaign is amazing, and unlocks both a skin for Chaos and the Ultramarines in MP if you beat it. In MP, lascannons are two-shot kills, one-shot headshots. Thunderhammer is good if you can sneak up on someone. Lots of higher tier weapons are good at one-shots. The only MP servers are siege control standard, and exterminatus.Exterminatus is amazing. You and a team of up to three others [solo is allowed] fight five waves of orks before moving to the next arena. There are five arenas total, each with stronger enemies. Tactical is good for when using dual weapons, devastator has certain spots that make it OP, and the assault isn't that good at anything except escaping. Exterminatus is good for low level players since the PvP servers are full of max level people. Also, exterminatus lets you kill hundreds of orks without mercy for no other reason than you can.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2015
												+Perfect optimization, not even a single crash or frame drop at 1080p and 144fps (i5 4690k 3.5ghz, 8 GB, gtx780)+Good variety of enemies+Gameplay is pretty basic but really, really fun+Good story and story telling in pure W40K style+From the mid game plot twist to the final boss, everything goes way up and its GREAT+Exterminatus and competitive multiplayer are AWESOME+It required me almost 15hours to beat the game on hard, plus the coop horde mod and competitive mod, the game is quite long and has a lot to offer+At some point the blood ravens will show up+Loved the open areas...-...not so much the closed ones-Gameplay even if its a lot of fun but can be somewhat ripetitive-The jetpack is one of the coolest features of the game and i get to use it only 3 times, also no aereal skirmishes :(-Unfortunatly multiplayer is dead with less then 400 players-No dedicated servers, this one is BIG.-I really expected a lot more gore from this game, at least mutilations of limbs and torso, after all its warhammer-Graphic not that great -No Cato Sicarius cameo? Really? :(Great W40K game with a lot of potential, too bad THQ went bankrupt and we will never see the other 2 games of the trilogy.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												I know nothing about Warhammer.  I don't know why orks who are basically scrapyard junkers can fly spaceships, why it's the far future but humanity worships a machine god, why some of the dialogue is vaguely medieval, or why Space Marines are all at least SEVEN FEET TALL.  What I do know is that this is a pretty decent third-person shooter.  It's basically Warcraft (which I DO know about) meets Gears of War.  The campaign will only last you 7-8 hours, and from what I understand, the multiplayer has several modes (thanks to AFatalPapercut for correcting me on this)  but no campaign co-op.  If it's on a good sale, pick it up.  Graphics are pretty decent, but with few customization options.  Voice acting is good, optimization is so-so considering the game is 5 years old.  There are occasional absurd difficulty spikes, but the controls are easy, and mingling a fair amount of melee weapons and combat into the game works surprisingly well.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												TLDR – Space Marine is a third person hack & slash shooter taking place in the world of Warhammer 40k. If you’re working your way through the games in the Humble Relic Bundle, Space Marine is a great way to round out your Warhammer experience after beating the Dawn of War Real Time Strategy games. Remember Starcraft Ghost, the first person shooter taking place in the Starcraft universe? Me neither because that game was cancelled. But Space Marine is a decent approximation of what I think that game would have been like. You encounter the distinctive enemies of Warhammer and lead your squad through a war torn world beset on all sides by alien hordes.In this chapter of the Warhammer 40k saga, you play Captain Titus of the Ultramarines (like regular Space marines, but more ultra I guess). Your mission is to infiltrate a planet under massive Ork attack and secure a vital strategic asset before the Orks can get their grubby mitts on it. The Orks (with their British accents) are generally scavengers and will pick apart any technology they can get, including the super secret weapon that happens to be on this particular planet, so it’s up to you to stop them. The game is played in the third person perspective, like Mass Effect but with no real cover system and much more emphasis on melee fighting. You have a small selection of guns and a few melee power weapons that will be familiar to people who’ve played the Warhammer games, for example the chain sword and power axe. The guns are reasonably powerful and you can mow down waves of enemies with your limited ammo before getting to the hack and slash melee fighting. At key points in the game you also get access to the badass jetpack that you often see space marines run around with in the RTS games. The Orks almost always come in large numbers so get used to the melee portion, it will make or break your game experience. Orks aren’t your only enemies though, and you’ll find yourself under attack by forces of Chaos closer to the end who are significantly more difficult to deal with.Pros:+Greater immersion in the Warhammer world since you won’t be getting an overhead view like the real time strategy games. You’ll actually be dropped into it playing as a single person fighting xenos in the name of the emperor. Enemies from the Dawn of War games like Nobs and Chaos demons are real threats, unlike their counterparts in the other games.+Decent story, and some flavor added through “servo skulls” which act as personal logs (similar to the recordings in the Bioshock games). These give you some background on the world you fighting for, and the enemies you’re up against.+The game has multiplayer with some people playing, so I was able to join a few cooperative matches when I wanted to try it out. Cons:-This might be a personal problem, but I seemed to get headaches when playing this game for more than an hour. It probably has to do with the movement of the camera as your Space marine stomps around in his power armor.-There’s a bug with one of the servo skulls if you’re going for the achievement to collect them all. Just get this one last and you should be good. Fortunately you can load specific chapters from the start menu.Note that the difficulty of the game skyrockets in the last half hour or so of the story. The rest of the game is pretty straightforward and you can take your time, but suddenly you’re all alone up against a horde of powerful foes. Overall though, the game is fun and I would recommend it to any fan of the Dawn of War games or action games in general.

												While I have only a few hours played on PC, I played this game for more than 100 hours on Xbox 360. Set in the future where there is only war, you play as a Space Marine super soldier fighting for humanitys right to survive. The campaign is interesting enough and the flow is solid. Can be Repetitive.Multiplayer:At first it might seem like a bunch of super soldiers flying around and cutting you up. Because thats what it is. While there are sniper rifles and other guns many plays like to play as a sword or hammer wielding maniac who charges straight at you.The servers still have some life but its nothing like it once was.Survival mode:Basically, you and a small squad fight against a set number of waves to complete an objective. Waves get harder as they go and it can get really hard.Overall, this game is solid and offered me countless hours of fun in a genre where Warhammer Games have been a let down.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												This game has been on my wishlist for at least 2 years and i've only been able to get it recently thanks to a sale.Man, i just cannot get over how awesome the atmosphere is in this game.I had a ton of fun playing the single player campaign, it was made superbly, as well as being well written in my opinion. I really felt like i was a spacemarine myself. I felt like i was Captain Titus.I felt like i was the only thing standing between the forces of orks+chaos and the survival of all mankind. I felt like i was the hand of the emperor, crushing all that stood in my way. The amount of playtime you could get with this game could vary but it may well be hours upon hours.The multiplayer option allows for either you and a few other spacemarines to take on chaosmarines in full fledged combat or you and a few other spacemarines on an Exterminatus mission where you must purge an area full of xenos.You can customize your spacemarine so you can look like the badass you've always dreamed you'd be and mete out some death and destruction.The graphics are pretty good as you see explosions everywhere, lasers and bullets flying as well. Relic entertainment did a great job on how the world itself would be made, the details on the environments really made me believe that in the future there is only war.10/10Life is the emperor's currency, spend it well..on playing games and all that.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2013
												Let's start out with saying Captain Titus is a badass and he'd still be a badass even if he never was a Space Marine. But lucky for us, he is! So that means Badassius Titanius gets to play with toys that are too brutal for videogames. F*ck that, this is Space Marine, even if it's the Ultrasmurfs.Jokes aside, Single Player pits you in the skin of Captain Titus. The story is a bit predictable, the Orcs are attacking, but you don't really care anyway. This is Space Marine and you have a duty to do. Which is to brutally slaughter Orcs in the most gratuitous way, largely. I won't spoil who the secret enemies are who will start attacking you late-game. (CHAOS MARINES SHHHHH)Health packs are for Heretics. You regain health by stunning an enemy and using a finisher on them.You can carry four firearms, whereof two can be swapped out as you so desire. The array of firearms is classical, with every typical playstyle covered sooner or later. The weapons rarely feel underpowered, but you do have a sense of "wrong place, wrong weapon" at times, which urges you to keep a weapon variation based on distances. Something for close, something for far.Three melee weapons, whereof the Hammer limits your firearm usage to your sidearm or bolter.Melee feels strong and satisfying. Whenever enemies get close, you'll feel like you can rely on melee to finish them off relatively easily. Using the hammer makes you prone to rush in and tear them up, a tactic better fitting with Orcs or equipped with a Jetpack (which is only available on specific areas, sadly)If anything, Single Player makes for a great tutorial on how to handle Multiplayer, which is pretty unforgiving.Multiplayer is pretty much how you imagine Space Marines going at it. It's big, it's harsh and a little bit quick, as your health does not match that of Titus.All the weapons you encountered in the Singleplayer are present, and an extra melee weapon if you bother to buy it's DLC for it. The way you go about choosing weaponry is unusual and interesting.You start out with just one class. Which is the classic Bolter. BUT, you can copy the weapon loadout of the person who killed you. No requirements. If you got killed by a guy with a jetpack, copy it and get some payback. Respawning is fast too.This balances out with being only possible once. Dying again only makes you able to copy that killer's loadout, or pick a class.Reaching level 4, you'll unlock two things.First, a customization slot, allowing you to put together your own class type(normal, heavy or jet♥♥♥♥♥) with the unlocked weapons available to that class type. Then you can read up on the weapon specs and the available (locked or unlocked) perks a class can have. They are various, and many complement a different playstyle with the same class. Variety is endless, and I'm sure that, having unlocked enough over time, you can cater to your own playstyle.Secondly, you can customize your Space and Chaos Marine.Meaning, you can swap out unlocked armor pieces and color your Space Bad*ss in any way you like. In general, the armor has a primary color for the brunt of it, and a secondary such as for trimming and extremities.The color availability itself is pretty impressive and funnily applicable. Imagine picking colors for a car in GTA or Saints Row, that's the kind of options you get to deal with. You get Reds, Yellows, Blues, Greens, then Metallic's and all that jazz. It's pretty hilarious how your Space Marine suddenly is painted like a car.You can also choose the emblem that'll appear on your left shoulder armor. But if you are thinking of coloring your Space Marine in honor of a known existing Space Marine chapter, you shouldn't bother putting in the work. These color schemes are readily available for both Space and Chaos Marines, at no cost or unlocking requirement. Including their emblem.If you like 3rd person shooters with an emphasis on badassery and without sissy features like crouching or cover-based shooting, then Warhammer 40k Space Marine is right up your alley.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												Great game.Space Marine stands alone as third person shooter. It has solid mechanics as well as a pretty decent story. Game mechanics are unique in that there is a great moveset for each melee weapon, and the game is built around maintaining ferocity in close combat and securing execution kills in order to maintain HP. There are no health pickups or regenerating health (although there is a shield/armor mechanic that functions in this manner in addition to the HP). The multiplayer is very solid, with both versus and exterminatus (co-op) being very dynamic and fluid. However, if you're a fan of the Warhammer 40,000 universe in general this game is even more of a treat for you. Seeing the familiar factions rendered in loving detail up-close like this is absolutely awesome. Discovering more of the world's lore through the servo skulls and seeing nods and references to elements of the RTS games were great. Everything is very authentic and recognizable, and it's a great addition to a Warhammer 40k fan's library.Either way you look at it, this game is a purchase that you wouldn't regret. A high energy, vibrant third person action game.

content:
Posted: May 31, 2015
												The future is grim.  The future is cockney...This seems to be one of those games you either love or hate.  I’m definitely in the love camp for this simple yet astonishingly over the top bloodbath.  This was my first contact with the games workshop stuff, and it’s a pretty cool IP.  Playing as Captain Titus, some sort of monastic space warrior lord, complete with chunky baby-blue armour and a few chums, you must save a factory planet from about a bazillion cockney-accented space orcs.  At its core, game design is not very nuanced or progressive; you shoot, grenade, and chainsaw your way through masses and masses of enemies, with little bits of jet-packing here and there.  Despite that, Space Marine is just so much damned fun I could barely put it down, even on my second play through.  For one, this is pure, unadulterated power fantasy with amps turned up to 11. Combat unfolds something like an early Slayer album, as waves upon wave of baddies (who all sound like Hackney cab drivers, for some reason) charge you in cathartic and blissfully chaotic battles which are exhilarating from start to finish. Your green-skinned adversaries often try overwhelm you with sheer numbers, which gives the game a crowd control element not common in these types of shooters; in small numbers, you can paint the walls red with them, but when 30 of the boys run in for a scrum, you’re in for a real slug.  By the end, you will have spilled oceans of blood, as it flies frequently and with reckless abandon.  Add in some great weapons (chain-sword and vengeance launcher, anyone?) and exquisite sound design which adds weight to your weapons and agony to the cries of your foes, and you’ve got one hell of a game. Second, this game gives you something different in that there’s no cover system and no health packs.  Instead, health is regained by using your melee weapon to gloriously eviscerate any enemies; perhaps you’re also some sort of space vampire?  Anyway, it means you must do some gritty hand to hand fighting, and more crowd control as enemies will try to scrum you when you go to replenish your health, making battles even more desperate and ultimately fun. Graphically, this is nothing too special, but it runs well on even modest pcs, and I had good framerates all the way.  I enjoyed the story, although I had to hit Wikipedia a few times to understand what was going on in the wider universe as well as some of the terminology.  I also though the music was very fitting, especially as ominous horn blasts herald charges of green fury.  I haven’t tried the multiplayer yet, so I can’t comment on that.My only real beef is that that Captain Titus and his two buddies are such boring, unemotional and uncharismatic characters. From what i've read online, there are other much more interesting space marine armies, like space vikings, space ninjas and space goths.  Wouldn't you rather play as a space viking?Even though I’m not a games workshop boy, I had a cathartic blast playing through Space Marine, twice.  It’s not subtle, nuanced, or revolutionary. What it is, is just damn good fun.  I dunno what happened to the devs after THQ went bust, but I’d love to see a sequel or successor to this one day.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Space Marine is a very interesting game. It's got several different modes (single player, exterminatus, and versus), each one of which plays very differently. Single player is a typical Warhammer 40K story; i found it quite engaging and interesting, but i'm a fan of the genre. Exterminatus is where you fight wave after wave of enemy, with up to 3 other people. Versus is your typical death match type game. What really makes it stand out to me is how fast-paced the game play is, and how fluidly it blends attacks together. There's also a variety of play styles it supports - you can be a Raptor, or a tactical marine, or what have you. It's got enough variety to keep things interesting for a while.I also really enjoyed that you could play as chaos in exterminatus and versus modes.The character customization is a lot of fun if you are a fan of Warhammer 40K. I was able to get my emperor's children guy looking just about perfect.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												In Dawn of War I, a Space Marine was a faceless soldier slogging through the mud alongside a hundred others, individually weak and collectively strong. In the expansions, the commander got personalised gear, but gameplay didn't change much. Victory came through a horde of power-armoured grunts swamping the enemy. It was strategic. In Dawn of War II, Space Marines were your Brothers. You, Commander, had a face, a personalised fighting style, and Sergeants who had actual voices. Victory  was achieved by taking cover and outflanking the enemy. It was tactical. In Space Marine, you are a superhuman soldier, son of Guilliman. You bring death from above as you descend in a jump pack on wings of fire. When you run, the ground shakes. Your sidearm is a miniature rocket launcher. Your chainsaw sword tears the enemies of the Emperor apart with whirling teeth. As you play, Death is your companion and ally, a trusted friend who brings doom to the Ork. When the enemy has the audacity to harm you, you do not hide and wait for your shield to recharge or your Larraman cells to heal you; you get in the enemy's face and kill them to heal yourself. Victory in the singleplayer campaign and in multiplayer Exterminatus mode is achieved by running toward whoever is shooting at you and taking them apart in a frenzied brawl. It is visceral. You, Captain, are a Space Marine. In the Emperor's name, let none survive.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												This game is criminally underrated, and one of the greatest "didn't sell enough to warrant a sequel" tragedies I can think of. Action games rarely go all out when it comes to the sheer number of enemies you fight, and simplistic-yet-satisfying gameplay is hard to pull off but Space Marine does both incredibly well. The multiplayer is solid for what was probably an afterthought, but the single player campaign is superbly entertaining and packed with violence in the WH40K style. If only this game had Tyranids in it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Simply amazing. If you're 40k fan, the opportunity to play as a single character rather than at a tactical level (as we have so many times before) is brilliant. Combat is an unusual mix of third person shooter and frantic melee combat, which sounds odd in theory but really makes for a great experience.Yes, the campaign is a little short (a good couple of evenings play if you don't rush it), but the voice acting is first class and the story is memorable and true to its roots. Graphically rich and violent in its depiction of the waves of enemies you will righteously purge, it indulges 40k fans with one of the best depictions of the game universe I've yet played.After completing it I dabbled a bit with the multiplayer on Exterminatus mode, 4 players versus wave after wave of enemies or upto 8 man teams versus 8 other human players and that gives the game a bit of extra longetivity.Ultimately, its a game you will want to replay for the campaign or pvp blast. Enjoy it, finish it and then load it up it up again whenever you feel like purging xenos (or human opponents).***EDIT*** I want add the multiplayer is really good. You can play with others against waves of computer controlled enemies as I mentioned before or on two opposing teams of human player against each other. This adds another level of enjoyment.I would STRONGLY SUGGEST you play the co-op game mode "Exterminatus" first to get all the weapons unlocked. "Versus" mode is pretty unforgiving if you don't have access to the Weapons and Perks. Killing the cpu mobs is fun and reasonably easy. With practice I can now complete 2 and a half waves solo, although no doubt there are others who can do better. ***/EDIT***Finally, my recommendation.I picked up the game when it was on sale and frankly I wish I had done so sooner. Grab it whenever it's on sale and don't worry about the DLC, it's not necessary unless you want to look cool in multiplayer.

												A thoroughy enjoyable third-person action game with solid shooter mechanics and immensely satisfying melee combat, Space Marine puts you in the power armor of a captain of the Ultramarines... which makes you feel instantly beyond badass. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												Do yourself a favor: skip Eternal Crusade and get this game instead.   The weapons are fairly balanced, there are a couple that stand out as simpler to use but largely they've all been balanced to perfection.   The different styles offered have a rock, paper, scissor type mechanic which play off of each other very smoothly.  But not so much so that you feel like certain classes automatically beat others.  A skilled player can take all comers with any style no problem.   The animations are extremely smooth and it's managed to stand the test of time in terms of playability and replayability.  The multiplayer doesn't have the playerbase it used to, but this one is still definitely worth your time.   Plays GREAT with a controller or keyboard.  But if you've been looking for a game to utilize that USB controller that's been collecting dust on your shelf, this is a must have. It boils down to this:  smooth responsive gameplay,  tight controls and graphics which are still pretty damn polished.

content:

												Fairly short, I got 12 hours out of it on hard, but pretty darn fun. It's controls feel weighty and satisfying, as do its guns, and the game does a great job making you feel like one of the Emperor's finest. It also does a great job capturing the scale of things in the 40k universe, which really impressed me. Biggest downside is the writing. It's probably the worst I've seen in a game. The conversations are basically trading just one-liners for the first 2/3rds of the game, and the characterization on the marines is just god-awful. But shoot, you're not playing this for the story, you're playing it to be a Space Marine!

												A good action game full of lots of gratifying shoot ‘em up and cut ‘em to pieces cartoon violence.  The game is too short (I finished it in 11 hours) and there isn’t much going on besides the killin’.  The story is simplistic and a bit derivative (lots of Lord of the Rings references and level lifted straight from the films and re-hashed for the setting) but I had fun playing it.  I do wish it were longer and am disappointed that the sequels were cancelled before they were produced as I wanted to play more of it when I was done.  I do think it is over-priced for the amount of gameplay you actually get, especially since it is aging now, but if you see it on sale and like Warhammer I would recommend buying it.Don't bother with the DLC as it is almost useless execpt for multi-player and MP is all but dead now.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2014
												This is a fantastic game that has amazing gameplay and a decent story based on the 40K universe. Gameplay, though simplistic, is very satisfying and at times you truely feel like the powerhouse an Ultramarine Captain should be. The enemies are repetitive, but a constant stream of new weapons and upgrades keeps thing fun and interesting, though some weapons are far worse than others. Melee combat feels a bit weak most of the time, as you end up losing may more health than you would of it you stayed out of close range. However at times it's very energetic, cleaving through smaller enemies is fun and you'll find yourself trying to go toe-to-toe with the larger ones in close combat just for the satisfaction in it, though that usually ends up badly for it. The backgrounds look gorgeous and the scenery, though keeping the general concept of a ruined planet, still manages to change constantly enough to not bore you. Unfortunately, the biggest problem with this game is it's story. The story itself is based on the 40K universe and does a very good job showing the universe to the player... too good, sadly. Throughout the story you follow a character named Titus, a Captain of the Ultramarines. Around the halfway point of the game you come in contact with a source of pure warp energy and survive, your Legate pointing out how impossible that is. While this is brought up a couple of times thereafter, it's not until the end of the game where the full impact of this occurs. After defeating the big-bad and waking up to the sunset, an Inquisitor questions your connection to the forces of Chaos based on what the Legate had told him and he takes you into custody. As a fan of the universe, I know this is an immediate death setence, and Titus, the character you just spent the campaign getting to like, is essentially dead. While this is accurate to what would happen in the universe, it does not make for a satisying ending to a videogame and it really hurt my opinion of this game. Other than the ending, the story is strong, it ties in directly to your objectives and there are some good twists now and then. I strongly recommend this game if you're a fan of the universe, it respectfully represents the Space Marines, Orks, and even Chaos and Inquistion. This game truely feels like what it would be like to be in a Marine's Power Armor, a demi-god like yet heavily outnumbered champion. If you're not a fan of the universe the gameplay is still fun, but don't expect the story to make much sense to you, the developers didn't do a fantastic job explaining things to new fans.

The pvp mode to search for is "sieze ground", other modes than that you would have to make an event for it to happen.The las cannon and melta gun have been quite irritating in mp, sometimes i think the game would have been better without them. The dedicated wikia seemed a bit thin on gameplay mechanic details, so youll need to ask around for tips to learn "aspects" of mp pvp.I havnt experienced super much lag in the pc matches, but plenty of "migrating host"; pauses the game normally for seconds up to a minute or so. On occasion host migrations pauses for minutes or freezes the game and you rather restart the game.The game doesnt seem to be supported anymore, that could be the reason why cheaters are spotted regularly in mp. Cheats consist of having more than two perks activated at the same time, or impossible class-weapon combinations, ex: a tactical with chainsword or power maul. From what ive heard there seem to be a claim that these "weapon bugs/ cheats" could be just visual; that in some way people are able to change the visual display of a tactical knife to a chainsword instead.8/10 would play mp again with friends. I bought the game + dlc¨s in a bundle for 10,74€, and i dont think its worth more than that 2016.

												A good action game full of lots of gratifying shoot ‘em up and cut ‘em to pieces cartoon violence.  The game is too short (I finished it in 11 hours) and there isn’t much going on besides the killin’.  The story is simplistic and a bit derivative (lots of Lord of the Rings references and level lifted straight from the films and re-hashed for the setting) but I had fun playing it.  I do wish it were longer and am disappointed that the sequels were cancelled before they were produced as I wanted to play more of it when I was done.  I do think it is over-priced for the amount of gameplay you actually get, especially since it is aging now, but if you see it on sale and like Warhammer I would recommend buying it.Don't bother with the DLC as it is almost useless execpt for multi-player and MP is all but dead now.

												Definately feels right. You're a badass space marine in the 41 millenium defending a forge world from an alien envasion. The orks, large ape-like green aliens that would make tolkien crap himself, weilding crude ranged and melee weapons. Oh and there's a twist plot twist... if you're familiar with the 40k universe you'll probably roll your eyes when it happens.You'll find yourself finding waves orks weilding various weapons, usually crude blades that engage in melee, which you can match with the iconic chainsword of the 40k universe. Oh ya, also a power axe and a thunder hammer, but really who cares?the consranged weapons feel a bit weak when you're fighting an ork charge. You'll likely only be able to kill 2 of them before they close on you when and you're forced in to melee combat... on the other hand... chainsword. So maybe not a con afterall?Multiplayer makes you feel way too fragile. As a shooter, not my thing, but as a 40k game just a bit unsatisfying to be a space marine and made of paper.8/10

												   I sat down tonight and decided to take a look at some of the games in my Steam Library that I missed over the years. content:
Posted: October 22, 2015
												So I'm updating my previous review which was written at 112 hours of playtime. At present I have just about 548 hours on this game and have to say it's absolutely fantastic if you enjoy Warhammer 40,000 and can get over the occasional lag issues, you will also want to look into joining a clan or a group in order to play the game more frequently.The game's story is good, lengthy and an enjoyable slaughterfest of carnage in the Emperor's name, there has not and most likely may not be any game to come out in the near future that will allow you to wield as much power as you do in this game without being overpowered, you never feel that there's no chance of death and tactics are required even though you can cleave through your foe as though they were made of paper, the singleplayer also allows you to perform epic feats through the use of a slow-mo system called "Focus" that allows you to slow down time when in aim-down-sights mode and increase your melee damage by an incredible amount that allows you to cleave through boyz, nobz and meganobz with ease, the game does lose some of its touch when you finally get to the last few levels where you fight Chaos Space Marines, they are much harder to kill and do not feature any sort of gore which leaves a lot to be desired, but the game is pretty good overall even for just the singleplayer, It'll take you about 8 hours to beat if you play on normal, may vary depending on skill of course.Now. Onto the multiplayer, while it is a laggy pile of crap that often causes desyncs and frustration when people use ridiculously overpowered weapons, it is also bloody fantastic and one of the best and most easily accessible 40k games featuring the Adeptus Astartes to date, no game I've ever played allows you to feel this powerful whilst still being on equal standing with your enemies, you feel like an absolute beast of a man who can tear through an entire team given the right loadout and skill, I've personally gone on 20:0 (K:D) rampages with a stalker bolter with precision shooting in both long range and close combat, it's absolutely visceral and I love it. There are of course the issues of lag which cannot be ignored, every other game will lag worse than playing with Dial-up, remember downloading a 1 minute youtube video for about 8 minutes? that's basically what this multiplayer can be like, people warping around, instakilling you but taking no damage and even receiving no damage even though they stand still. It's very buggy and can get very frustrating but with a group to play with, it's absolutely amazing.Now, I wouldn't recommend buying this game at full price unless you're satisfied with the singleplayer content as the game's multiplayer is becoming less and less active with the upcoming release of Eternal Crusade, I'd say pick this game up on a sale if you can, play it and enjoy some multiplayer games if anyone is still playing but I'd recommend anyone who loves Warhammer 40,000 keeps an eye on Warhammer 40,000: Eternal Crusade, it's an upcoming MMOTPS in the style of Planetside 2 set in the 40k universe, it's shaping up to be absolutely amazing and definitely a game people will want to pay attention to if they love the 40k universe as much as I do.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10
												This is one of the best 3rd person Hack/Slash/Shootem games...period.  It is set in the extremely hostile and brutal Warhammer 40k universe.  Campaign on easy took me about  15 hours to complete and I died excessively.  Much to my enjoyment!  When you die in this game it is awesome because of the sheer scale and volume of Orks that come at you!  There are 3 unique perks/classes to choose from and about a dozen or so classic WH40K weapons like the Chainsword, Bolter, Melta Gun, etc.  In campaign mode there is nothing more satisfying than using a stun attack and then EXECUTING an Ork in a brutal and melee kind of way to REGAIN HEALTH! In multiplayer you get wave after wave of Xeno madness in Exterminatus! I absolutely recommend this game!  I purchased the Chaos Expansion and really enjoy it as well.  This game plays like watching the movie 300...slow mow, blood constantly splattering and flowing over everything, and brutal melee combat that just does not stop! A++

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18
												Well FINALLY! A decent take on a FPS Warhammer 40K! It looks great, feels great, moves great and is (depending on difficulty and/or single/multi-player game selection) as easy and/or hard as to be... - You guessed it: great!The Story is simple and deep at the same time. Lots of shout-outs to the lore and the board game. There's a few things missing, but I'm gonna forgive it, simply because I understand the Devs' problem that they had to keep it all progressive and over-the-course-of-the-game-like. The graphics are so blocky and ugly that they're stunning. (Warhammer 40k fans will get what that means.)The enemies and combat is in-your-face gory and brutal, as it should be in the deep dark universe of Warhammer 40k.The Arsenal of Weapons is not only cool, it stays true to the lore... The characters work incredibly well, and grow juuuust enough during the game that you're feelling bummed when it's all over. (SEQUEL!!! - I doubt it, but, I, for one, would welcome it.)Right... So, down to cases.Pros: 5/7 - Nice, simple, deep, developing, engaging storyline; decent, believable characters (I know you're hoping for more, Devs, but let's be honest. This is Warhammer 40k. Even decent and believable are BIG words of praise for story purposes.) ; Graphics are as they should be. Not pretty, but stunning in their dark, blocky, vast, gritty ugliness; Good Funfactor is excellent. Stomping, Chopping and Shooting Orks and Chaos Marines is SOOO much more fun than it sounds. And It actually gets harder and more fun in multiplayer once you take the time to get into it; Very Nice Replayabillity, (there's ton's of difference between single-and-multi-player-games, and the difference in difficulty settings-vs-feel in the campaign is visible enough that it makes several consecutive playthroughs viable.)Cons: 2/7 The money-maker, unfortunately, is in effect in the multiplayer. (Look Devs, as much as I applaud you wanting to provide assistance to those unfortunate few who don't have the time, talent, skill, or dedication to "earn" the assorted skins, weapons, gadgets and-what-not, BUT do have REAL money they're willing to trade you to GIVE it to them isn't really endearing you to the rest of us, who like a challenge, who like to play and rank up and stuff. I understand you're running a business, I really do, but it's discouraging and more likely than not to make me quit the multiplayer than not.) ; Things are a liiiitle repetitious. The variation in topography and architecture makes it less obvious, and the progression in the singleplayer campaign to bigger, badder, better trained-and-equipped-enemies is all well and good, but while it IS fun to "SMITE THE INFIDELS" "FOR THE EMPEROR!" and all that, I'm not gonna lie. Sooner, rather than later, it'll get old. Thankfully there's tons of content and good ground for replayabillity here, but given the fact that competitors are already vying for top FPS spot in the Warhammer (40k and otherwise) theme, the Devs might wanna consider upping the ante on this title. Soon. More content... More Factions, (Guardsmen, Eldar, Tyranids?) maps, an expansion, whatever... - Theres room to grow here, people, and you know it.(Oh. Incident'ly... I'm gonna go ahead and ask where the "Powers" are, in the game. You know... Psychers or whatever they were called in the boardgame... Every faction had them, more or less... They would probably rock the Multiplayer if you balanced them right... Just saying.)

												This game really takes you to the WH40K world.  The architecture you see in the game, when you run or leap down, you feel as if you weight A LOT, the music is precise and fit for an environment that doesn't promote musical arts (that's why the music is so cool). Posted: February 24
												One of the best Warhammer games available (along with Dawn of War), this game is unique amongst most Warhammer games in that it is  not turn based nor grand strategy, it is a 3rd person shooter similar to Gears of War in gameplay. With a great story, fun gameplay and grimdark world it is a perfect reflection of the Warhammer universe lore. I couldn't recommend this highly enough if you enjoy Warhammer or shooters. It isn't very long, perhaps 8-9 hours story, and the online has mostly migrated to Eternal Crusade now.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2011
												Decent game. The single-player part is a bit boring at times, where you're just walking around, doing nothing. There are also a lot of lifts, with no real function. I think they're there to increase the playtime. Also, I wish there was more variation in environments. About 90% of the game you're inside a building. The shootouts and close combat are satisfying, but can become frustrating. And the reason for that is when you're executing an enemy, you're still open to enemy fire. So while an execution should increase your health again, most of the times it doesn't even help or even gets worse, resulting in too many deaths. And... well, there aren't too many bossfights. I think there are only 2-3. Disappointing.The graphics are sharp, and the voice acting is brilliant (Mark Strong !) though. But this game could've been so much more. Wait for a pricedrop before buying, unless you're into decent games, of course. (The multiplayer is supposed to be fun though, but I've yet to try it.)[Rating: 78/100]

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Play as Captain Titus in this gory third-person-shooter version of the 40k universe (with pretty much no racial/chapter diversity), a battle-hardened Ultramarine who has no idea how to jump over 2-foot ledges or direct instructions. Although some of the game's functions may not work as well as the devs might've hoped, it still delivers hardcore killing-action without any delay (sometimes it gets annoying, but what can you do? Stop crying). Surprisingly similar melee weapons give you many opportunities to pulverise, slash and pound your enemies with; so you'll certainly have your fair share of blood and gore (or don't, and just hoard ammo,  hang back and be the kind of captain that says: "No, you guys go ahead into the fight. I'll stay back here and cover you with my little bolt pistol that conveniently has infinite ammo"). And even when you finish the campaign (Which is a challenging go-here-and-hit-these-things type story on it's own) you can go head to head with the other 4 or 5 players that still play the multiplayer feature, or form a team with up to 3 other players and take on 21 repetitive waves of overpowered enemies in the slightly more popular and less broken exterminatus mode. If you're the sort of person that wants a FPS version of DoW, this is it.Note: Hard mode is pretty easyAlright, we're done here.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Reading some reviews on steam and russian playground.ru, i was a bit disappointed about this game. There were mentioned some mistakes of the developers, concerning behaviour and wearings of the Adeptus Astartes. Never the less, i made up my mind to buy Space Marine. And you know... that was perfect, despite of some mistakes. What about its "minuses" - 1) Its russian dubbing is badly done in some phrases of the main character - sometimes it sounds too indifferent. That irritated me a bit. 2) Meltagun in the game is a kind of shotgun which shoots a cloud of gas, though it releases just a stream, that melts a tank - in cooperation mod it can't humiliate a marine within a shot. 3) Yes, there are some appearance mistakes, which contradicts with the Codex. These are minor mistakes, so if you are not acquainted with precise details of Warhammer "lifestyle", the game will be perfect for playing either in the campaign mode or the coop. Well, "the pluses" - 1) The Ultramarines kill dozens of orcs and heretics. What can be better? 2) Good storyline, i can say it is perfect. Good job. You just should play for a better understanding of its plot. 3) A good cooperation mod, where you can find at least one game. It is good for all the rest Warhammer games, where you have to wait your turn for an hour, 'cause there are no players. 4) Despite of some mistakes, which i described in minuses, the reference to the Warhammer back can be seen here, especially if you know it. The main hero reprimands his subject in narrow interpretation of the Codex and that leads to his departure in the inquisitor's ship. That point leads to forgotten II and XI legions of Adeptus Astartes, forgotten and deleted from Imperial archives. The Ultramarines (as known from some books of Warhammer Horus Heresy) became the biggest legion, just as mainly they were those who recruited marines from these two legions. These marines have one distinctive feature - often they act as they want, not looking into the Codex, while "real" Ultramarines can't but follow it in their belief that no one can be more educated in military science than the Imperator and their Robute Guilliman. This fact points out, that the main character is one of these recruited marines. That fact makes the plot clear and answers everything, concerning this matter. My opinion: don't be afraid to play this game.
