number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												I'm quite surprised how amazing this game is.The single player was one hell of a ride. Extremely enjoyable ride. Ride full of slashing limbs and making big holes in torsos and vaporizing hundreds and thousands (definitely thousands) of green skins and heretics.The combat mechanics are nothing new, but they are well polished and the killing enemies is satisfactory. The melee fighting in large groups of foes could take some work because your character starts to stutter when he is being hit from every possible side and angle. But it's still better than being surrounded by group of enemies and being attacked only by one at a time (ehm ehm AC ehm ehm). Shooting experience is also really good, as is the feeling of watching explosion of blood after a bolt from your weapon penetrates the body of your target. The execution mode which regenerates health by finishing enemies has nice range of incredibly good looking animations.The weapon progression is slow but steady. You have 4 different melee weapons and 10 ranged weapons at your disposal. Through out the game you'll find fury seals (something like a berserker mode) which will upgrade your ability. But only with something incremental as longer fury time, or regenerating HP by inflicting damage. Those are nice things to have, but there could be something more interesting gameplay wise. The steady progression comes to a halt few chapters before the end of the game, which is kinda sad. There are also few instances where you have a jetpack, whit which you can propel yourself up into the air, find a group of foes and fall down on them dealing massive damage, stunning them and looking at the awesome shockwave.The level design isn't anything special or even good. It's a corridor with a lot of curves and vertical traverses. But even though  it isn't great from gameplay point of view, the game has an amazing atmosphere. I love postapo and I could feel it everywhere I've went. It was awesome, the heavy feeling that this world is doomed and that there is no hope for civilians. And that I'm here to help however I can, fighting "alone" against the never ending hordes. This is nicely complemented by a atmospheric soundtrack. The story isn't something special, it's your generic shooter story with a villain and wanna be twist waiting for you somewhere. But I would say that for a WH40k fan it has to be really enjoyable. It's a game that is suppose to be pure fun and relax, not something to think about, so I don't see a problem with the story line. The only weak point was the final boss fight which was a dull sequence of the same QTEs over and over again.There isn't anyone in the multi player right now which is sad. Because when I've played it with friends few years ago it was great fun. There are some basic modes like versus (team against team) or you can play some parts of the story (I don't think it's the whole story, but I can't remember) with a group of friends.My conclusion is that it's a great entertaining game, pure fun from killing thousands of enemies and I can recommend it to everyone.8.7/10 (I like the number 7)

content:
Posted: February 8, 2016
												Rating: 5/10Budget: I dunno...Replayability: LowLength: UnknownWarhammer is great. Warhammer 40K is great too. Warhammer PC games are generally something that tends to leave something desired, but maybe that is just my personal opinion. This old wargame has been reinvented so many times now, that it's actually very difficult to keep up with. This installment is a "hack-and-slash" where you play as an ultramarine. The first 5 minutes of the game made it clear that it was NOT a game I would enjoy. I initially see absoloutely nothing wrong with it however! It's generally just not the kind of game I'm into. If I am to say something positive about the game, the voice acting seems sound, for a hack-and-slash, the game seems well made, the graphics aren't exactly good - but it's an older game by now. Usual repetitiveness of the average hack-and-slash. Requires a bit of Warhammer 40k background knowledge to fully grasp. Probably nothing an hour on a wikipage will not fix. I can't really be one to critize this game, as it's not by genre. I'm not a hater, so I recommend reading some other reviews from people who might be more enthusiastic about this genre of game - that is if you yourself are into this type of game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Brutal simply put brutality at its finest. The Warhammer world is already filled with great story lines and the Space Marines are no exception. In this game you follow Captain Titus and his team and carve your way through thousands upon thousands of Orks in this master piece of a third person shooter/brawling title. The game features a variety of weapons all are very gratifing to use from the starting gun, the bolt pistol, to some of the more classifed weapons such as the vengence launcher. Each weapon has its own kick and sounds like your firing a truly elite weapon each and every single round. The game's melee combat is just as exception as its ranged combat I dare say its even better. From a dagger to a chain saw sword, and a massive hammer the game also features a varity of melee weapons that suit many different play styles all feel great to use and the melee movement and fluidty are astounding. For War hammer fans this game is a must. If your just a fan of smashing little green monsters with giant weapons and guns this game is for you.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Amazing game. Honestly, it is very tough to say a game is perfect, but this gets very close. TL;DR @ bottom.Pros:+Pretty up to date textures+Nice amount of weapons that you can choose from+Smooth controls (I would recommend a gamepad if you have one, although M&Key is OK.)+Pretty great soundtrack++Amazing voice work+++One of your Ultramarines looks like Anthony Hopkins+Decently long game+Plenty of multiplayer contentCons:-Due to THQ going bankrupt, there will be no sequel to this *planned* trilogy. (Ends on insanely annoying cliffhanger) -The online playerbase is a bunch of elitist neck-beards that hate new players-Even on the hardest difficulty, the game was still pretty simpleThis game is all around pretty solid for 29.99. For all the DLC as well, it is 59.99, and completley NOT worth it. Pick this up on a sale, and get the full collection if you really enjoy multiplayer. This game definitley requires that you join a group to have fun with multiplayer. If you've wanted to get into Warhammer 40,000, I'd say this is one of the CHEAPEST ways to do so and enjoy it. This is just scraping the surface of the Lore 40k has to offer. I honestly recommend this to anyone looking for a good 3PS. tl;dr:Great 3rd Person Shooter, feels a bit like GoW with less clunkly movement. Game is stupid difficult without a built in 'cover' function, but still very fun. Pick it up on a sale, and only get DLC if you like multiplayer games.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												I never thought it possible, but these developers managed to turn Chainsaw Sword-wielding Space Marines into boredom - quite a remarkable feat.This title brings nothing new to anything; rather it detracts good stuff from titles many years before it. It feels like playing a very inferior clone of Gears of War - yes, the first one that came out on the original Xbox so many years ago.Suffering from severe consolitis, your character model controls like a tank stuck in syrup while covering roughly a third of your screen at all times. It also has a "sprint" feature controlling like a runaway dragracing car, bumping into objects and disrupting your movement flow.The combat is horrible; combos are repetive mash-button-travesties, and if you do mess up it's because your Space Marine tries to grab the Orc standing right next to the one you stunned - thus you die to BS that is no fault of yours. And to my biggest surprise - this game has grenades so boring I keep forgetting to use them - it's just a flashing red light with a patheticly poor pop at the end of it. Even the guns don't feel meaty or well done, they have that terrible plastic toy gun feel and sound to them.Not to mention it has the gruesome save points we all love to hate, destroying your progress many times over during the game, forcing you to repeat certain sections again and again, ad nauseum.The stages merely consists of bricks, bricks and more bricks, with a ghastly epitomizing color palette of grey, brown, and greyish-brown. It's excrutiatingly tedious on the eyes and one wonders if the artists were color blind or just forgot about other colors in the spectrum.Audio logs has some of the worst and most unspired VAs I've ever encountered and the story is stupid hogwash drivel that brings the game to ruin even faster. The game also have those insultingly boring "puzzles" where you press a button to make your character push a barrel or whatever else on some rails, and it drives the final nail in the coffin for this steaming pile of mediocre garbage.This really isn't worth your money, even on a sale, even in a dollar bundle. They took a huge dump on everything cool about the 40k universe and should be ashamed of it. You'll be bored to death playing it, and it's only because of my sunk cost fallacy I'm even bothering trying to finish the ugly MF. Support some indie game instead, because this so-called AAA game is just a poorly designed trap for your hard earned money. Wait for the reviews on 40k: Deathwing instead, and remember as always - NEVER preorder.

content:
Posted: September 12, 2011
												It's obvious that Relic and THQ didn't learn any lessons from "Dawn of War 2". "Space Marine" has all the same issues - for the campaign, the AI is simplistic and doesn't scale with difficulty; adding in more health and damage is just the cheap and easy way of making things tougher. For multiplayer, the problems are too numerous to mention, but we begin with the horrible lag issues. Many weapons used in multiplayer are extremely counter-intuitive and broken, most egregiously the plasma cannon. There are also constant issues with terrain collision and inconsistencies with executions. (Captain Titus saws orks brutally in half, for example... with the flat edge of the chainsword.)The few good things to say about "Space Marine" overall are that they captured the FEEL of being an Adeptus Astartes very, very well. They also kept to the lore as best they could, which isn't easy when the stated goal was to make the game accessible to non-fans of the Warhammer 40K universe. Overall, a 5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2013
												FOR THE EMPEROR!  Xeno scum and vile daemons shall die before your blade and bolter!Welcome to Irreverend Opinions As we take on Warhammer 40k Space Marine.The BlurbAn imperial forge-world, where machines of war are made, has been invaded by the Ork scum, and it falls on the shoulders of you, a heroic space marine captain, to slaughter them all and save the day.  But wait!  Chaos!First person linear story shooter, with a multiplayer extension.The GoodThe campaign is both fun and involving, no matter if you're familiar to the setting or not.  The story carries a couple of predictable twists, but also a couple of unpredictable ones also, with a bitter ending after victory has settled.  A worthwhile multiplayer experience lets you continue the enjoyment after the game has been completed.The weapons are simple to master for most part, and enemies are both varied and run with a decent AI.  The graphics are very high-standard, from environmental detail to droplets and giblets as you stomp on an orc's head, to smoke coming off the weapon.  Sound quality is quite well-rounded, giving in-game speech without being too overwhelming, and without drowning the player in explosion noises.A very polished piece of work.The BadWhoa, railway much.  The whole game is a corridor shooter.  You can tell that this is simply because of the storyline, which makes up for the fact, but if you want to have a free-roaming sandbox, or even a bit of elbow room, then you'll be left wanting unfortunately.The UglyThe final boss battle is purely QTE.  Really, guys?  Stop doing this.No, really.  Stop it.SuggestionsCan't say much here, with the game this finished.  The core complaints I have are the nature of the game, which cannot be altered without breaking it; and the ending, which honestly I doubt the developers will find worth their time to alter.  If I had my way, I would encourage the ending being shifted to be more inclined to a shooter battle - which is what the game actually functions as, last I checked.The Summary8/10, worth holding onto after the campaign because the multiplayer is enjoyable.  Fun shooter game, if a little restricted, but the story makes up for it.---If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												introduction:I have mixed feelings about this title. Note that I played only SP campagin. the hook:On each level you have to fight through a linear map i.e. get from point A to B with only one possible route with boss at the end. Inbetween some maps you will have something to break the monotony (minigames), like shooting down planes, etc. gameplay:Overall, the gameplay is fun, splashing orks head, or fixing his teeth with a chansword was much more fun than I expected. That being said, there are some things I didnt like.- The moves are ridiculouslly simple to perform. This trivialized button combinations are a slap to the face of classic walking-fighting games you could encounter in the 90's.- As a fan of the WH40k lore, I have to say that the arcade'y gamestyle ruined the atmosphere for me. the game lacks the heavy, dark atmosphere that the books/short stories have, so you might reconsider, If that's what you're expecting (example: automatic healing, 'immortal' AI teammates).summary:The game is OK, the story is a little clichee (but I enjoyed it), so are the characters, gameplay is fun, but simple, it does not have much replay value to me. Some people might find this game awesome, but I cannot recommend this game to any random bloke without a word of warning. recommendation:This game deserves a third kind of rating, 'MEH', but since there is none, I give thumbs down, replayability being the main factor.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												I bought this game for $10 because i loved the Warhammer 40K series. Warhammer made great Dawn Of Wars in RTS modes but when i saw it in third person shooter i was thinking what the ♥♥♥♥? When i took a closer look i saw Games Workshop + THQ. Now that blew my mind. I loved Games Workshop's games and THQ's games so i imediately bought it and played it.Firstly, the campaign is extraordinary with sublime graphics. The cutscenes had fine graphics and the gameplay was awesome! I could not believe how well developed the questline was. Just like Darksiders 2, there is fast gameplay in the campaign where you start off with a chainsaw and a bolt pistol. Then you start cutting all the bloody orks up and Captain Titus does not give a ♥♥♥♥! Next, throughout the campaign, you develop better weapons and a special skill as well which allows you to restore health. New melee weapons such as the Power Axe and the Power Hammer is unlocked. Some levels even allow you to equip a jetpack! When wielding the Power Hammer and flying on a jetpack, the combos and skills combined are absolutely magnificent. Smashing up Ork boyz and beating the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of ♥♥♥♥tards who get in your way! When combos are used correctly, you are unstoppable. Through out the game you also discover weapons such as sniper rifles, laser snipers, heavy bolters, plasma pistols, plasma bolters, grenade launchers and lots more! Later in the chapters, the chaos demons and the chaos space marines appear from a portal after Captain Titus was used as pawns by the Chaos lord. Now havoc wrecks the place and Captain Titus has to save the world with his two companions. In the campaign there are 17 chapters! Each chapter last about 15-45 minutes (depending on difficulty and your skill level). After the campaign there is an epic epilogue to it but, we aren't finished yet.After finishing the campgain there is an online option! In the online section there are 4 main different types of games. Versus, Versus Private, Exterminatus and Exterminatus Private. Versus is basically PVP where you can choose between lots of modes such as capture the point, team deathmatch, free for all, capture the flag and seize ground. The versus servers are still really active filled with players. Versus private is basically versus except it is only for friends and solo. Exterminatus is the co-op survival mode. You can play with 2-4 players on 4 different types of maps. After every 5 rounds you switch to a different map but with harder monsters. In Exterminatus you kill Orks. On the last wave (bonus wave), stage 21, chaos demons and chaos space marines invade you and you must kill them all to win. Exterminatus private is basically exterminatus but with friends/solo only. In multiplayer mode there are 41 levels in total. When you reach level 4 you obtain a place where you can customize you space marine/chaos space marine. When you progress through each level you can unlock more gear, weapons and perks. Armour can be unlocked by finishing really hard challenges or you could buy custom ones from the steam DLC shop for Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine. In multiplayer there are 3 types of main roles: Tactical: Carries a default bolter and a deafult chainsawDevastator: Carries a default pistol and a deafult heavy bolterAssault: Carries a default pistol and a defaul chainsawThe tactical is the support. The devastator is the tank and the Assault is the damage per second. The assault usually wields power axes and power hammers or it can wield relic items from the DLC.This is one of my favourite Warhammer 40,000 games. Games Workshop already makes great RTS and THQ makes great bloody third person gamers such as Darksiders II. If you are a Warhammer 40,000 fanboy, love THQ games, love Games Workshop games, love Darksiders II or if you love thrid person shooters/third person games then you HAVE to buy this game. DO NOT wait any longer buy it now! The only thing that's stopping you is the price -_- Although it is slightly over priced ($39.99) you might want to wait a while until it's about 50%-75%. Stunning graphics, unbelievable gameplay, good multiplayer, great features and epic weapons and classes! MUST PUT ON YOUR CHRISTMAS WISHLIST FOR 2015!!! DON'T LISTEN TO THE ♥♥♥♥ED UP NEGATIVE REVIEWS! BUY THIS GAME NOW9/10Chop2015

												I just finished the game, and I must validate the claim that Space Marine is one of the greatest games you've never heard anyone talk about, or know anyone who has played it.I've read reviews on this game before buying it on sale, and I must say that the negative critiques were nothing more than nitpicking. The only major flaw this game suffers from is stupid ally AI that will walk around in the open, take fire, and not return it. A great resolution to this would have been online co-op, but sadly there's no singleplayer co-op.I just want to point out that Space Marine is the first game in what was supposed to be a trilogy, but things happened, companies went extinct, and there may never be any sequels. With that said, the ending ends on somewhat of a clif-hanger leading up to the next game. However, don't let that stop you from experiencing one of the best & most fun games I've played in a long time. You will indeed feel like a bad @$$.

Posted: November 28, 2013
												As a true fan of 40K I can say I will never pick this game up again to play at any point. The failure to find a sweet spot for game play turns this sour early & stays sour. As a button masher this isn't the worst I have ever played but it forces you to close the range gap to heal your self in close combat with stuns & then death blows, that fails to work when you are getting shot at & have a mob of over 10 orc's around you. The shinny did hit the mark with the feel & story that is 40k but if you cant enjoy the game at all I don't see how that could raise the mark at all. The more I played this game the more I just hated it, you don't feel like a space marine you feel weak & frail not a gene altered human that's 8 ft tall in armor & that has been trained to handle every thing. One of the major problems just comes from the play balance having 360 combat all targeting the player with shooting raining down & no way to get healed but to stay in the melee mix just fails as it drags out every combat & makes the next combat worse if you didn't get healed & remember you still have to run to the shooters to kill them or just get chipped away as you shoot back & don't get healed, the game really just felt like pulling teeth after some levels. This is the fan in me that cant let this one go the bolter is a gyrojet rifle (look it up its a real weapon) not a machingun & it just makes the space marine so much less, a bolter is for a skilled fighter one shot = one kill the machingun is for some one who cant shoot & needs 20 shots to hit...

content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												Singleplayer is fun, in a mindless kind of way, but satisfiying because of the accuracy in the portrayal of Space Marines from the 40k universe in that they are pretty much walking tanks with shield generators. The sad thing is, multiplayer is pure cancer. Singleplayer creates this notion of near invincibilty of your character through a healing mechanism to regenerate either by sitting around waiting, or by the stomping of greenskins. Well, in multiplayer, all you do is the former.     Each engagement feels like you will die, and in most cases you do. Which isn't too bad, but being that many of the modes ask you to be in the thick of combat to win, waiting over ten seconds to spawn or spawn at your base that could be quite a far walk from said thick, becomes very, very annoying. Yes, there is a perk that will bring this down to a couple of seconds, but sometimes that slot could be used for something more useful. Like protection for Tazmanian Devils with Jumppacks and chainsaw swords...     The couple of issues I have with this game online stems from the fact that no proper balancing was ever done. As you rank up winning rounds and killing Heretics, (or non-believers), weapons, armor cosmetics, and class perks become available. Challenges were also included to add some reward for doing such things as kills, kill-streaks, or multikills. But this isn't only restricted to exp toward your level, this also includes weapons perks. The things is, when host has advantage, as well as the many others that have near-perfect connection with them, the game becomes unbearable to play. Killing a single enemy is like perdicting the future in milliseconds. Each action must be made thinking that someone will move into celestial alignment with your sights, granting you access to the heavens and their many gifts thinking once you earn that weapon's perk for completing a specific challenge, you could finally start competing on an equal footing.     Not so much.     Unfortunatly, the god's were unforgiving. THQ was striken down before any balancing could be made. Oh, yeah and hacks are there. Go figure. Just giving you fair warning. Don't expect a lot out of this game multiplayer-wise.

												I just finished the game, and I must validate the claim that Space Marine is one of the greatest games you've never heard anyone talk about, or know anyone who has played it.I've read reviews on this game before buying it on sale, and I must say that the negative critiques were nothing more than nitpicking. The only major flaw this game suffers from is stupid ally AI that will walk around in the open, take fire, and not return it. A great resolution to this would have been online co-op, but sadly there's no singleplayer co-op.I just want to point out that Space Marine is the first game in what was supposed to be a trilogy, but things happened, companies went extinct, and there may never be any sequels. With that said, the ending ends on somewhat of a clif-hanger leading up to the next game. However, don't let that stop you from experiencing one of the best & most fun games I've played in a long time. You will indeed feel like a bad @$$.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												A good game.  The single player campaign is very well made, and the whole aesthetic matches the 40k 'verse to a T.  The multiplayer is a mixed bag.  I don't do pvp much, but you can do 1 v 1 private match to gain all the perks you want so that balances.  The Co-op multiplayer is good - Exterminatus is very fun, but you need 4 people.  At present, the multiplayer pool is essentially dead.  The only way to do co-op or vs in Space Marine is to meet up with one of the dedicated 40k gaming groups (of which there are a good number) and schedule with them, or to have personal friends to play with.  PUG grouping is non-existant nowadays.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												A simple and well rounded third person shooter which while it isnt anything mind blowing it certinly is a fun experince. The story is such you are captin titus of the ultra marines and are sent down on an ork infested planet and your objective is to rid the planet of them it is simple enough. Game play wise it is a third person shooter which decides to forgo cover and just makes use of the space marines overall resistance to bullets. The gunplay is simple and well done with guns sounding meaty. The lore in this game shapes up pretty well to the original lore except for a few places one place being the implamentation of the melta gun which instead of the constant stream it acts more like the shot gun of this game. The single player has a decent story with good gun play and fun if simple melee combat with some exceutions which are reasonably entertaining. The pvp multiplayer is a bit janky with some weapon changes from the single player but is overall solid. The exterminius multipler coop survival is fun and will provide some entertenment even if it gets repetitive. Overall a fun solid if repetitive game which is a worthy entry to a very small list of good warhammer 40k games.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2013
												У нас на руках лежит игра от студии Relic по вселенной Warhammer 40.000 под гордым названием Space Marine я как фанат данной вселенной долго ждал эту игру,ролики отрывочного геймплея что на E3 что из дневников разрабов обещали нам ну просто охренително ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥скую где уже не надо было щёлкать пальцами по мышке так как это уже изрядно поднадоело ,а нам датут толстую тушку космодесантника и на нас вывалят огромную кучу орков ну и свытекающими от сюда полследствиями,но теперь перейдем к цифрам:1)Сюжет: сценаристу я бы лично оторвал бы обе руки и засунул бы ему в задницу потому что такой кретинизм ещё уметь придумать надо,полная скукота и никаких сюжетных поворотов.2)Графон и окружение:карты дико страдают от гигантомании,ну уж слишком они большие в том смысле что идеш в общественную столовую а она высотой в 100 этажный дом текстурки нарисованы скудно,тупые 2D задники аля привет из 2000 года иногда радуют ток реально эпичные пеёзажи но таких моментов мжно по пальцам посчитать(их всего 2).Персонажи нарисованы мыльно,удары оружия как в японском мультеке:искры свет и радуга.3)Геймплей: геймплей сингла по началу представляет что то подобие прикольного =,но это все быстро переходит к идее плана вот тебе локация вырежи все живое на ней.4)Звук:звук оружия в игре реально приятный и радует.5)Мультиплеер:мультик был жив когда игра вышла было несколько режимов pvp типа анигиляция,флаг,превосходство с игроками сражаться интересно куча возможностей как себя повести и действовать печалит только классы их всго три:тактик,штурмовик,опустошитель,описывать их смысла нет так как у каждого свои особенности и фишки но сейчас либо игроков нет вообще или собираестя пати из скилованых ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ов за плечами которых с 1000 часов но в самомо начале он был очень увлекательным и именно за ним я и провел все 100 часов.PVE режим был тоже достаточно увлекательным в лане ты и 4 братюней бегаитеи нарезаите орков в колбасу при этом стараясь не здохнуть тоже очень классная вещь , ну перейдем к оценкам:Графон:5/10 в наше время такой графикой не удивишь.Звук 9/10 звук хорош и этого не отнять.Геймплей 6/10 в лане боёвки тоже есть недочеты.Мультиплеер 10/10 заслуженная оценка за те часы удовольствия что я провел в нем.Вообщем не плохой мультеплеерный шутер от 3 его лица тупым сиглом,но для любителей вахи пойдет.Общая оценка 7/10 но ток из за мультика.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												Endorsement: “A Gears of War-clone that should have replaced the original’s series” I love Gears of War as much as the next guy, it’s awesome and fun. But 40K Space Marines really gives Gears a run for its money in terms of quality of gameplay, and if fully realized, could have easily replaced Microsoft’s exclusive as king of 3rd Person Shooters.Pro:01)	 An action-style, Warhammer 40K game02)	 A genuine twist on the “Gears of War” formula that makes it a personal and engaging-style of play03)	 Visceral game that is hugely satisfying04)	 Uniquely-written characters that go against the “Vanilla, Angry-marine” clichéCons:X1) Gameplay can get too hectic for its unique-style, resulting in unfair deathsX2) Online modes are pretty barrenX3) The story is “porn” for Warhammer fans who want a Space Marine action-game, so you may be indifferent or constitute a contagious case of “eye rolling”Verdict:In a “What If” multiverse scenario, I’d rather see 40K Space Marine’s grow as a mainstay series than Gears. The game is extremely fun and has more gameplay potential than Gears of War could ever have. Get it if you’re looking for a unique-spin on the Gears formula

content:
Posted: July 23, 2012
												Space Marine - еще одно увлекательное погружение во вселенную Dawn of War.Relic молодцы, пошли на опасный эксперимент, и главное, все у них хорошо получилось.Из плюсов могу выделить атмосферу. Конечно, с полюбившейся мне с детства стратегией она не стравнится. Однако весьма неплоха. Ну и конечно, сложность. Играя на среднем уровне сложности, некторые моменты я перепроходил по 10 раз. И это хорошо, как я считаю.Минусы тоже есть. К примеру, бесполезные напарники. Они нужный лишь по сюжету, a в бою от них толка нету, разве что можно отвлечь противника на них, что бы заживить раны. Ну и конечно, большой минус - отстуствие РПГ состовляющей. Как я считаю, было бы неплохо реализовать в игре то, что мы увидели в Dawn of War 2, а ту самую Dawn of War 2 оставить в стиле первой части.Ну и все. Прошел игру с довольствием, ни капли не жалею.

												Warhammer 40k Space Marines is Relics first outing in the 3rd person shooter spectrum of the series and its a competent shooter that's lacking in variety, has a forgettable story with a very sequel bait-ish ending and on top of all that its single player lenght is nothing to write home about, barely passing the 7th hour mark on your first playthrough. 												The singleplayer offers 6-8 hours of brainless fun. No alternate pathways, no high difficulty settings (hardly any deaths on the hardest difficulty available), quite generic 40k story with the most obvious twists imaginable. It still manages to make you feel like a badass. Biggest letdown: Final boss fight is a quicktime event. Did not try the multiplayer (maybe yet, most likely will not).Worth a pickup while on sale for a few bucks (would have been disappointed at full price).

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												Borrows pretty heavily from popular TPS titles, but a lot of the features are tried and true and even if you've played enough of those games, the setting itself is enough to make it interesting. It felt a bit closed off, given you really only see the Ultramarines and Orcs (with various Chaos entities making their appearance eventually) when theres tons of races and chapters. If you love Warhammer and haven't played this, you probably owe it to yourself. There aren't many titles in the W40k library that focus solely on action so if you want to stop strategizing and just kill some greenskins, grab it on sale for a few bucks.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												It's enjoyable enough, and definitely worth a look if you're a WH40K fan.It's very short, though. I installed it in the morning and finished the campaign in the evening. If you're not interested in the multiplayer (which I'm not) there isn't a whole lot of content to be worth the 30 or so they ask for. I picked it up on sale so I don't feel particularly burned by that. It's another one of those console ports that's designed to be beaten in a single rental session.The gameplay is more or less what you'd expect from a God of War clone, just set in the WH40K universe. You can tell Relic doesn't make this kind of game very often, because there isn't even the oh-so-modern feature of being able to huddle up against some cover at the push of a button, like you'd expect in Gears of War or Mass Effect or whatnot.The story was as mentioned very short, and kind of bland as well. Orks show up, Chaos shows up, you kill a lot of stuff and then it's over. That's about it.Still, smashing orkies with a power hammer was very enjoyable.

												Borrows pretty heavily from popular TPS titles, but a lot of the features are tried and true and even if you've played enough of those games, the setting itself is enough to make it interesting. It felt a bit closed off, given you really only see the Ultramarines and Orcs (with various Chaos entities making their appearance eventually) when theres tons of races and chapters. If you love Warhammer and haven't played this, you probably owe it to yourself. There aren't many titles in the W40k library that focus solely on action so if you want to stop strategizing and just kill some greenskins, grab it on sale for a few bucks.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												Was fun for a short amount of time but even though the game is crazily short I don't feel like it was short enough.A few minor complaints, the way to regain health is tedious (and during the animation you're forced into, you can just lose the health you're trying to gain back)..and the over-righteous voices made me giggle rather than take a war game seriously.On the other hand, though, seeing the environments and the creatures of the warhammer universe come to life was pretty awesome, not into the collectibles figures myself but I always thought they looked really cool.Game was nothing more than visual entertainment for me, I much rather would've just watched someone play this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2013
												It's enjoyable enough, and definitely worth a look if you're a WH40K fan.It's very short, though. I installed it in the morning and finished the campaign in the evening. If you're not interested in the multiplayer (which I'm not) there isn't a whole lot of content to be worth the 30 or so they ask for. I picked it up on sale so I don't feel particularly burned by that. It's another one of those console ports that's designed to be beaten in a single rental session.The gameplay is more or less what you'd expect from a God of War clone, just set in the WH40K universe. You can tell Relic doesn't make this kind of game very often, because there isn't even the oh-so-modern feature of being able to huddle up against some cover at the push of a button, like you'd expect in Gears of War or Mass Effect or whatnot.The story was as mentioned very short, and kind of bland as well. Orks show up, Chaos shows up, you kill a lot of stuff and then it's over. That's about it.Still, smashing orkies with a power hammer was very enjoyable.

content:
Posted: January 2
												PROS- The aesthetic of the game is perfect, the Space Marines exactly like they should, as do the daemons and the orks- The story line is very interesting and isn't just a "There are bad guys here, go kill them" sort story-The multiplayer allows for a person to not only choose from a selection of pre-made designs, but to also design their own chapter or warband-Captain Titus, while he is an Ultramarine, is not a rigid, "the Codex Astartes doesn't say we can do this, so we shouldn't character"-While limited the selection of available weapons includes some of the best weapons available to Space Marines-The sound effects of each weapon sound realistic-Accessible to both fans of 40k and new people, without having to have a section of the game that is about universe buildingCONS-The main character is an Ultramarine (I don't dislike the Ultramarines, but there are other chapters)-The game takes place on a Forge World, but there are no Skitarii-Leandros is an example of why people hate the Ultramarines-The choice of weapons is limited-The final boss is a quick-time event-Unique armour sets only available through DLC-No Chaos campaignOverall, I think this game is very well made, despite the flaws.FOR THE EMPEROR or if you prefer FOR THE DARK GODS

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Just bought this yesterday and after beating the campaign I was surprised to find that the multiplayer can still put a decent game together. I can almost always find an Exterminatus game (horde mode) and the gamemode Seize Ground usually has players in it as well. I recommend however that anyone looking to buy this and play multiplayer, first rank up to at least level ten in Exterminatus to get into pvp, since a variety of weapons and different perks only come through levelling up. That said, the pvp balance in this game is for♥♥♥♥♥♥ not necessarily the weapons, but the way the clasees are used and to what extent.Multiplayer overallPro's-Exterminatus and Seize ground are somewhat active-No dedicated servers it seems, but switching hosts only takes a few seconds which is really nice-Armor customization objectives and acheivements add some pretty dank armor and something to play for-Dlc isnt overbearing given that most people play classic anyways-Gameplay really comes down to the situation you find yourself in most (Weapon and class loadout)  and what role you want to play on the battlefield-It only took around 12 hours, probably less, of gameplay to unlock most of the weaponsCons-A space marine can somehow get killed from the rocket boost of an assault pack, and in general you will usually die instantly-a few seconds after being fired upon-Host changes can interupt gameplay and break immersion. (Pauses everything though, so you dont die from it usually)-There is no limit to the type of class there can be on the field at any one time meaning Assault and lascannon spam-One perk pretty much screws an entire class, that being the Tactical Marine, and the perk in question being two main weapons. All this creates is a lack of tactical diversity and more spam-Lower level players will have a lot of difficulty playing the class Tactial Marine since the default bolter is a decent all rounder but is almost useless against the Assault Marine or anything at long range for that matter-Maps can get really repetitive and after about eight hours of gameplay you'll get bored of both exterminatus and versus gamemodes-Higher level players have the advantage of strong weapons and experience, new players will die a lot, and in general you cant take much damage from direct hits which is strange-Back to back deaths without a kill, much less a minute or two of gameplay IG are way too common-The bolter is essentially useless, and overall game balance suffers because of it. With all the different weapons in the game, its become very specialised. Close quarters? Melta/Storm Bolter. Mid Range? Stalker/Plasma. Long Range? Stalker/Lascannon(Devastator class only)I really dont understand why they took out the kraken-round bolter from the campaign.Campaign12/10 would miss like 12 servo skulls somehow again(Story doesnt have much depth nor do the characters but I bought this game to kill♥♥♥♥♥♥in the name of the Emperor so I liked it).Your average person, should I buy it?When its NOT on sale no, on sale at a good discount, yes its fun./tg/ Should you buy it?Of course, you have to buy it in the name of your Spiritual Leige. (Seriously you'll like it)DLCDont bother with it, from what I've gathered from other reviews it seems everyone just plays classic anyways, for the skins and gear, no, unless you're a lore/40k buff and really enjoy buring heretics with your Salamanders armor, but as always do it at a discount. (War gear seems to have the same stats as the default but im not so sure about rate of fire or swing rate so yeah...)I really hope Relic and Sega do more with this game like making the time to kill higher, or release another, too bad its Sega.

												I'm really amazed I don't see any mention of this, but even though the battle system is nice and seems good at first glance, you'll quickly notice this is far from true. There are only 2 ways to regain life, 1 is activating a timed system which will regenerate you for the duration and the other is killing enemies with a special move. Now that sounds fine, but killing enemies with a special move is where the problem lies. During this killing move, you are vulnerable, because it takes a few seconds you WILL get hit at least a couple of times, making the entire special kill worthless and it will cause you to die instead of gain health half of the time.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												I've given this game a "thumbs down" but more because of its current state than because of its raw potential.  If you're buying it for online play...don't.  The online community seems to basically be dead now.  This is a shame because, back when the game first came out, it was a blast to play, with some fun customization for your avatar in terms of wearing different armor and painting it.  (My two favs were playing as a Death Company Blood Angel assault trooper, or a loyalist from one of the Horus Heresy traitor legions wearing pre-heresy armor.)  VERY RARELY, you can find a decent game of basic assault, but pretty much all of the DLC is now useless otherwise (e.g. Dreadnought mode, Exterminatus, the Chaos exterminatus version).  If you can find 16 other people who own this game, you might be able to host a game yourself, but then you'd better hope they live near you.  The problem with the game's multiplayer is that it uses an internal matchmaking system a la Left 4 Dead and shoves you into a game hosted by one of the players.  This means there are no dedicated servers, and, coupled with the dwindling of the in-game community, you could be playing with people on the other side of the damn planet for all you know.  Also, if the host leaves, the game will make someone else the host, which can mean that a good game turns to crap (or vice versa) out of nowhere.  This is a TERRIBLE design approach.That said, the single-player game is fun, if you view it as a videogame and not as a representation of 40K fluff.  Yes, you'll be powerful, but you won't be fluff-level powerful in most cases.  The combat system in this is extremely similar to that found in Darksiders, only the environments are a lot less open and a good bit more linear.  Combat, once you get the hang of it, is fun, though.  Unfortunately, it's also quite short.On the whole, at this point, I'd say buy the game when it goes on sale at, say, $10 or so.  Much more than that, and it probably isn't worth it, given that the SP campaign is extremely short, and Exterminatus on your own is dull and usually ends quickly anyway.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2012
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!This is probably one of the worst ports I've played so far on the PC. This game was pretty clearly developed for console. With little video settings to change, there isn't much wiggle room for people who want to tweak their performance issues, which you will probably have.Even if you do get the game to run at a reasonable framerate, there's the multiplayer issues. For the most part the gameplay is fun, but is totally ruined by the fact that the player base is SO small, and there are no dedicated servers. This is done much like how Gears of War 1 P2P servers worked, as in it didn't. These local hosts usually either live in the UK, or in Africa. Pings usually are yellow or red, and there is a "dynamic" host changer to "optimize" everyones pings, but this ends up in the game locking itself every 5 minute for about 3 minutes saying "Changing Host".I only bought this game because I'm a huge fan of the 40K lore, don't buy this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Warhammer 40k: Spacemarine is a game so caught up in doing a half-arsed job of emulating other successful games, it has no identity of its own. The gunplay is a poor knock-off of Gears of War and the melee combat is a poor knock-off of Arkham Asylum, and the difficulty alternates between snooze fest to rage fest between each encounter. Melee combat has only half a dozen moves per weapon (with just three weapons) and performing the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ finishing move over and over again to regenerate health is a wearying necessity to stay alive, so wading out into the fray is more of a chore than the visceral joy it should be. This is especially true when the ork rocket troopers are introduced en masse as, with no a cover system and a character who moves with all the speed and grace of a sack of potatoes, you'll be obliterated in seconds flat if you aren't constantly leaching enemies for health.The story is uninspired, too. No spoilers here but if you're familiar with the 40k universe, it's pretty predictable stuff.If I had to say something positive about this game, it would be about how appealing the art style and lore is. Then again, considering that these was borrowed from Games Workshop and aren't added to in any meaningful way, it's not credit which the developers are due. The guns feel ok, I suppose, nothing to get too excited about though. Seriously, if I weren't such a fan of Warhammer, there's no way I would have soldiered on to the five hour mark before quitting for good.There is no reason to play Space Marine. Play one of the Gears of War games or Arkham games or, if you want to play something set in the 40k universe, one of the Dawn of War games. Relic should stick to strategy games, they're out of their element here.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												I can not recomend this game at all. If you're a diehard Warhammer 40k fan, then by all means, enjoy the singleplayer and extermanatus modes. Those modes were a lot of fun, and made for some good gaming. The controlls are ok, but the movement is very clunky at best. Multiplayer is unbalanced and complete garbage at times. You will often find yourself on the losing team with no way to bounce back. Framerates will drop super low often, and ruin your best planned ambushes. And what ever you do, DO NOT BUY THE DLC!!!!! If you want to enjoy Chaos Unleashed, be prepared to wait for hours untill you find the 10 people in the world who actually bought it. Don't even bother with drednaught assult, because no one has it. I just wish I played less than 2 hours on this game so that I could refund it. Now I'm stuck with it. It's one saving grace is the fact that it's better than the consol version.   *Update* For a better Multiplayer expiriance, play Warhammer40K: Eternal Crusade. It's not finished, but it's a vastly supirior game, and much more fun to play.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2014
												Advantages:- Nice armor and environment designs- Weapons with different mechanics- Unusual multiplayer experience thanks to jetpacks and melee combat- Deep visual customization in multiplayer- Brutal executionsDisadvantages:- Very stiff acting and naive storyline- Extremely short campaign and only two bosses (both very easy)- Game is easy even on the hard difficulty (and I actually started playing it on hard right off the bat)- Environments are pointlessly very large and empty, some areas suggest they were created to be used for something, it's like two different people took care of surroundings and enemy spawns, the maps have great unused potential- Can't climb laddersI got this game on a -75% sale and I'm happy to have it, I like the multiplayer because it is quite original, yet I wouldn't pay the full price, that's why I don't recommend this game, but I think buying it is not a sin, especially if you're a fan of Warhammer.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Warhammer 40k: Space Marine is a decent shooter with two scoops of Warhammer 40k lore. It mixes streamlined combo-based melee brawling and simple long-range cover-reliant shooting. Neither the melee nor ranged combat get terribly complicated, but they don't have to. The game's level design is marred by a frustrating one-two punch: uninspired and frustrating "arena" combat areas, and poor checkpoint placement. I haven't tried the multiplayer, which seems to be a major selling point, so I might be missing what makes this game good. On the merits of its single-player campaign it's not bad, but you can do better for your time and money.

												subpar to my expectations, I think I bought this game(apart from the super awesome cover art) to get to know the world of warhammer 40k more, I visited Gameworkshop and played a WH40k game on my n-gage, and so I was kinda hoping this game would make me familiar with the universe. an example of a game which did just that splendidly was the Game of Thrones game, I've never watched the series, the game had both great gameplay and twist but also delved into the GOT world details so heavily I didn't follow much, but enough to get a feel for it, to become familiar with it. there was a lot of story there.in Space Marine the gameplay design is mediocre, it's fun and great, but you've had the same experience in a gaziliion games before, and there isn't any new experience. very liniear, too simplistic level designs, and I might say the graphics are also a disappointment but that wouldn't be fair of me, since I'm playing this game in 2015. the story isn't that complicated either.I came here wanting to get to know the world and the races and the politics and the history, was I got are enemies of different colors and weapons to kill in many many ways. fun, repetetive, not what I was looking for.oh, and the button mapping is the worst I can think of in recent memory.and one last thing, i realized later on that the game has huge structures and beatuiful environements. however they're all up such that they don't appear in your normal view while going around, you have to stop and look up at them, if the camera was zoomed out while not in combat or centered up that might've made you enjoy the scenery more.

												I'm someone that loves WH40k and this game is a good entry into the universe. BUTT. There are a lot of reasons why this game just isn't as good as it could/should be. Firstly, the story is short. Very shot. Like you can probably beat this game in one sitting short. But you could tell that they wanted to do more with the story in future additions. So while the story is short, and there isn't a lot or any replayability on that end, lets turn to the multiplayer.The multiplayer is utterly abysmal. Let me elaborate. Character and class customization is cool and allows you to play as almost any of your favorite Chapter/Warband. Finding a game is almost impossible, most of the time there is only one game running and because it's all player hosted, get ready for lag. And lag plays a very key role in a firefight. For example, you can melee attack someone 5 times and do no damage despite it looking like you're doing damage, then all of a sudden you're dead because during that time the enemy appeared to be standing still, he was actually beating your skull in with a chainsword. Hacking is very rampant now compared to back when this game first came out. My guess is there is no anti-cheat, or if there is, it's very far out of date. So expect the random getting killed through walls, across the map one shot head shots, and the snap pistol shots from an assault marine in mid air right before he crushes you. All in all, there was an opportunity for greatness that feel short (RIP THQ). I only recommend buying this game if it's heavily discounted and even then, don't expect much. Stick to the story, and only venture into multiplayer if you're brave or ready for lots of frustration.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2011
												This game is a very bad port of a console game to PC. Multiplayer has no option for dedicated servers and is entirely peer to peer, and thus is plagued by pervasive lag problems. There were periods of days when users spent hours waiting for a game due to it not being able to connect. I didn't have the patience for that nonsense myself. Single player is uninspired. Despite having good voice actors like Mark Strong, the script is insipid, and the voice actors are not given a lot to work with. Single player plays like a beat em up with guns where you run into mobs of enemies to clear after traversing lots of empty space. The final boss fight is a joke and perhaps, best exemplifies what type of decisions went into making the game: defeating the end boss involves following on-screen prompts to click the left mouse button repeatedly, followed by the space button, with an occasional f button, done about a dozen times. Even the animations were as repetitive as the prompts.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												What I was expecting: INTO THE BREACH MY BROTHERS!  *DAKKA DAKKA DAKKA* HOLD THE LINES!!! *BOOM*FOR THE EMPORER!!! *RRRRRREEEEEE SLPOSH RIPPP* CRUSH THE ORKS IN THE EMPORER'S NAME *RIP TEAR*What it actually is:Captain Titus, We need you to run as slow<hold f or press mouse 5 to regen health from executing enemies>ly as possible down this corridor and<Achievement Unlocked: Kill 5 guys> wait <Achievement Progress: 5/1,000 kills> for a wave of orks to show up. Then you kill them. <hold f or press mouse 5 to regen health from executing enemies> When you get to the place,<Achievemnt Unlocked: Got to the Place> there will be another wave <hold f or press mouse 5 to regen health from executing enemies> of orks. Please kill these <Achievemnt Unlocked: Kill 10 guys> orks too.HOWEVER: it's an okay over the shoulder shooter hack n slash, but it's not 40k. Not bad at all for the 8 dollars I got it for on sale. But I wouldn't spend 30 dollars on it. Once I get over how this isn't over-the-top 40k, I'd say this game's a fun lil romp. But I was listlessly sighing a lot while I was playing because you run through these uninteresting empty corridors ("This place is crawling with orks") then you're treated to battle where you can pay attention to what you're doing or just blindly melee everything.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												I can not recomend this game at all. If you're a diehard Warhammer 40k fan, then by all means, enjoy the singleplayer and extermanatus modes. Those modes were a lot of fun, and made for some good gaming. The controlls are ok, but the movement is very clunky at best. Multiplayer is unbalanced and complete garbage at times. You will often find yourself on the losing team with no way to bounce back. Framerates will drop super low often, and ruin your best planned ambushes. And what ever you do, DO NOT BUY THE DLC!!!!! If you want to enjoy Chaos Unleashed, be prepared to wait for hours untill you find the 10 people in the world who actually bought it. Don't even bother with drednaught assult, because no one has it. I just wish I played less than 2 hours on this game so that I could refund it. Now I'm stuck with it. It's one saving grace is the fact that it's better than the consol version.   *Update* For a better Multiplayer expiriance, play Warhammer40K: Eternal Crusade. It's not finished, but it's a vastly supirior game, and much more fun to play.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Just bought this yesterday and after beating the campaign I was surprised to find that the multiplayer can still put a decent game together. I can almost always find an Exterminatus game (horde mode) and the gamemode Seize Ground usually has players in it as well. I recommend however that anyone looking to buy this and play multiplayer, first rank up to at least level ten in Exterminatus to get into pvp, since a variety of weapons and different perks only come through levelling up. That said, the pvp balance in this game is for♥♥♥♥♥♥ not necessarily the weapons, but the way the clasees are used and to what extent.Multiplayer overallPro's-Exterminatus and Seize ground are somewhat active-No dedicated servers it seems, but switching hosts only takes a few seconds which is really nice-Armor customization objectives and acheivements add some pretty dank armor and something to play for-Dlc isnt overbearing given that most people play classic anyways-Gameplay really comes down to the situation you find yourself in most (Weapon and class loadout)  and what role you want to play on the battlefield-It only took around 12 hours, probably less, of gameplay to unlock most of the weaponsCons-A space marine can somehow get killed from the rocket boost of an assault pack, and in general you will usually die instantly-a few seconds after being fired upon-Host changes can interupt gameplay and break immersion. (Pauses everything though, so you dont die from it usually)-There is no limit to the type of class there can be on the field at any one time meaning Assault and lascannon spam-One perk pretty much screws an entire class, that being the Tactical Marine, and the perk in question being two main weapons. All this creates is a lack of tactical diversity and more spam-Lower level players will have a lot of difficulty playing the class Tactial Marine since the default bolter is a decent all rounder but is almost useless against the Assault Marine or anything at long range for that matter-Maps can get really repetitive and after about eight hours of gameplay you'll get bored of both exterminatus and versus gamemodes-Higher level players have the advantage of strong weapons and experience, new players will die a lot, and in general you cant take much damage from direct hits which is strange-Back to back deaths without a kill, much less a minute or two of gameplay IG are way too common-The bolter is essentially useless, and overall game balance suffers because of it. With all the different weapons in the game, its become very specialised. Close quarters? Melta/Storm Bolter. Mid Range? Stalker/Plasma. Long Range? Stalker/Lascannon(Devastator class only)I really dont understand why they took out the kraken-round bolter from the campaign.Campaign12/10 would miss like 12 servo skulls somehow again(Story doesnt have much depth nor do the characters but I bought this game to kill♥♥♥♥♥♥in the name of the Emperor so I liked it).Your average person, should I buy it?When its NOT on sale no, on sale at a good discount, yes its fun./tg/ Should you buy it?Of course, you have to buy it in the name of your Spiritual Leige. (Seriously you'll like it)DLCDont bother with it, from what I've gathered from other reviews it seems everyone just plays classic anyways, for the skins and gear, no, unless you're a lore/40k buff and really enjoy buring heretics with your Salamanders armor, but as always do it at a discount. (War gear seems to have the same stats as the default but im not so sure about rate of fire or swing rate so yeah...)I really hope Relic and Sega do more with this game like making the time to kill higher, or release another, too bad its Sega.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Warhammer 40k Space Marine...Well, this is going to be predictable as hell. For those of you that know what I mean by "predictable" I mean over done, and here's why: The Space marines have been on almost all the marketing for Warhammer 40k. Because of simple box art this usually results in people outside of the fanbase thinking "oh hey, those are the good guy Spartan people from Halo of duty fighting demons in Hasbro reskin armor....Let's go make a chess game out of it...With grenades and AOE attacks...Ya'know, just like chess."So you better like the Space marines 99% of the time because that's what you are going to get until someone revisits Fire Warrior, or release a game about Eldar, Imperial Guard, hell the Orks sound fun! ♥♥♥♥ it, let's begin the review. The Campaign  You play as captain Titus, an ULTRAH SPHESS MEHRIEN! sent to this Forge world with a mission to retake the city from the massive Ork horde. But wait! Turns out the Orks are being led by someone with a brain! Just so you know I'm being sarcastic, it's no surprise who it really is and the videos on the store page give it away before you even purchase the game. There isn't much to talk about the campaign for Space Marine, it's simply 'meh' it's not bad but it isn't good either. It's just...Decent, at least enough to keep you going, unless you get tired of getting your♥♥♥♥♥kicked by Nobs in tight hallways. The Gameplay  To be honest I'm a little disappointed. The execution animations get tiresome after a few hours so that means you'll be playing this game in sips.The ranged weapons also feel dull, and campaired to the awesome power of the melee weapons within the game I felt like there was no point to the guns. It's like giving the player Excalibur at the very start of a game then tell him/her that he/she should use a squirt gun instead...Chances are you're going to go with the over powered weapon they just gave you.But if that was the only flaw within the gameplay I would call this just nit picking. Unfortunately this is a console port...Best way to say that is "♥♥♥♥ keyboard players!"I rarely use controllers since I play 70% of the time on my desktop/laptop. But there are games out there that are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to play without a controller. So, how bad is it? Well the mouse feels slow and unresponsive. The keys are placed in odd areas on the keyboard, for example: by default the 'ctrl' key is the aim button. Character movement on the keyboard is sluggish and hard to control, espeically while sprinting- (I feel like I'm driving a heavily armored gothic bumper car with chainsaws attached! and there are no breaks!)And then there is the audio...The XBOX360 version of Space Marine's sound is perfectly fine, but on the PC? Sound tearing everywhere! This happens generally when there are a large amount of enemies in the area, this is a game about fighting Orks by the way...Enjoy the sound of- "WAAAAAAA-RIIIIIIIP*STUTTERSTUTTER*-AAAAAAAH!!!!" I assume Space Marine suffers the same problem Source games have, but I can't confirm this so I won't go into too much depth about it (god knows I get enough flame wars on these reviews just for saying Hack'n'Slash instead of Hash'n'Slash...Yeah don't ask) The Multiplayer  Normally I'd say the more content the better, but I think multiplayer is the reason why less attention was placed into the singleplayer. But besides that, you start off with a class selection and a long♥♥♥♥♥road of unlocks (oh joy) Tactical, your basic soldier with a bolter rifle and a selection of grenades. After progressing for a while in multiplayer you'll find yourself with a wide selection of guns to use such as- the Plasma gun, sniper rifle, storm bolter, and finally a grenade launcher. Sadly other bolter varients from the lore are not in the game. Also the flame thrower isn't in there either which I have a hard time understanding.Heavy bolter marine, he starts out with a heavy bolter but eventually you get a las canon and a plasma cannon. Although I don't know why because the only "vehicle" in multiplayer is the Dreadnought, and that's a 9.99 DLC! Finally the Assault trooper, this is the most fun you'll get in multiplayer, jumping around from place to place with your jetpack. You start out with a chain sword but eventually you unlock stuff like the power axe and the thunder hammer. Sadly he dominates the other two classes once you get the hammer and it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥just killing one of them. The Final Verdict  When I first bought this game I wanted to give this game at least a 7/10! But later down the road I realised this game is mostly generic. And at it's worst, the PC port was hard to play with all the audio tearing and bugs.Then the multiplayer didn't help with the stupid♥♥♥♥♥progression system children these days demand we have in all of our game selections. If there were no loadouts or leveling system, just pick a gun up off the map then it would be fine. But because Call of Cancer has devoured the minds and hearts of game developers, publishers, and consumers alike we may never see triple A titles free themselves from this terrible trend.Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a 5/10! The console version is a 6/10, but only because the controls and the movement were smoother, and the audio wasn't making my ears bleed. It's decent, but that's all this game has to throw. My suggestion? Get this game when it's on sale, because Relic are a collection of fairly decent folk it goes on sale around 17 bucks every now and then. Until someone stops making Space Marine centered games I'm going to wait another 5 years.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2011
												Despite what contemporary reviews may say, the single player experience is enjoyable. While certain elements can be considered competitive, if played in modest real-world installments this is not noticable at all. Furthermore, the combat and weaponry is simply so fun and accessible that each combat scenario is fun and engaging. I can only imagine that when co-op is available it will only increase the playability. Multiplayer is also interesting, although not my primary draw.The graphics, voice work, and attention to setting in particular is worthy of merit. I think being a Warhammer universe fan is understandably critical to getting a bit more out of appreciating the work that went into this. Is it worth $50? Possibly. Should you buy it the minute it goes on sale or when co-op becomes available in about a month or so? Definitely. Either way, it will not be a bad investment of your money. Because whether some may feel its an average game or above-average game, it's quality work.

												Warhammer 40k Space Marine...Well, this is going to be predictable as hell. For those of you that know what I mean by "predictable" I mean over done, and here's why: The Space marines have been on almost all the marketing for Warhammer 40k. Because of simple box art this usually results in people outside of the fanbase thinking "oh hey, those are the good guy Spartan people from Halo of duty fighting demons in Hasbro reskin armor....Let's go make a chess game out of it...With grenades and AOE attacks...Ya'know, just like chess."So you better like the Space marines 99% of the time because that's what you are going to get until someone revisits Fire Warrior, or release a game about Eldar, Imperial Guard, hell the Orks sound fun! ♥♥♥♥ it, let's begin the review. The Campaign  You play as captain Titus, an ULTRAH SPHESS MEHRIEN! sent to this Forge world with a mission to retake the city from the massive Ork horde. But wait! Turns out the Orks are being led by someone with a brain! Just so you know I'm being sarcastic, it's no surprise who it really is and the videos on the store page give it away before you even purchase the game. There isn't much to talk about the campaign for Space Marine, it's simply 'meh' it's not bad but it isn't good either. It's just...Decent, at least enough to keep you going, unless you get tired of getting your♥♥♥♥♥kicked by Nobs in tight hallways. The Gameplay  To be honest I'm a little disappointed. The execution animations get tiresome after a few hours so that means you'll be playing this game in sips.The ranged weapons also feel dull, and campaired to the awesome power of the melee weapons within the game I felt like there was no point to the guns. It's like giving the player Excalibur at the very start of a game then tell him/her that he/she should use a squirt gun instead...Chances are you're going to go with the over powered weapon they just gave you.But if that was the only flaw within the gameplay I would call this just nit picking. Unfortunately this is a console port...Best way to say that is "♥♥♥♥ keyboard players!"I rarely use controllers since I play 70% of the time on my desktop/laptop. But there are games out there that are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to play without a controller. So, how bad is it? Well the mouse feels slow and unresponsive. The keys are placed in odd areas on the keyboard, for example: by default the 'ctrl' key is the aim button. Character movement on the keyboard is sluggish and hard to control, espeically while sprinting- (I feel like I'm driving a heavily armored gothic bumper car with chainsaws attached! and there are no breaks!)And then there is the audio...The XBOX360 version of Space Marine's sound is perfectly fine, but on the PC? Sound tearing everywhere! This happens generally when there are a large amount of enemies in the area, this is a game about fighting Orks by the way...Enjoy the sound of- "WAAAAAAA-RIIIIIIIP*STUTTERSTUTTER*-AAAAAAAH!!!!" I assume Space Marine suffers the same problem Source games have, but I can't confirm this so I won't go into too much depth about it (god knows I get enough flame wars on these reviews just for saying Hack'n'Slash instead of Hash'n'Slash...Yeah don't ask) The Multiplayer  Normally I'd say the more content the better, but I think multiplayer is the reason why less attention was placed into the singleplayer. But besides that, you start off with a class selection and a long♥♥♥♥♥road of unlocks (oh joy) Tactical, your basic soldier with a bolter rifle and a selection of grenades. After progressing for a while in multiplayer you'll find yourself with a wide selection of guns to use such as- the Plasma gun, sniper rifle, storm bolter, and finally a grenade launcher. Sadly other bolter varients from the lore are not in the game. Also the flame thrower isn't in there either which I have a hard time understanding.Heavy bolter marine, he starts out with a heavy bolter but eventually you get a las canon and a plasma cannon. Although I don't know why because the only "vehicle" in multiplayer is the Dreadnought, and that's a 9.99 DLC! Finally the Assault trooper, this is the most fun you'll get in multiplayer, jumping around from place to place with your jetpack. You start out with a chain sword but eventually you unlock stuff like the power axe and the thunder hammer. Sadly he dominates the other two classes once you get the hammer and it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥just killing one of them. The Final Verdict  When I first bought this game I wanted to give this game at least a 7/10! But later down the road I realised this game is mostly generic. And at it's worst, the PC port was hard to play with all the audio tearing and bugs.Then the multiplayer didn't help with the stupid♥♥♥♥♥progression system children these days demand we have in all of our game selections. If there were no loadouts or leveling system, just pick a gun up off the map then it would be fine. But because Call of Cancer has devoured the minds and hearts of game developers, publishers, and consumers alike we may never see triple A titles free themselves from this terrible trend.Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine is a 5/10! The console version is a 6/10, but only because the controls and the movement were smoother, and the audio wasn't making my ears bleed. It's decent, but that's all this game has to throw. My suggestion? Get this game when it's on sale, because Relic are a collection of fairly decent folk it goes on sale around 17 bucks every now and then. Until someone stops making Space Marine centered games I'm going to wait another 5 years.

It's damn amazing. Haven't tried multiplayer yet though, not really interested in trying at this time, but I'd still recommend this game to anyone looking for some intense action if you find it discounted.
