number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
												"Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine". The game where you're supposed to be the best of the best. One of the strongest thing in the Imperium of Man, however. That is not the case. I bought this game on release a few years ago when it was released and stopped at just at the beginning of Chapter 3. But as the years passed. I couldn't exactly remember why I put down the game, I saw it in my library and figured I'd reinstall it. I couldn't phantom why I put the game down without finishing it. So I booted up Singleplayer again to finish my campaign.  I recall watching an interview for the game before its release. I remember them saying, "You're a Space Marine. Cover is for♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Space Marine is designed to keep you in the fight." They completely failed on this. The combat is awful. You aren't a Space Marine, you're a ♥♥♥♥♥. Your shields go down in an instant until you get the Iron Halo (which is at the end of the game). You can be torn to shred by Orks no problem. Even the standard Chaos Space Marines you encounter later on the game are tougher than you are. Combat is flawed from the very beginning. Since you aren't supposed to be in cover, you're getting shot all the time. No matter where you are. There is no rest in a fight. You're always being hit unless you retreat back and hide behind some crates. Even then, most of the enemies. including the orks have unnatural accuracy. You'll learn to despise the Orks with Rokkit Launchas and Chaos Marines with Plasma Cannons, as they'll volley over any cover you're hiding behind and hit you directly. But then, it doesn't matter. Since the game doesn't focus around cover, you'll still take damage from any rockets or grenades that explode on the other side of what you're hiding behind. One hit is enough to completely remove your shield, and two or three more will outright kill you. So if you get hit by all three rokkits at once? You're dead. The game largely revolves around staying in melee combat and preforming executions to keep yourself going. However, if you try to preform one while in the middle of combat, you'll either get the same amount of health you started with, or you'll just die. As I mentioned, enemies have an unnatural accuracy with all their weapon. During the cut scenes for the executions, you can (and will) still get hit by any ranged or unit within melee range. The unnatural accuracy also extends to the point where they can fire through their teammates and still hit you without killing their buddies. (Excluding Grenades and Rokkit Launchas). Later on in the game you'll start encountering chaos pyskers, they'll fire a beam at you and if you're hit in the open by one. You're as good as dead.  Fights are all designed around this type of encounter. An extremely powerful ranged unit in the back (or several). While you get swarmed by melee infantry which can quickly over run you. So most of the game is just back peddling into corners to deal with all the melee infantry before you can peek out and take a few pot shots at the ranged units, as staying out for more than a few shots will generally get you killed. This if course, gets worse along in the game as you go from dealing with Orks to Chaos. At some points you'll be getting bombarded by plasma weapons, pyskers and swarmed by traitor guards and regular chaos space marines. Most of those fights require simply dumb luck and very slow movements to progress through. Dealing with Chaos is simply a cluster♥♥♥♥, as when you're distracted with those who pose a threat, you'll be getting shot by traitor guard, who serve no purpose other than to take up half of your screen with the hit indicator.  So the game is about 6-8 hours of the same combat over and over, ontop of artificial difficulty. It quickly gets frustrating as the game has no actual save system, just check points. Which is extremely annoying as dying some times will put you back right before a lengthy cut scene. (Looking at you, boss fights). Which are unskippable. The game is the same story as literally every other Warhammer game. You're under attack by orks, then SURPRISE ITS CHAOS, even though it was completely obvious from the beginning.  Even the very end wave fight is awful, and insanely harder than the last boss.It consist of going through several waves of enemies with little to no cover. Each wave having more♥♥♥♥♥♥tacked onto it. If you fail it, you have to start back down the hallway so you have to run back and watch the same few minute long cutscene again. The Boss fight after it is a compete joke, its an on-rails quick time event where you fall down a spire. A few moments have free movement where you can dodge stuff thrown at you. For some reason you can fire, but Titus just holds his gun to the side and all the bullets fly off the screen.  The secret to killing the boss is this: 1-1-1, hit space, 1-1-1, hit space. Hit F, cutscene. Repeat x2-3 times. Congrats, you win.TL:DR?- You play as a weak♥♥♥♥♥Space Marine Captain.- Muh Ultrasmurfs.- Awful, repetitive combat.- Extremely accurate orcs.- Demons are somehow weaker than Chaos Marines.- Same exact story as any of the other games.- Bad check point system.- Dead Multiplayer. If you're a 40k fan, you'll find several annoying flaws in the game. So I'd recommend passing this game up and go play Dawn of War or Chaos Gate. Something else worth your time. If you're looking to have some fun and don't care about repetitive combat. Pick it up for when its less than 20 on a steam sale, forget about all the DLC since mutliplayer is dead.If you're looking to just play Multiplayer. Don't. The only active game mode is Exterminatus, all of the others are dead. Including the DLC ones, even Chaos Exterminatus. So save yourself the money.

number of helpful: 8 of 18 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												This is a bad game, hiding behaind a great license. It is very pretty, very repetitive, and presents Space Marines as slightly stronger than your average Ork.What this game does best, by far, is present a stunningly beautiful graphical display. The Ultramarines, weapons, jump packs, and world at large faithfully recreate the best iteration of a Warhammer 40K universe in any game out there. I believe this is what has led to so many positive reviews. The gameplay however, is not good. Repetitive to the extreme, hordes of enemies come at you, and you press X a lot. When a larger enemy comes at you, you press Y, then X a lot. Sometimes you press B as a "finishing move" which restores health. Each weapon has two finishing move animations. You will see them a lot.What is more infuriating however, is how this game does the exact opposite of what we all hoped it would; play a near-invincible juggernaut that is a Space Marine captain. Far from feeling invulnerable however, you will quickly learn that small groups of enemies can take you down very quickly. Individual Orks take 6-8 shots from your heavy bolter to kill. Your two squadmate Ultramarines are borderline useless, and any form of squad tactics are completely absent. And for some reason, Relic decided to use the Halo-style personal shield for the Space Marines. Meaning, as you wade into combat, you will frequently need to run away and duck behind a corner for your shield to regenerate. It is also notworthy that this game has no form of a "cover" system.Very pretty, very repetitive, makes Space Marines out as slightly stronger imperial guardsmen. If that sounds appealing to you, this is your game.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												I re-completed this game on Hard some time ago, and though it was somewhat fun while it lasted, the game is, in fact, far from perfect in most aspects.The most obvious flaw of the game is its repetitivity. Throughout the story different weapons and enchancements become available, sure, but essentially the gameplay situations themselves are becoming more and more of a deja vu as you proceed.  You jump into some new portion of terrain. There are Ork. You have to battle through their forces to reach a more powerful group of Ork, then you either interact with something or get a vox-transmission from your allies, and the next portion of terrain (and Ork) unlocks.  You reach a relatively vast area with a passage which is locked. You have to reflect an enemy attack to proceed (sometimes one of your followers are busy with certain story action while you cover them). There is always an elevated area you cannot get to, from which the waves of enemies come.  You are trapped in an arena-shaped location. A boss calls in waves of enemies. When you are done with them, he gets to you and you have to complete a QTE for a cinematographic KO.There are some refreshing moments, like jetpack riding, but they are like dessert, before which you always get to eat another full pot of cereal. Perhaps, it would be less noticeable if the game would turn out to be less absurd by both the terms of WH40K canon and mere common sense.  A forge-world, the marvel of imperial engineering, basically supposed to be a giant temple of Omnissiah, is protected by imperial guardsmen instead of Legiones Skitarii. I mean, how lore ignorant could that possibly be? It`s essentially like guarding a Pentagon with one 80-year old grandpa with a pre-WWII hunting rifle.  _Three_ space marines dealing first with an entire Ork WAAAAGH, warboss included, then  with a warband of a prized Chaos champion followers, the champion himself included, too, is this an actual game storyline or a teenage fanfiction? If things worked that way, none would dare attack any imperial world - there are certainly enough space marines to put just three of them to guard each planet.  An Ultramarine captain tells his fellow Ultramarine he did wrong by strictly abiding the Codex. I wonder if the developers just happened to run into a list of bad WH40K-themed jokes and thought they would paste them into the script - or rather just make them a script.Overall, the singleplayer part of the game is just not worth the pain. The multiplayer has a lot less sharp edges and generally allows more diversity, but still looks like a semi-serious wannabe-Warhammer game, with power armor painted all colours of rainbow (acceptable for Chaos, but nonsense for loyalists) and a pretty standard, though entertaining, gameplay. There is also Dreadnought assault, but finding an active game is extreme luck. Whoever finds himself a fan of the 40K universe should probably only buy this with a major discount.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2014
												Space Marine.... as long time fan of Warhammer 40.000 universum ( and tabletop wargame ) I was curious about this game a lot. It was a bit of let down. First impressions are great, Astartes feels bulky and heavy, atmosphere is breathing 40k greatly but it kinda vanish after couple of levels and then there are problems. This game is very repetitive. You really do just 1 thing all the time. Levels are plain and bit boring by design. Essentialy you are either inside where there is not much difference between different buildings or you are outside which is only differently textured hallway...no big open spaces.Also if you are fan of 40k and know something about Space Marines you´ll get dissapointed some more. Bolter feels good, sound is great, overall awesome but performance in actuall killing is underwhelming. Ork boy wearing a t-shirt  easily takes  4-5 rounds to body which is in fluff enough to put down a space marine in power armour. Another thing which felt a bit wrong was that you play as Ultramarine, a chapter known best for their tactical aproach to things and here it´s really just bloodbath more suited for say Space Wolves or World Eaters... it just doesn´t feel like Ultramarine.So if you are not a fan of 40k or you don´t know about it a bit there is slightly above average 3rd person shooter/slasher for you. You´re gonna play it, finish it but you won´t probably remember it. 6/10If you are fan of 40k you´re gonna joy puke at the beginning (especially if you are imperial fan, as I am chaos player in tabletop) but you are gonna be sorely dissapointed by the end of it if you even make it there. 5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2015
												First of all, I'm a big fan of Warhammer 40k setting, tabletop games and PC strategy games; I LOVED the possibility of playing in an action game based in this universe: being a Space Marine, saving Imperial Guardsmen, meeting Inquisitors and defeating Chaos.I hoped it was good. I WANTED it to be good....however, this game is AWFUL.What we've got here is a boring, linear, repetitive third person action/shooter game. Every area is structured as an "arena" where you'll fight endless hordes of Orks (with a little variation in the last hours) with no strategy, timing or ability involved. Again and again. And again.These fights will be EXTREMELY easy, except for some difficulty spikes thrown randomly into the game. When you die you never feel like it was your fault, nor you feel to improve your abilities when you defeat 10 or 15 'Ard Boyz.Then there's the setting. Every ambient has no details and is identical to the one before and to the next one, meaning you'll be frequently lost and looking for an exit. There's no map, but don't worry: once you've reached an area you won't be able to go back to the previous one, meaning that exploration is absolutely useless. Moreover, you don't get any strategic benefit from the environment, except for some explosive barrels or crates of ammo & granades once in a while, so why bother?In the end, this game was a huge disappointment for me. Go buy it ONLY if you know and love Warhammer 40k lore and the only thing you want to do for the next 15 hours is press X on your controller. Over and over again.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												My problem with this game is in its combat system. It have a melle combat and quite a lot of ranged weapons. It mix very well and its fluid, but there is a bit of a problem if you use melle as a primary combat choice.The strongest melle weapon in the game, called Thunder Hammer, locks you to using only 2 ranged weapon slots from total of 4. And those 2 slots are reserved to a pistol and your standart Space Marine rifle. It would not not be a big problem, if the game didnt switch to a huge shooting galery in the middle of the game.In the first half of the game those combat arenas are fine, because you can get to 95% of the enimes on foot and the enimes have good mix of ranged and melle units. But as you progress through the game, most enemies start to be a very powerful ranged units and on top of that, those combat arenas will restrict your movement in a way that you cant reach those units on foot.So only choise you have is to shoot them down, with ranged weapons which are pistol and standart rifle. The rifle does the job quite well, but you need a lot of bullets just to shoot down 1 guy, so you burn through your ammo very quickly. That leaves you with a pistol that have unlimited ammo but have no damage and no accuracy. This is where the frustration comes in, because the game become unnecessary difficult and punishes melle playstyle.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												Pros:-Warhammer 40K universe is awesome-Gameplay is fun-Cool 40K guns-Fun set pieces-You get to use the Thunder Hammer-Imperial Guard and other Space Marines fun to fight with-Take downs are cool-Ork Nobs-Unintentional comedy -The way you kill the final boss is hilarious-Multiplayer character customization Cons:-Every character is boring-Scope and epicness of 40K killed by how constrained and linear the levels are and how small the engagements are-Very weak script and uninteresting dialogue. If you've ever play the Dawn of War 1 RTS games, you'll understand-Invincible boring robot like allies-Being in elevators-Pressing green buttons-Absolutely terrible ending. Very unsatisfying-Lackluster music. No intense low male chanting or drums, just weak score-Multiplayer not worth playing. Constant host migration and boring unimaginative Chaos Marines VS Space Marine gameplay. Imagine if it was like Battlefront with Imperial Guard vs Orks with players unlocking heros (Space Marine, Warbosses / Ork Nobs) to use in battle every once in a while. Tons of AI everywhere and vehicles. Instead they took the easy boring route, not worth buying the collection with all the multiplayer DLC. -No cool melee combos to learn-No reason to play through a 2nd time-Chaos Space Marines poof into purple dust when killed6.5/10 Buy the normal edition when it goes on sale for under 10 dollars. This is coming from a huge fan of Warhammer

												I played through the solo-campaign in this third-person shooter and I was kind of blasted. Im a huge Warhammer 40K fan and this game was basically a must buy for me. If you finished the campaign which took me like 5 or 6 hours the bloodthirst of your bolta is not over, not even close to be over! The war continues in fast paced online battles where you gain levels for achiving challenges or killing other players. You unlock new outfits and new weapons. There are not many maps, but the maps available are awesome and hard to master. I can REALLY recommend this to EVERYONE who loves Warhammer 40k, you will not regret it. For all guys who like action, grab it aswell! For those who like to experience a long single player campaign, this is not the game you are looking for. PS: The DLC`s are actually worth it.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
												So I bought this off of the back of Totalbiscuit's nerdgasm of a First Impressions video. Unfortunately, for whatever reason, I encounted unbearable reverb on the sound effects that drowned out music and dialogue. Worse, even Space Marine's pretty dedicated fanbase is apparently unable to fix. But I muted the soundeffects (music & voice acting is fine) and proceeded onwards.  The gameplay is good, nice weapon and enemy variety, voice acting is pretty solid and the story is passable enough. I haven't touched the multiplayer.Then, my save file corrupted and I ended up stuck at the end of a level with an absent cutscene trigger. It has a single savefile (smauto.dsav) hidden away in the Steam userdata folder, which you can only back up by copying and pasting.Sega Support's only solution was create a new save file AKA restart the campaign. Let's just say I wasn't happy.Though I liked playing it, I'm can't recommend it. The lack of soundeffects soured the experience considerably, let alone the eleven hours of gameplay lost to a in-game save system that is frankly unfit for PC. I shouldn't have to exit the game to create a separate save file. These two issues have killed any desire I had to play the game.It is however a rarely authentic Warhammer 40k experience. If you buy it, remember to back up your saves regularly to save yourself some grief.TL;DR+Positives+Authentic Warhammer 40kGood gunplay, simple yet fun meleeVaried enemies & weaponsSolid performance by the cast-Negatives-An unfixable bug that creates unbearable reverb on sound effects.Muted weapons make me sad.Single save file system is susceptible to corruption, which will force you to restart the campaign.Manually saving (as in locate, copy and paste the smauto.dsav) is annoying.A solid game with one immersion-killing technical issue and another of the potentially gamebreaking variety. Your experiences may differ, but it might not.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2011
												This game had a huge amount of promise and it just fails to deliver on every front. It could have been designed as a shooter, or it could have been designed as a melee combat game and done very well at either role. Instead it does "OK" at both roles. In addition you are walking a hallway. Yes, the hallways have different textures and sometimes cover but they are literally hallways that define the path you must take. I haven't seen combat like this since I played side scrollers on the neo-geo, Space Marine may be 3d but the gameplay is the same. If the game gave you an open map, and you had more use of the jump pack the game would double the fun that it is, but you don't. So I don't recommend this game unless you just have to own everything 40k or you really love Space Marines. The novels describing the 40k Universe portray a gritty Universe of depth that you can imagine, somehow upon seeing the world in Space Marine it manages to make it unreal and shallow.

The Teleporting- If you're unlucky enough to get this problem then just try going into a different lobby or gamemode otherwise prepare for the rage as you get destroyed by everyone since you are lagging like crazy, this happens even if you have fantastic ping by the way so either wait it out or go search for a new gameOverall, i really like the game, i havent beaten the campaign yet, going to soon probably. Try avoiding the multiplayer unless you need something, it's really not worth the rage so stick to co-op, which is called Exterminatus.I personally give the game 7/10 Killstreak Kills

content:
Posted: June 18, 2013
												Nostalgia, nostalgia, nostalgia. As a huge 40k fan in my childhood, I don’t know why it took me so long to play this game. Has been in my library for about 2 years and just never played it. Boy, was I missing out. The game plays similar to Prototype, but much simpler controls for use on a keyboard. The story line is nice, I wasn’t a big follower of 40k lore, but that didn’t matter, you get caught up on everything fairly quickly and I came out the end knowing that little bit more about the Warhammer universe.  The game’s length is just about right;  it does however leaves open ends to the story which could lead to a sequel which would be nice.  If you are a fan of the 40k series, this game is certainly worth a go, I loved seeing all of the different races and army’s come into life, Orcs, undead, Chaos, all there. Not sure how much someone would get out of it if they weren’t a fan of the series though – might just be a run of the mill hack-n-slash to them. Still, recommend a play through for what it costs.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
DO NOT BUY THIS FOR THE MULTIPLAYER.DO NOT BUY THIS FOR THE MULTIPLAYER.DO NOT BUY THIS FOR THE MULTIPLAYER.Client-side hosting that'll sporadically migrate hosts regardless of if the host has a good enough connection, often chosing the worst host as far from the other players as it possibly can. You're forced to play competitive multiplayer if you want to unlock armor pieces or weapon perks that actually make your weapons useful, even if you only have interest in playing the cooperative mode.Third party programs exist that allow cheating in multiplayer, so it's kinda sketchy trying to grind up or get achievements when you don't know if you're playing against legitimate players or not. It's already difficult enough when you're being SMASHED because you don't have the same perks unlocked, but you'll usually run into the same crowd of people as the MP community is small as can be. And alot of times, they seem dedicated to emptying out the server/community by conducting themselves as trolly as they can, an example being a clan stacking nothing but lascanons on open maps.On the other hand, it has a pretty solid single-player and the cooperative mode can be fun if you get a bunch of buddies in a private match, it's basically like Mass Effect 3's multi, survive through x amount of waves of enemy, maybe a capture the point objective here... Just don't do an open match. Even if you and your buddy start the match, some random person from across the world may end up in your game and for some reason, this game will decide to migrate the host to them and now you and your buddy have to leave because your connection is now ♥♥♥♥ed.There is a diamond in the rough here, it's just so rough you'll perhaps find yourself bitterly glad THQ went out of business and wishing the same of Relic.

												Just finished the Singleplayer campaign .... Linear leveldesign, alot of story cramped into a small amount of time, multiple bossfights set in the last hour of gameplay, little variation in enemies.HOWEVER ... the guns are great, the levels (though linear) look great, the cutscenes dont interupt anything, enough quiet hallways and small walks to calm down and both the melee as well as gun combat are freaking amazing. content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												2/10This game was 4 years in the making, and has that feel that if they'd had 6 more months they could have made something truly awesomeThey didn'tSadly, they didn'tIt's a pity, because I really wanted to like this one, even if there was an Ultramarine, rather than any of the more interesting options (I sense the heavy hand of GW marketing there)This game's single player campaign lasts areound 9 hours2 of those hours are spent riding in liftsanother half hour is spent on cut scenes, leaving a short 3rd person shooterSomehow, in that short time, it still manages to get repetitive, tedious and boring.The designers went with the decision of making one model per enemy class, making about 20 different things to hit in total. When they attack in hordes of a half-dozen at a time, the lack of variety shows. When these same hordes attack in consecutive rooms for an hour, you give in to despair. Identical hordes charging headlong would have seemed OK if they were Tyranic, but Da Orkz is famous for their kustom jobz and variety.This makes it feel cheap and rushed, which is a shame.

number of helpful: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												Overall, the story is cliche' and can be seen from 3 miles off by a blind guy including all the plot twists. This wouldn't be an issue, if not for the fact that the game seems intent on minimizing any of the interesting things within the 40k lore, you don't see any of the awesome armor of the Imperial Guard laying waste at range (yes, yes, I know, they were being overran, but then we should have seen Orkz with looted tanks, then, eh?), Space Marine mechs, or the tons of baddies and variants of the Chaos and Orkz forces. This felt less like a planet wide invasion and war than it did a strike force, and this is made all the worse when you see that even when Chaos forces are preparing to invade and wreck things, there are only the most minor of vehicles of the Guardsmen in any respect. Even when the Imperial fleet arrives, you don't see any vehicles really, aside from troop transport ships... This could be forgiven if the gameplay was amazing, but that is next.The gameplay is repetitive, and I can already hear folks say, "Well yeah, you're a Space Marine, of course! You are meant to kill things over and over!". There is one major problem though... You feel invincible. Aside from 1-2 deaths from being cornered as I rolled into a wall, there wasn't anything to fear. The AI went to the Herpa Derp school of combat, and this is most clearly seen by the Chaos Marines. They seemingly forget that their most hated enemy, the Space Marines, were just shooting at them, only to have you step around and then look at you as they ponder if you'll be their friend. "Maybe this time we can frolic in the fields of bones and snuggle vorpal bunnies as the blood fountains start in the background!" I don't expect super secret tactics taught to only the most elite of forces, but I do expect more then move left, move right, then get shot, or to stare at you with their heads conveniently out of cover. Orkz should be more charging and melee (which I admit many of thier units are melee which is nice, but far too squishy for even the standard bolter). The Chaos forces are just sort of a joke, especially the Guardsmen, and even their marines are a simple headshot with the laser cannon, they feel less like a real challenge as opposed to being really "challenged". What's more, there is a lot of padding as you walk through various corridors of rubble, and without a jump feature (aside from some of the funnest sections of the game which are all too brief, and honestly the the only major redeemer in single player) it greatly limits exploration in a giant planet factory. About 9 models for the Orkz which is sad given Orkz are not what one would call "organized" with standard gear aside from some having melee primarily, others ranged, you can't expect every Ork unit to be exactly the same.  It's even worse with Chaos, as the idea is these units are being warped into monsters essentially at random (as if Chaos wasn't a hint at that), clocking in with 8 models as well. These counts are including the Warboss of the Orkz, as well as the Chaos Commander of the Chaos forces. If I am off, the count is likely not off by more then 1-2 as I recall the units from memory. I'm not saying make every single unit look different, that would be an insane task when you have a swarm of Orkz coming down on you, but you do expect to see more then one model for every enemy (with the exception, perhaps, of the standard daemons of Chaos). This could have been achieved easily with something so simple as some minor palet and texture swaps on the faces, and 2-4 scars made for the Orkz to put on faces randomly upon spawn. Yeah, it wouldn't change much, but it wouldn't look as bland, and would take little work. I'll grant you, Chaos would be harder to make have variants, because for all intents and purposes, the Chaos forces (the marine portions there of, and the corrupted Guardsmen) look the same as their Space Marine counterparts, aside from palet swaps of course for the most part, but that isn't to say you can't have tumors or something (again, 2-4 variations) to help liven up the roster so it doesn't look like you're killing a corrupted Guardsmen, and his 15 identical brothers who all so happen to work for Chaos too. As has been said already, the game feels dull, and if not for the sale, I'd say it's not worth it. Even with the sale, it took me 6.9 hours to complete the campaign while a cat "helped" me play. Was it worth 7.50 USD? Yes, but not much more, as much of that playtime was padded by lifts of inexplicable requirement, and hallways of nothing but ammo and the occassional collectable.  4/10

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												This is a review for single player only.First of all nevermind the fact that the game looks like absolute 4rse, one can get over it.But the whole game simply bored me like a very few other.The plot is a snoozefest and I couldn't care less anything said during the dialogs.Unfortunately I couldn't get my XInput controller to work with this game, but I didn't make much effort to do so, since you have ranged weapons and I'd prefer K+M aim over it. However the implemantation of it or simply the character movements don't feel good at all.Your character, Captain Titus, moves so slowly, sluggishly that it's just not fun to control. It would be balanced by your melee attacks feeling powerful, hacking through dozens of orc (and other creatures) however the pacing is so bad that sometimes the game feels either too easy or way to hard. When easy you get the "Aaww yeah I'm so powerful" feeling while you still have to keep an eye on your health. However when the game is hard, you have to move with a snail's pace in order to not get killed within a few seconds and at lest in my opinion this isn't the game's primary goal.Also you have to stun then execute enemies in order to regain health. However the animations for it are so lengthy that you can get killed by doing so. You would think that during the __lengthy__ execution animations you wouldn't be hurt to balance it but nope... I got killed so many times while regaining health that I'd simply given up on melee and only used it when there were very few enemies around.The gameplay and said pacing: kill a bunch of enemies, "run" a bit, press "e" to open door, get in elevator, wait for your mentally challenged AI partners to get in the elevator, press "e" to start elevator, rinse and repeat. That's it. (Oh yeah, there was a turret section once, "great fun"...)Speaking of AIs, it's bad... horribly so... The friendly AIs sometimes don't shoot at all at enemies and/or simply just stand in the line of friendly/enemy fire or just blocking your way...Overall I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone. Even I couldn't be bothered to play through it, even though I hate not finishing something.

												Recognition as an action game:As an action game, Spacemarine genuinely does what it set out to do: It is a relatively fast paced- and sometimes intense game with a lot of blood flying all over the place, orcs roaring at you, guns blazing like nobody's business and you seldomly have a quiet moment. Multiplayer is a disaster though and the DLC is infuriatingly obvious and sickening.Recognition as a Warhammer 40k game:Oh my, where to start? I will be brief and without too much detail, but trust me I could say a LOT! about this game- Anyway. This game is such an absolute disappointment due to its incredible "surfacey" modus operandi. It never ever explores the WH40K lore in any appreciable depth (and the list of missing things is huge), it never gives you any choices, it never gets tactical and the whole thing feels very "consoley" and cheap - This is a VERY poor representation of WH40K and is barely what I'd call a game. I Am VERY disappointed, because my god this game is boring

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5
												Many years I waited. Stalking this thing in the background. The cancellations. The change of company hands. And the promises..oh the many many promises. As a raving frothing at the mouth "FOR THE EMPEROR!!" type its at least a borderline acceptable 40k game. However for the average gamer it will be a beautiful 40k game graphically but gameplay wise it is very lacking. It has a shield and health system similar to that of halo and a perspective like that of the gears of war games. The combat is a hack and slash system that lacks a block button, emphasizes stun locking, and gives you the ability to dodge roll. Then of course it wouldn't be 40k without guns but you can compare that to gears of war without a cover system. You can charge through "some" objects(very very few)which occasionally feels awesome. I have personally beaten the game on all difficulties be it through a console or PC and the game becomes most difficult when the armies of chaos appear. They tried to make a story that was honestly fairly good for the time when it was released, but it is the survival mode that stood out to me and kept me coming back when I would have cast it aside much sooner. But in conclusion for the many years I sat watching all the tidbits and development occur I find this game disappointing and unless your a frothy mouthed space marine lover like myself this game is something I would honestly pass up and look toward something else.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												I got this game while it was on a Steam sale, and am VERY glad I did - it's frankly not worth $30 U.S., mostly due to the disappointing campaign.The whole sordid affair took me less than six hours to beat, the lore was so deep that a sizable number of the references they dropped in-game made no sense, and the ending left me with the same bad taste in my mouth as Halo 2 and Half Life 2 - huge amounts of build-up to a supremely disappointing let-down. The gameplay was solid and chopping down swarms of Orks was satisfying to the Nth degree, but they make the classic blunder of introducing a new bad guy 3/4 of the way through the game.  I haven't tried the multiplayer, and frankly don't intend to.  If I wanted a game that had to surive on its multiplayer content, I would have bought Modern Borefare 12 or something like that.In sum: incredible potential, sullied by an unsatisfactory ending and characters with story arcs so flat you could level a foundation with them.
